reviews.title: Meh.. got really bored
reviews.text:
I really liked Dragon Age Origins and wound up playing it multiple times through on different classes. I believe my gameplay time was 60 hours, mostly because I wanted explore every nook of the game.

I just finished Dragon Age II this afternoon in 35 hours of playtime. I COULD have played longer, but was getting incredibly bored with doing the same types of quests in the same locations over and over again, so I ultimately chose to just head for the endgame and get it over with.

With Dragon Age: Origins you had a sense of purpose and a goal you felt you were reaching for...

In Dragon Age II you feel as if you are wandering about aimlessly doing quests for cash, because in reality that is what you are doing most of the time.

[tiny spoiler in next paragraph]

About 30% of the way into the game you feel as if you are finally breaking away from the city, when you join an expedition into the deep roads. I was excited when this part came up as I felt it was going to lead to the rest of the quest.. however, once you are done with the expedition, you go BACK to the city and start doing the repetitive questing again until the end of the game.

After 30 hours, the game started to feel really "grindy", just doing stuff so you can gain levels.. cash.. and equipment. If I want to grind I will go play an MMORPG.. PS3 games shouldn't have these aspects as part of the basic gameplay. Now that I am done, I have no desire to go back and play again with a different strategy. Of the 35 hours I played... I'd say 30 of them were spent in the exact same locations doing the same thing.

With the above said.. it is not ALL bad. The graphics were fantastic. The characters were interesting and fun.. especially the interplay between them. The fighting was ramped up a lot from the first version, making it a nice challenge at times and I was really enjoying it up until [same small spoiler about to happen] you wind up BACK in town after finally getting out of that place.

Overall.. if you are just looking for the Dragon Age experience... it will fill that void. However, if you are looking for an epic storyline and lots of adventure... find something else. This will likely frustrate you more than you will enjoy it.

reviews.title: A great start with lots of potential - Potential failed... Cancelled my sub.
reviews.text:
Leaving my previous review below, because it was written before patch 1.2 and what this game was to become, so you can read my original optimism!

What ruined potential. Once you hit level 50, the game becomes an absolute mindless grind, with no sense of purpose at all. It is one thing to do the same raids over and over if they are fun or have purpose, but it loses its luster quickly and becomes the usual (stand on the x, hit the 3 key seven times, then the 5 key times and then stand on spot Y). The PvP (basically now reduced to warzones ONLY) have absolutely no sense of purpose, except to grind for gear. They are supposedly introducing "team" play, but they missed the opportunity to have a overall purpose to the PvP, such as helping your chosen FACTION. Open world PvP is non-existent and had no sense of purpose either.

For a game that started off telling an amazing story... it completely loses its way towards the end and you just don't care about what happens anymore.

Space combat.. great potential gone wrong. You wind up repeating the exact same space missions during your initial progressions. (The level 40 missions are the exact same as the level 20 missions, just with slightly higher goals (kill 40 fighters instead of 20).

When they added content to the story in patch 1.2.. I didn't both to complete it as I had stopped caring about the storyline.

It's a shame, because this could have been a fantastic game, but they took the easy way out and decided to turn it into a mindless grind.

This is defiantly one of the better MMO's and has some aspects that make it much better than the rest.

The Best Aspects:

The story line is fantastic and the voice acting makes it much more enthralling than other games which simply present you with a wall of text. It maintains the feel of both an MMO and single player game.

Crafting. Finally a game got this right. You don't have to spend endless boring hours grinding away at resource gathering and standing over a forge. You get companions in the game and send them on missions and they gather the resources for you and craft the items, earning you experience. This is the first MMO where I am actually doing the crafting.

They have nice bonus systems to encourage you to group, but you don't HAVE TO if you don't want to in order to complete your story line. (If you group with others you earn experience from them completing quests as well as you own, so you level much faster!)

The Good Aspects:

Space combat is a lot of fun, but isn't fleshed out yet. You can do space missions, but are essentially stuck on a rail as your ship steers itself through space and you control where and what you shoot, with small room for movements.

Characters are pretty customizable, as you can switch your skill tree. So you can go up the healing tree and then decide you want to do DPS and go back to your trainer and spend some credits to reassign your skills. (You get the first swap for free). You can also create interesting hybrid characters, who can serve dual purposes.

What needs work:

The PVP just isn't there yet. There isn't anything to encourage people into open world PvP, so it is pretty much restricted to "warzones". These are mini, repeatable instances where they put equal number of republic and empire and give them a goal to achieve. Great idea.. execution isn't there yet. There is no in game voice communication, so you get thrown into a random group and then it becomes difficult to execute because you can't communicate quickly. Further they put people of all levels into the same warzone and although they scale your HP up to level 50, unless you are level 50, your gear and skills aren't on par. (Hopefully they will bracket the warzones in the future to make them more balanced).

Overall, however, this is a great game that has lots of potential. Hopefully they resist the urge to go with other MMO's have gone before them and just turn it into a constant grind for gear. Right now, it isn't grindy and that alone makes it worth playing!

reviews.title: Not what it promises to be.
reviews.text:
This is a game that had a TON of potential, but completely missed the mark.

I was extremely excited for all that this game promise.. This game promises No Classes, No Levels, Total Freedom of Play...the reality of the game is quite different.

I think everyone understood there was some wiggle room in their marketing statements, as there would be some type of progression and "leveling", which there is. Instead of the traditional leveling, you earn Skill Points and Ability points and apply them to a "skill wheel", which unlocks different skills for different weapons. This ultimately allows for a single character to take on any role in the game.. wanna be a tank, switch weapons, wanna be a healer, switch weapons, so the only real reason to create an "alt" is to join a different faction or for cosmetic purposes.

Unfortunately, where the game goes horribly wrong is in the forced progression curve, which winds up being far more restrictive and linear than many of the other MMORPG's I played (including SWTOR, which had a very linear and specific storyline to follow).

The usual MMO experience is you move into a zone, pick up all the quests, do the quests, gain experience "clear" the zone and then move onto the next, harder zone. Some people choose to focus on one quest at a time, some people follow a specific storyline, and some people grab everything in place and grind through quests as fast as possible... Secret World is NO DIFFERENT in set up. If you do not clear most of the zone, you will not be powerful enough to move onto the next zone. However, unlike other MMO's, Secret World restricts HOW you go through the zone and forces you to constantly backtrack in a forced time sink.

In The Secret World, you accept mission A from character A. On the way to your objective you encounter character B who requests you also to complete a task at the same place. You go to accept this new missions thinking "cool, I can kill two birds with one stone" and you get a warning window that you must "pause" quest A to accept quest B. If you choose to pause quest A and take quest B, you have to go back to character A to "unpause" quest A, leaving you to run back and forth over the same ground several times... and it isn't just character A and B, you come across character C, D, E, F and G along the way and each time you talk to them you are told you can't accept their missions without abandoning the mission you are on... Freedom of play? Why can't I get BOTH bandages and medication from the pharmacy at the same time?? No, I have to get the bandages, return them to character A, then find character D again, go back to the same pharmacy and find the medication and return it to character D and then hunt out character B who wanted water from the store which was right next to the pharmacy.

The developers have offered several conflicting excuses for this baffling limitation, everything from "memory problems on the backend" to it being a high level decision made to force you to get immersed in each mission, instead of treating characters like mission hubs. Ultimately, one honest dev admitted that if they removed the limitation it would break the progression curve and they would have to reduce the amount of experience you gained from each mission and people would complain there isn't enough content. (ie, we need to force you to run back and forth because you would progress through the game too fast if we allowed you to follow a logical progression.)

This brings me back to the main selling point... "TOTAL FREEDOM OF PLAY" If I am someone who chooses to grind quests, why is there something wrong with that? If am someone who WANTS to focus on one quest at a time, great. If I want to do 3 at a time, why am I not allowed to make that choice? They made it 100% clear in the forums that this system was NOT up for debate and would NOT be changed under any circumstances. This non-intuitive questing system made the game feel like work, rather than fun. I was looking for a game that offered more freedom of gameplay and this felt exactly the opposite.

reviews.title: A good game that tries to break the mold (but probably shouldn't have)
reviews.text:
This review is based on the final beta weekend, which after playing I decided to go ahead and pre-purchase, but the game is not without some flaws, yet it is far FAR better than other recent offers in this genre (The Secret World I am looking in your direction!).

The graphics are well done and you really get a good sense of an immense world... it ALMOST felt too big and the directions you could go were fairly limitless.

The questing system was one of the better ones, as it gave you enough guidance to get you where you needed to go, but not so much that it was holding your hand. Further, you felt free to pursue whatever quests you wanted without being forced in a particular direction.

The game makes use of dynamic events, which is a little similar to rift, in that SOMETHING happens nearby and asks all nearby players to work towards a common goal. These are often helpful in also completing your quests. However, on the downside, I felt they relied on the dynamic events a little TOO MUCH, as it seemed one was popping up every 5 minutes, making them quickly become less of a special thing and more common place. Spacing them out more (maybe 1 or 2 per hour) would make them feel more special. Withing a few hours of questing, I was starting to ignore the onscreen notification of "an event is taking place nearby".

I really liked the PvP systems they developed for this game. First you have an arena style pvp zone, where you automatically get pumped up to top level, given all your skills and given the high end gear for your character. There are several different "capture the flag" style zones that you can jump right into and start pvp'ing as soon as you get into the game. In this same zone they also have tournament PvP, where you can get together with a pre-made group and battle other pre-made groups in the same zones. ( I spent most of my time during this beta in this zone so I could get an idea of the full capabilities of all the classes and once I got my grove, it was a blast!)

Secondly in PvP you have a WvWvW (world v world v world) system in which your entire server battles against other servers for dominance by capturing forts and key points on a map from one another. This really adds a added bonus to the game in that you feel a greater sense of purpose in joining with people on your own server to work together towards a common goal. There is no need to party up or join a raid, but you can still join in the battle and work together.

For me, the biggest negative, and the only reason I give this game only 3 stars is that in a decision to "break the mold" of MMORPGs the developers decided to do away with the "holy trinity" of DPS/TANK/HEALER and rather make each class self-sufficient. While I completely appreciate the thought, I don't think it quite worked out the way they planned and it seemed to do more to frustrate gameplay a little bit. While I agree that the idea of "needing a healer" or "needing a tank" to complete a raid or form a team needs to change, trying to completely eliminate these roles really diminishes the fun for people (like me) who flat out LIKE playing the healer or tank. This is where I felt The Secret World had a great idea (keep the basic dynamic, but allowing a character change professions on the fly), but they screwed up the questing system so much they made the game unplayable. So.. if you are someone who likes playing a healer or a tank, this game will be a little frustrating, because the playstyle you have become used to isn't supported here.

Further, it seems that while they eliminated "traditional" roles, class makeup still seemed to play a HUGE role in who won matches. Two Guardians (the closest they have to a "tank class" could essentially act as a single tank for an entire party (by chaining their conditional removal and regeneration efforts, they become almost unbeatable) and Warriors, when paired with elementalists, could deliver HUGE burst DPS through combinations... so while the stated goal of not having a healing class or a tank class was to remove the necessity of particular group make ups, there is STILL the necessity of group make ups if you want to win matches.

In short, while each individual class is nicely balanced against each other (no one class is really OP), group makeup still plays the primary role in how you will succeed and if you don't have the right class composition, you are going to lose your match, thus undermining the entire reason they eliminated the "holy trinity" to begin with.

While these are problems with the game play, it is still a fun game with lots of potential. For a "beta" it seemed EXTREMELY polished and ready to go. I am looking forward to seeing the final release.

reviews.title: A great game, that tries to break the mold (but probably shouldn't have).
reviews.text:
This really is a fun game to play in many different ways, but they had several great ideas, that just didn't appear to be executed in the best possible way. Some of these are easily fixed... some are built into the game structure and make it less fun than it could be.

On the PvE side of things, they have a fun and interesting storyline and LOTS to explore. Almost TOO MUCH too explore. In order to "complete" a map (which you get rewards for), you have to find every point of interest, every vista (a lookout point that you have to jump to), complete every quest, find every waypoint (travel spots), and earn every skill point. Those who love exploring, will, no doubt find this tons of fun. However, if you JUST follow your storyline, you quickly find that you wind up in areas far above your level, so it becomes in your best interest to either gain experience by completing the map OR finding another "starter zone" to do early quests. I am not a fan of being forced backwards before moving on and would rather the storyline flow more with your leveling, BUT they give you so many different ways to earn experience, that isn't so much of a drag that it brings you down. You also have "Dynamic events" that pop up and you can join in and help. (ie, minotaurs are invading and you need to help stop them).

I wanted to add a little more in here, in regards to the "completion" of a map and something I learned which is both good and bad. When you "complete" a map, I mentioned you get rewards. Those rewards are geared to your level. So, if you complete maps as you go along you will get random rewards for your level, which likely aren't worth much, because you level very quickly... However, IF you don't finish anything and then wait until level 80 to complete the zones... THEN you get very valuable rewards. Nice for people who rushed through early and then decide to go back and find all the vistas and points of interest... kinda sucky for people who spent the time to fully explore their maps at the lower levels.

There are 3 parts of the PvP world. First, there is tournament style Structured PvP, where your pre-made group of 5 faces off against another pre-made group. This can be fun, but quite annoying, as I will explain more below due to balance issues. Second, there is open PvP servers where you join a server and it randomly puts you on the red or blue team and you fight to control points. You may switch teams in the middle of a match, or from map to map. This is kinda fun, but again, due to some balance and mechanics issues I have with the game, not as fun as it could be. Then there is WvWvW (world v world v world), which is, by far, the most fun part of the game, where you join with your entire server to control points on a map and score points against other servers. Unfortunately, current queue times to get into WvWvW range from 3-5 hours, so, at the moment, getting in to play this aspect of the game is like winning the lottery. I am sure they will fix this will time, because that type of wait time is obviously unacceptable.

So.. what are the problems?

The dynamic events are too frequent and too repetitive. They are a really cool aspect of the game, but the novelty of them wears off quickly and you find yourself starting to ignore them after just a few hours of play. Worse, the same events pop up over and over and over again in the same spots. One particularly annoying one is right by the crafting stations and it won't let you craft until the "event" is over and it seems as if every time I hop over to craft, the "event" is happening.

My biggest complaint with the game that won't change and will frustrate many MMORPG gamers. They have done away with the "holy trinity" of Tank/Heals/DPS and given each class abilities to self heal, group heal, CC, tank, etc. There are some "tankier" classes and some that are more useful with group heals, but nothing like what you are used to. If you LIKED playing a healer or tank in previous games, you are likely to find GW2 quite frustrating... DPS is king here... You can put together some burst DPS builds that can bring down someone in seconds (or fractions of seconds), with little they can do about it. You have "control" and "support" roles, but in the end, a group of burst DPS thieves or life steal necromancers is going to roll over even the most skilled and "balanced" team.

Which brings me to what I mentioned earlier about balance. "Build" is king in this game. Even though everyone in SPvP is boosted to level 80 and given access to all the same weapons and their full skill trees... Which weapons you choose, which skills you slot and which traits you boost will 95% determine your dominance in PvP... skill is secondary to build. Having the right build will overpower skill nearly every time. My friend linked me a burst dps warrior built which I created and within minutes was dominating in PvP only having to press 3 keys over and over again. Maybe to some people spending hours going over different combinations of skills/traits/weapons to come up with the one that gives you the highest crit chance, coupled with the most vitality and toughness seems like fun. However, I just want to PLAY the game. So, yes, it is great that the give you lots of choices and the ability to create your own role, but I don't see any way they are every going to achieve true balance, there is going to be a constant flux of nerfing and buffing. In the build up to the game and interviews, this seemed to be exactly what they were trying to avoid, but maybe it is just an inevitability with MMORPGS?

So at the end of the day... it is a really fun game, but not without some serious flaws some of which are part of the design and some which will likely never be completely fixed.

reviews.title: PS3 Slim more useful
reviews.text: This has made my PS3 slim a lot more useful by adding extra USB 2.0  slots and the addition of the media readers slots built into the device. It was very easy to install and well worth the money spent.

reviews.title: Great Game
reviews.text: I just got this on Friday April 25th and have been playing all weekend. This reminds me of the early versions of the game but with modern graphics. I was able to figure out the controller without reading the instruction until I had to use the chat feature. Sort of reminds me of FF XI but with more visuals and greater gaming world. I look forward to leveling up my character and joining a party with my friends.

reviews.title: These are very comfortable and I use them in on line gaming with ...
reviews.text: These are very comfortable and I use them in on line gaming with fiends and they work flawlessly and my pals do not bitch about feedback noise anymore.

reviews.title: Uncomfortable after prolonged use
reviews.text: Prolonged use seriously hurts my hands.

reviews.title: Steam is Evil
reviews.text: I bought this a week ago and was happily playing until a steam update crashed it.  Now it doesn't work at all.  The problem is not with the game itself but with the evil steam wrapper.  Steam's support is entirely email based and they apparently can't be bothered to help.  They also don't allow refunds so they have very effectively stolen my money without providing a useable product.

reviews.title: Fantastic, mostly
reviews.text:
I received this mouse just a few hours ago and I love it. It did take me a little while to fully understand the programming software in order to make it do what I want. Now that I understand it, I don't have a single complaint. The Windows 7 x64 drivers installed without a glitch as did the programming software.

I like that I was able to change the palm rest to make it higher than normal and I was able to adjust the side buttons forward to put them in just the right place. In the 4 hours I've been using it, it has used 17% of the charge in one battery, not too bad in my opinion. I look forward to using more as so far I am very pleased.

UPDATE: It's 3 days later and I am in the process of returning it. I like it, a lot. I like how it feels and moves and nearly everything about it, except; Whenever I swap batteries when I plug the one to be charged into the receiver it disconnects from windows so I have to crawl under the desk and unplug/re-plug the usb cable. Mad Catz support told me they think it is a defective receiver but will not send a replacement unless I first send them this one. Thankfully Amazon is replacing it free of charge.

UPDATE 2: A month later, problems are solved and I am loving this mouse. As others have mentioned, battery life could be better but so far it's fine with me. Going back up to 5 stars.

reviews.title: Great Keyboard -  Great Price
reviews.text:
First off I want to note that I got this when it was priced at $29.99, perhaps the best deal I've ever got on a keyboard. I replaced a CM Storm Trigger with this after the Storm developed connection issues after only 3 months, probably the worst deal I've ever got on a keyboard.

I wish I had bought this one first because I like it better than the cm storm. It's much lighter and much, much easier to program. Obviously it doesn't have the nice cherry switches like the storm does and I am concerned on how long it will last, but it's a great keyboard and the touch is fine, I can't complain.

At first I was worried about the green lighting, I thought it would look strange and be hard to see. To my surprise it looks great and is very easy to see. To my eyes I'd have to say it's easier to see than either red or blue light, both of which I've had before.

And because I do all my typing with the keyboard resting between my indian style crossed legs it's light weight is great, so much better than having 3 pounds of keyboard digging into my legs.

The only CON I've found is sometimes when I type the keys will squeak a little and that is a bit annoying. If it ever gets bad I'll just pull the caps and touch the springs up with a bit of oil.

My only regret is that I didn't buy 2 or 3 of them when they were priced so low.

reviews.title: Overpriced and Uninspired
reviews.text:
I had really hoped for more from this game. Sadly it's more or less Civ 5 in new clothes with most of Civ 5's best features lost in the translation. Same as many others I've waited years for them to "finish" civ 5 and thought this would be a good culmination of their work. Wrong! This is more like starting over with a big step backwards.

I regret giving them my 50 bucks for this, it should have been downloadable content for civ 5. At least then some of the polish they'd achieved would have been carried over.

UPDATE: Minus another star, was 3 now 2. I've played several games of this new civ so far, they go much faster than usual. There are some neat things and now that I've got used to the interface it's ok too. What isn't ok is having to play on only random maps. No scenarios, no meticulously setting up the perfect game. And I'm sorry to say, random gets boring and repetitive very fast.

Hopefully soon they will release a map and scenario editor and given things like that have, for a very long time, been a part of Sid Meier's Civilization, it's pretty lame they release this game without it. IMHO.

2nd UPDATE: It's been a month now and still no update so there goes another star.

On a positive note, the game does play nicely. It moves along with an ease I've not before noticed in any civ and the soft sounds for events don't make me cringe.

reviews.title: Impressive
reviews.text:
"Wow," is the best I can think of to say about this game. It's really something and I like it a lot. Usually I only play serious strategy games such as Civilization and my past forays into console games have been far less than satisfactory. Thanks to the other reviewers here I decided to give this one a try and I'm very glad I did.

At first I was wondering if it is just an interactive story. I'm not much for the story aspects of games and it took several scenes before actual game play comes up. Surprisingly, I held in there and after the first couple short missions I was hooked. The story itself is not overly original but also not so common as to be boring. The main characters are likeable enough and as things progressed I found myself interested in what was going on and anxious to find out what would happen next.

So then, the Pros: The Graphics, great! I wasn't sure what to think of the watercolor/cartoon/anime mix at first but after seeing it in action I'm hooked. While most modern games seem to be going for the "real as life" look this game looks softer, less in your face. Also on the plus side of things is the ease of play. It was easy to learn how things work and to understand the goals and objectives set out. I got an Xbox controller to use with it, my first time ever using one, and I'm having a great time with it.

Another plus, to me, is the music. I often turn the music or all sound off when playing games because I usually find it distracting or somehow undesirable. This one is different and interesting is that parts of the music, while certainly different, is reminiscent of songs I've heard, some old and some not so old.

On the Cons side of things I'm coming up a little short. I would prefer to not have go through a configuration launcher every time and sometimes the story plays on emotions in ways I'd rather it didn't. Sometimes the story scenes are a bit long and I would get impatient for the next mission. And of course there's always those times such as when my best gunner totally misses the house sized tank 20 feet in from of him and gets me ranting and wanting an undo/redo/wtf button. But that's part of luck and chance and it wouldn't be a real game without. None of these things warrant losing even one star so my rating stands at 5 out of 5.

All in all I think this is one of the most refined and polished games I've ever played. It's done. Totally complete and playable on initial download. No waiting weeks or months for patches and updates. No hours spent grinding through forums hoping to find a fix for some inane problem. This game works and works well.

When the next episode or book in the story is released for the PC I will most certainly buy it too.

5 out of 5 stars for this one and kudos for the developers. Well Done!

reviews.title: Decent Keyboard, Horrible Software
reviews.text:
This keyboard is nice enough for the price. It has a good touch for typing and the red lighting shows up surprisingly well. What isn't nice is the programming software. In fact, it's some of the worst I've ever seen. They put almost no effort into it and the result is difficult, tedious and barely useable. If you're very interested in programming macros, get a logitech. I haven't tried the razor software so can't speak to it, but this software is much harder to program with than logitech's and even a bit worse than cooler master's.

Example: The worst part of the software is once you have programmed in and edited your macro, you cannot save it. It is forever bound to the key you selected. If you decide you want it on a different key, you have to program it into that key. With the logitech software, once you have created a macro you can drag and drop it whereever you want.

So as not to be all about talking up logitech I will say physically I like this keyboard better than any logitech I've used. And I've used quite a few.

reviews.title: Simplistic and monotonous
reviews.text:
The graphics look great and on my upper mid-range system it runs fine. Well, except for frequently crashing or just ceasing to respond. Everything else about this game is simplistic as if made for a 5 year old who needs to be led around and told what to do. Also, the endless droning voiceovers will make you want to defect and join the other side just so you don't have to hear the dull, monotonous voices over and over and over and over.

And then there is steam which can and does ruin every game it touches. The CODEX version actually runs better for me.

Wait until you can buy this on sale for 10 bucks before wasting money on it.

reviews.title: Moves nice and slick and has lots of buttons
reviews.text: Moves nice and slick and has lots of buttons.  It's the mouse I use now and I hope i don't have to change anytime soon.  I've gone through several of them.  They last a year to 18 months or so then usually the left click button gets funky.  Usually that is within the warranty and logitech has honored all the returns.  I will note the older ones were of higher quality, different switches and overall feel.

If you want a quality RPG with thousands of hours of gameplay then this is the game for you. It is to this day still the best Elder Scrolls ever made.

There's just nothing wrong with this game it's perfection after that squaresoft went on a steady slope. I own each and every release of this game, ps2, ps3, vita and i just had to add the ps4 version to my collection and i am going to be playing more and more because i can never have enough of this beautiful spectacular game.

reviews.title: Huge disappointment.
reviews.text: This is not a game for first timers, if i was a first timer who never played a final fantasy game before and this was my first it would destroy my whole image of the series. Incredibly stupid battle system, the story was wrapped up quick like someone made it up in the 10 minutes before their lunch break, vague characters which the story never mentions their past or why did they come to be with you, boring repetitive fetch or kill side quests and not even 5 minutes into the game and they throw the sex appeal at you with "Cindy" which i think her entire existence in the game is nothing but a forced sexual theme in a poor attempt to balance the all male cast. Not even the music was up to par. The story was 90% ffx with the whole idea of the main character dying after the final summon with a forced in death or two to make it emotional. Sorry, just didn't do it for me, by far the worst final fantasy game in the series. The kingsglaive movie was okay, basically the only good thing about this whole ff15 thing although I caught a hint of witcher from it... slowly losing your creativity squeenix.

reviews.title: takes pressure off cheeks, easily adjusts in size, nose area reduces light gap, really good so far!
reviews.text:
EDIT/UPDATE: This strap is still doing really well. Shortly after this review (Sep 2021), once I discovered Supernatural-Workout near, go far fitness app, I have been using it every single day for 60+ minutes at a time. I basically commandeered my husbands Oculus, and have been the only one using it. ZERO ISSUES. Now it is the end of December and I figured I would mention how well it has been holding up.

This strap takes some pressure off my cheekbones. I could feel the difference right away. The head strap is a significant upgrade over the default strap. My husband and I are currently sharing the Oculus, and we're always having to adjust the strap. I think my head it bigger. Adjusting this strap is as easy as a turn of a dial. SO MUCH BETTER, easier, more comfortable. We both are really liking this so far.

The silicon face cover is much better than the one that ships with the Oculus Quest 2. It is more robust, and I can feel the difference both when holding one in each hand, and once on the VR-- it is just more comfortable. ALSO, it has more material in the nose bridge area, which helps to fill up any gaps. There is a slit in the longer material which allows it to comfortably fit around various noses. Before I could see the floor and outside light, now it is pretty much all gone.

This strap simply feels more secure over the default. Everything about it more comfortable and natural feeling.

As for the battery pack holder, we currently do not have a battery pack to use so I cant comment on how well it holds one. But I can say that it is similar to a phone holder-- uses tension to hold it in place. I dont notice any added weight, or at least nothing that makes it uncomfortable by the addition of a more robust head strap and battery pack holder.

The cut out of material that leads toward rear of the strap is not perfect. I dont see it impacting anything unless it peels off. Hopefully all remains good there.

I am really quite pleased SO FAR. You better believe I will be back to update immediately if I experience anything bad, but I will also update if I experience/notice anything else worth sharing.

I hemmed and hawed between a 4 and 5. 4 only because I havent had this long, but 5 because if it continues to be a good working item then it is something I would easily recommend for someone to try. The current price of <$40 (and now there is a coupon for a few bucks off), makes it competitively priced, and worth trying. Anyway, 5 it is!

reviews.title: Secure, durable. Totally plain looking but I think that's a good thing.
reviews.text:
Plain, unassuming case. I LIKE that. It isn't fancy, it doesn't stand out. Anything could be inside.

It fits my (well, my husbands Oculus Quest 2-- but I commandeered it for Supernatural) perfectly. Has plenty of room to store cord, extra face frames, the controllers, and my grips. The VR just nestles inside snug. Has added internal strap to secure the headset. And a mesh pocket for smaller accessories. Outer case is durable feeling, has a strap for use on luggage, a hand strap, and an optional long shoulder strap.

Currently priced at $24.99. If they keep it at that price point, I would think this will garner more purchases over others I see. This is a perfectly good case, and if you like the clean, plain visual aspect of it, it is perfect (though I imagine the smooth surface could be dolled up with some stickers).

The product description did an excellent job on describing this product and showing off what it looks like inside and out. The product is as expected. I dont need to stuff my Oculus in it as I pretty much use it at home every day a few times a day, but it is nice to have a secure spot for times when not in use, and of course for when I take it on the go.

reviews.title: doubles Oculus play time, comfortable fit, hugs back of head for relaxing app experience
reviews.text:
It doubles play time without need for a physical battery pack. Nice option for those that use some apps laying down- there is no battery bracket to get in the way.

The Oculus has about 2 hours of run time, or less. I use mine primarily for the workout/fitness app, "Supernatural-workout near, go far". At full charge, I will go 1.5 hours, with maybe 20 minutes left. Totally fine, so long as my Oculus is fully charged. If I want to do anything else, then I need to charge it. Or if anyone else wants to play. I have been meaning to buy a battery pack for my [[ASIN:B094Z85PXS X-super Home Adjustable Elite Strap with Battery Bracket]] but haven't done so yet, I have been just using it every single day as a regular strap. My husband bought me a battery pack but it is way too huge. So when this rechargeable strap came up as an option to try, I figured it was something worth checking out.

The head strap is light and comfortable. The rear hugs the head, SO this is an excellent contender for those that play games, use apps that are conducive to relaxing, laying down. The fit relies entirely on the velcro straps (top & sides). I prefer the additional crank turn knob of my other strap, but this style is pretty popular and must have merit. The battery charges pretty quick. It holds about 2 hours of charge. I dont plan to have it as my daily strap, at least right now. I think I will keep it charged up, and have it on stand by for times I either failed to fully charge my Oculus, or when someone wants to use it after me and needs the extra juice. Or for after my evening workout session, and I want to go lay on the couch comfortably.

Anyway, so far so good. If I experience anything else worth sharing, I will be back to do so.

reviews.title: Lack of info for PS3 controllers, and terrible design.
reviews.text:
I have two complaints.

Complaint #1
-----------------
They really leave you in the wind with this product. I figured it out, but I'm wondering about people who are not as resourceful. The description implies you just plug it into the Switch, and you start pairing. That is not the case, at least it's not the case for PS3 controllers. There are no instructions, so naturally, I went to 8bitdo's website. On their site, there is something called the PS3 PAIRING TOOL. Sounds like what I need, so I downloaded it. In the downloaded folder is a README file. How often do people read the README files? Luckily I did! It says that before I can launch the software, I need to install a program called the SixaxisPairToolSetup-0.3.0.exe, or I can "Temporarily disable driver signature enforcement." For this 2nd option, there is a bunch of screenshots showing you how to do it in windows. I tried the 1st option first, and after installing the sixaxispairtool, it told me to restart. After restarting, normally a software will launch itself to help you along where you left off, but not this one. Once you restart, it was gone. LOL! So I thought maybe the magic has been done, so I proceeded to launch the PS3 pairing tool, but it didn't work. It would not recognize my ps3 controller. So I decided to try the second option, temporarily disable driver signature enforcement. For this option, I recommend you guys put all the instructional screenshots in your dropbox, then you can follow along reading the instructions from your phone. Because doing these steps will put you in a RECOVERY mode, so you can't view those screenshots anymore. They didn't make this accessory for everybody. They made it for techies and tinkerers who will go out of their way to make it work.

Complaint #2
----------------
8bitdo isn't too good at adapter designs. Take their Gbros adapter for example. It doesn't fit wavebird receivers, not because it isn't compatible, but because of the design. So Retro Fighters basically just built a new shell for that receiver and fixed the issue. So it isn't too surprising to me that this wireless receiver is a bad design too. Why did they make the usb brick casing so fat? You have to imagine that many people have two ps3 or ps4 controllers, that they may want to buy 2 receivers like I did. Well, two receivers will not fit at the same time on the Dock side ports. If you want to use two, you'll have to use a USB A to A extender, or a hub. There is one more usb port in the back of the Dock between the HDMI and Power ports. Guess what, it won't fit there either. If I try to squeeze the brick in, it will lift the power and hdmi cables from their ports at an angle, and this can especially damage the power cable.

I like to imagine this is what happened during product development...

8bitdo: "This is a beautiful design, and when our fans buy ONE receiver to add ONE PlayStation controller, they will be very happy."
Employee: "Should we design it so TWO receivers will fit on the side ports? Maybe also make it fit on the 3rd port in the back? Also, we might want to add a step by step manual for ps3 controllers"
8bitdo: "What's your name? You are fired!"

reviews.title: Nintendo Switch brought me here....
reviews.text: My PS3 controllers are now getting a second life due to the Nintendo Switch. But I never knew it was such a hassle to get the PS3 controllers to charge without the actual PS3 system. Smartphone wall adapters DO NOT work. Third party docking products on Amazon do not come with a power adapter, only USB cables. Which means they probably require you to have your PS3 on.  I've asked if Smartphone wall adapters will work with those third party docks, they say yes, but I don't trust the answer.  I kept searching and ran onto this official Playstation product. This is just what the doctor ordered! Actually, a computer will charge your ps3 controllers too, but I'd like all my game accessories in my media cabinet. This adapter tucks in the back of my cabinet and the ps3 controllers are now charging inside my cabinet out of sight, out of mind. $10 and it's an official item. Doesn't get any better!

reviews.title: This is the one to get!
reviews.text:
I got both this version as well as the generic wii2hdmi that most are selling, and I've found out that not all wii to hdmi adapters are created equally. With the generic one, I see more wavy diagonal lines. With the MayFlash, the picture is smoother, the diagonal lines are gone. You need to go to your wii setting and set it to wide screen and 480p. You also need to go to your display source and set it to widescreen as well. Everything looks proportional, the image is not stretched. This is a keeper, the other one is being returned.

BTW, I should mention that I'm using an ultra short throw projector with a 120" screen. With such a big image, maybe it is easier for me to see imperfections. So that should tell you how good this adapter is. It got rid of the lines I was seeing with the generic version. So on smaller screens, surely this adapter will do a great job for you.

reviews.title: You become a worse player!
reviews.text:
So we gave our Wii new life in this "Stay at Home" world. I bought the Wii when it first came out, back when I had no children. LOL! I have two kids now and the Wii is getting a new life. But I digress... about these guns. Three things I don't like....

1. You're kinda inserting your wiimote in at an angle. You basically place your wiimote on top of the gun mold "bed," but it cannot clear yet until you angle it and start to insert it into the connector. Then you can push it down flat. Connecting plugs and ports at an angle is uncomfortable to me. I feel eventually you will ruin the connector or port.

2. So in most Wii shooting games, the B button is your trigger, it is the button on the back of the Wiimote. So all these gun accessories are built so that when you pull the trigger, the mechanism inside then clicks the B button. So for a good gun accessory, the trigger on the gun mold should be as easy and as quick as clicking the B button on the Wiimote. Well, that's not the case with this gun, so you become a worse player. There is more resistance with the trigger, as well as more travel time. Travel time is how long it takes for you to completely pull the trigger. When you're just playing around with it and pulling the trigger. It's just like any other toy gun, you don't think anything about it. But when you start to play wii games, you will see that you got wore. Because all that extra time adds up.

3. I wanted my kids to be able to use it, but the handle plus trigger width was just too wide for a 5 yr old's hands. She ended up using two hands and spent more time focusing on pressing the trigger than aiming. So this is not good for little kids with small hands.

For little kids with small hands, I recommend something called the "Wii blasters." This was a set that came out around 2011. It comes with 2 guns and a game code for BIG TOWN SHOOT OUT. The game codes have since expired, but people are still selling these guns.

reviews.title: Half vs Full Body cover... this is full body.
reviews.text: This is probably something you don't think about, we certainly didn't... We just searched for Nintendo Switch Lite cases and picked one out. Initially, we got one of those soft TPU ones, but then we realized the top is exposed. So we continued searching and we found this listing. If you want FULL body protection, these 2 piece hard shell cases are what you want. However, you should consider this "con" before making your decision... You see the Switch buttons and directional pad protrude above the surface only by a little, so by placing a case layer on top, it makes the buttons almost feel flush to the surface. It's not completely flush, they are still raised above the case, but barely. You will need to feel for yourself and decide if this is right for you. I still give the case 5 stars because it does the job, and includes 2 glass screen protectors and cute thumb grips. A lot of bang for your buck!

reviews.title: This set will take up 2 usb ports...
reviews.text: I've been using wireless keyboards and mouses for a decade, so my mind had certain expectations. I once read about a wired set where the mouse is connected to the keyboard, and then 1 wire connects to the computer. This was like 5 yrs ago. It's now 2020, and based on something I read 5 yrs ago, I assumed it is industry standard now. LOL!  But I was wrong, this takes up 2 ports just like the 1980's, just like the 1990's, just like the 2000's. The keyboard itself is fine. Feels a little on the cheap side due to how light it is. I'm not sure I'm willing to put up with all these wires. But this was not the products fault, it was the user's fault for making assumptions. As a matter fact, I can't find any gaming sets on Amazon that uses 1 wire described in the article I read years ago. SMH.

reviews.title: 100% compatible with our original switch...
reviews.text: Slides onto our original switch and paired with no issues. I'm not having the charging issues that others are reporting, but I'll update review if I do down the road.  Battery life is adequate. No complaints so far.

reviews.title: Upper and lower coverage, Joy-cons detachable, & unit can be docked!
reviews.text: This is a hard plastic case that comes with upper and lower molds to protect your entire switch. The joy cons have their own upper and lower molds too, so they are still detachable with the case on. Lastly, it is dockable! I like these types of cases better than the soft TPU types because usually those are just 1 rubber mold that keeps the top exposed and your joy cons are not detachable unless you remove the system from the case. You have no such concerns with this case. We love it! Look at the pictures and look at the fine scratches on the case. Those scratches would be on the Switch if not for the case. Get yourself one! 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Aesthetically, one of the nicest switch controllers out there...
reviews.text: No complaints from my son so far. He's been using this controller to play Fornite, Tetris, etc. The extra buttons on the back can be mapped to virtually anything you want. Aesthetically, this is a beauty. It has a good heft to it. It doesn't feel light and cheap. I don't know the brand Mayfan, and it doesn't seem to be an officially licensed product, but you wouldn't know it by the quality. It's right up there with official makers like PDP. Comes with a USB-C cable. This is super nice. 5-stars

reviews.title: Super cute switch remote for our 6 yr old...
reviews.text: Awesome switch controller! It's about 5x3.6x2 inches, and only 4.9 ounces, so it's perfect for my daughter. If you have small hands you'll like it too. It's a good compromise between heavier controllers and the tiny joy-cons. Operation is smooth, no lag. However, if you play long sessions, the included usb-c will come in handy. It's rated for 8 hrs, which is much shorter than original joycons, which can last anywhere from 20 to 30 hrs.  5-stars.

reviews.title: Honestly, the perfect switch lite case, please read why...
reviews.text:
You probably don't think of FULL vs HALF BODY when searching for cases, do you? Initially, we got one of those soft TPU ones, but then we realized the top is exposed. If you want FULL body protection, these 2 piece hard shell cases are what you want. However, the issue with these full body cases is that most of them create the mold around the X,Y,A,B buttons. This makes the buttons feel almost flush to the surface, so you don't have a good tactile feel for the buttons. The good news about this full body case is that it DOES NOT mold around the buttons. It is completely cut-out, so you get 100% feel for the buttons. This is an awesome case that checks all the boxes for us:

1. Is it full body? Check!
2. Do you have a good feel for the X,Y,A,B buttons? Check!
3. Is it cute and daughter approved? Check!

The cute matching joystick caps are just icing on the cake. This is 5-Stars all the way!

reviews.title: Officially licensed Nintendo Switch retro controller with insane battery life...
reviews.text:
The design of this controller is classic/retro. It reminds you of the Super NES days. Here are some things to note:

-Weighs 4.3 ounces
-40 hrs battery life
-Motion Control supported
-PDP is officially licensed to make Nintendo products
-USB-C is included, but it is short. So you probably won't be using it when charging.
-NO NFC
-ZL and ZR buttons are curved in a way that will allow your index fingers to rest on.

Depending on how you feel about the placement of the d-pads and buttons, this controller may or may not be worth the money to you. If you're not completely happy about the layout, then check out the 8bitdo SN30 controller. Overall, that seems to be a better controller, but it all depends on what you value more. If 40 hrs of battery life is more important to you, then get the PDP. In any case, the 8bitdo is a good alternative if you're not sold on this PDP. https://www.amazon.com/8Bitdo-SN30-Controller-Windows-macOS-Android/dp/B0748S1VDC/ref=sr_1_4?dchild=1&keywords=8bitdo+sn30+pro&qid=1604087284&sr=8-4

This would be a 4 star controller, if not for the battery life, since it's price in the same ballpark as the 8bitdo SN30. But the fact that PDF is officially licensed and it has the battery advantage, then it brings it back to 5-Stars! You need to decide what's more important to you when deciding between these two controllers.

reviews.title: Nice controller, but it is micro-usb...
reviews.text:
40 hrs capacity on a single charge! Perfect for travel!

- Wireless range of 30 feet.
- Motion control feature.
- Two programmable back buttons.
- Additional precision analog stick.
- Interchangeable faceplate design.
- It weighs 8.8 ounces.

This controller feels very premium, but I must ask... Why micro usb? All Nintendo switch accessories are mainly usb-c. Why make us manage different cables? I love how all my accessories can be charged by just 1 usb-c cable. Now we gotta keep a micro-usb cable around too. Not a big deal, but why? LOL!

reviews.title: Too light, no SL/SR top cover...
reviews.text:
Of all the 3rd party joycons I've tried, this is probably my least favorite. What caught my eye was the charging cable. I thought it was pretty unique and unlike others. However, I don't think you can use it to charge other joycons. It was made specifically for theirs. I connected to another brand of joycons and there doesn't seem to be any reaction. I will update this review if I discover anything new on this front.

So there are two main things why this has been my least favorite:

1. Weight... At 1.7 oz. each, this is the lightest third party joycon I have. It is cheap! The original is 2.5 oz. each.
2. No SL/SR top covers. So if you split these up to play multiplayer games, your SL/SR buttons will be hard to press.

I'll rate this 3 stars. For 3rd party, I prefer this set a review a while ago. It is 2 oz. each and they include the SL/SR top covers.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-reviews/R3UHC1PVPNANJ3/ref=cm_cr_othr_d_rvw_ttl?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B08HQX1HKM

reviews.title: Nice looking fighting stick with Sanwa compatible internals...
reviews.text: Nice fighting stick for Super Smash Bros! I know the hardcore gamers can pick apart this stick, but my kid is 8 yrs old and is blown away by this, and that's all that matters. He gets dibs on this stick whenever we play Super Smash. For the serious gamers out there. The good news is that all the parts seem to be Sanwa compatible from the joystick to the buttons. So if you want to, you can replace the components. An 8 yr old doesn't know how to complain about a missed combo. LOL! So, I won't be doing any modification. This stick is fine as is. The red top of this stick is not permanent, it is a decorative plate, and can be replaced with other plates. They do include an extra design for you, but we happen to love red, so we won't be changing anything. Another thing to note is that when you plug in the USB-C cable, it is simply for power for wired play. It doesn't do any charging because there is no internal rechargeable battery. If you want to play wireless, you need to use two AA batteries, which they claim can give you 30 hrs of gameplay. We'll see about that. This is a 5-Star product!

reviews.title: Cannot dock with a case, not even a thin one...
reviews.text: I'm still in search of a dock that can accommodate a switch with a case. A previous one I had was too narrow width-wise, so it couldn't seat. The design on this one seems pretty open, look at the pictures, you'll see the width is wide. So I had hopes this could be the one! My switch with the thin case sat on the dock with no issues at all. That's what I was hoping for based on the design. But I realized of a new issue. Even if you can seat your Switch with a case, it might not charge. The reason is because your case creates a rise that prevents the usb-c port and plug to fully connect. Logically, I knew about this already. But I anticipated that the contact would be enough for it to charge. Sadly, the answer is no. It needs to be 100% docked. The only solution is to modify the case, like cutting out a slot to allow it to fully seat with no rise. This isn't something I'm going to subtract a star for. The dock does it's job perfectly fine when I take my switch out of the case. But just a FYI to those who are trying to do what I'm doing. This is still a 5-Stars product!

reviews.title: Super fun open world adventure MMO game...
reviews.text: This is a pretty nice MMO (massive multiplayer online) game. In this game, you will play, Fenyx, a demi-god. If you enjoy Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, you will like this game, but it has enough originality of its own. Soundtrack during the game is great, and the story line is open-ended, so there is potential for sequels. The best part of this game is the open world adventures. The entire map is open from the outset, unlike other games where you made need to unlock section by section. If you enjoy flying in games, you can do that once you get wings! The game is very fun, colorful and vibrant. Ultimately, you want to defeat Typhon. We like this game so much, we started wondering what it would look like on the more powerful consoles, and boy, it does look so much better on the ps5. But, this game is for the Switch, and we know, graphically, it's unfair to compare to the ps5. This game is 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Perfect for PlayStation collectors...
reviews.text:
I got no PS5, but this is a nice consolation prize until we can buy a ps5 one day. LOL!

-Wool cap
-Insulated bottle
-Crew socks
-Tech decals

All with ps5 logo and branding! 5-Stars!

reviews.title: High quality switch controller at 7.5 ounces...
reviews.text: Not really hardcore gamers in my home, so we can't give you the finer details or nuances of how it feels. If you're just somebody who occasionally plays the switch, you'll like this. We've used to for Mario Brawl, Fortnite, and Splatoon 2. It is USB-C and has a nice heft to it at 7.5 ounces. This is very nice. 5-stars

reviews.title: Pretty good 3rd party Nintendo Switch controller...
reviews.text: This controller comes in a no frills plain white box. It's not has hefty as other 3rd party switch controllers I've tried at 6.9 ounces. I use Splatoon 2 as the "go-to" game to test controllers, and this one works just fine. Motion control works fine, the vibrations are nice and strong. The 1200mah battery life is a plus. The stock photos make it seem like it's matte finish, but you can see in my pictures parts of it are actually glossy, so you can see the fine scratches. Overall, I give this a 4-Stars.

reviews.title: Nice Nintendo Switch controller perfectly priced...
reviews.text: Any Switch controller I try, I would like for it to at least be heavier than 7 ounces, and this one comes in at 7.2 ounces, so it feels adequate. It has NFC, motion control, dual shock, turbo mode, etc. Basically all the usual suspects in terms of features. It does skimp you on the battery. It's rated for 8 hrs of continuous play, which is low compared to others on the market. That's because the battery is only 500mah. But it priced itself accordingly. So for that, this is 5-stars in terms of value proposition.

reviews.title: Nice controller skins that will be compatible with the ps5 charging dock...
reviews.text: Nice grips! Some might want it thinner, but I like the extra thickness, and it fits with the official PS5 charging dock. You get a white one, and a black one, but all the thumb grips are black. We like it. 5-Stars.

reviews.title: Great looking, solid accessory for the Nintendo Switch...
reviews.text: Beautiful Nintendo Switch accessory. I'm just a daddy who plays occasionally, and get most of these accessories for my kids who are not yet 10 yrs old. What I'm saying is that we are not hardcore gamers, and don't get into the technical aspects of these controllers. Some gamers can tell the difference when something is a split second off. LOL! If you're a casual gamer, believe me you'll love these. The work and feel just as good as the original joycons, but you get better grip for your Splatoon 2 battles. LOL! That's what I use it for most. 5-Stars!

reviews.title: The best part of this case is the one piece design of the joycon covers...
reviews.text: This is kind of a unique case. I wanted something dockable to avoid taking the case on and off. However, keep this in mind, "dockable" only applies to the original Switch dock. It will not dock on third party docks that are designed differently, I've tried since I have several in my collection. But the most unique thing about this case is the covers for the joycons. The shell that covers the back of the main body is made of the usual hard plastic, however, the cases for the joycon are a one piece flexible rubber, which is a pleasant surprise. Normally, the cases for the joycon would also be hard plastic and would come in two pieces that would sandwich the joycon. This one piece design is so much more convenient! 5-Stars all the way!

reviews.title: Best keyboard I have ever owned, never going back to normal keyboards...
reviews.text: I tried gaming keyboards before, and was never impressed. But I believe my mistake was that the keyboards were not mechanical. I believe they can be gaming, but not mechanical. You need the ones that are mechanical! I don't think I'll ever go back to ordinary or membrane keyboards. The spring and tactile feel of this keyboard is awesome! I tend to be a nostalgic person anyway, so I love the retro feel of these keyboards. You also no longer need to worry about batteries since it's required to be plugged in via USB. The lights are cool, and the build quality is excellent. It is not light and cheap, this little guy weighs in at 34.4 ounces. No weak buttons, or touch buttons. The volume scroller is amazing!!! It is cold to the touch because it is made of metal, and feels oddly satisfying when scrolling. Everything is tactile, every key is springy. This was how things were made in the past. 5-Stars all the way!

reviews.title: Super cute Panda design, but more importantly it functions very well...
reviews.text: Because I love their keyboard products, I decided to try their controller too. This controller is high quality weighing in at 6.5 ounces. The panda design is a no brainer, had to grab it immediately for my daughter. She loves unicorns and pandas. LOL! I test it on Splatoon 2, my go to game for controller testing. Everything works as it should, and I even think I play better with it. My daughter might have to pry this away from me. Motion function, vibration, Amiibo NFC, etc., this controller has it all. 5-Stars!

reviews.title: You no longer have to remove your Switch case to dock...
reviews.text: If you have a case on your Nintendo switch, docking can be a hassle, especially with 3rd party docks, you will need to remove your case every time. I decided having the switch docked upright neatly is no longer a priority. Now, I just plug in the usb-c and let the switch lay on the table. Much quicker than having to remove the case, and you're not missing out on anything other than your Switch not sitting upright. A minor issue is that this dock needs to be plugged directly into a wall. There is only three ports: 1 for the HDMI, 1 for USB-C to your Switch, 1 spare USB port to charge an accessory. So technically, you never have to see the dock, as long as you plan ahead and have long enough cables. But I would like to switch cables easily, so I'm using an extension cord to bring the dock to the table. 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Awesome dock that color coordinates with the Nintendo theme...
reviews.text:
Gets the job done! No more having to remove my protective case! However, understand that the power adapter is not included. I happen to have gotten another accessory set that includes everything, but the dock wouldn't seat my switch with a case on. I needed to remove my case every time. That is the reason I got this dock. Your Switch won't be sitting up neatly, but it is much more convenient to just plug and play, instead of having to remove the case. What's also great is that it color coordinates with everything in the other set. This is the other set I'm talking about: https://www.amazon.com/review/R2SU9HR7308F1Y/ref=cm_cr_srp_d_rdp_perm? ie=UTF8&ASIN=B08KVPT7DN

With the kit in the above link, you'll get a case, HDMI cable, power adapter for your Switch, and a dock. If your Switch doesn't have a protective case, then you might want to consider that link. But I got this dock as well because I do use a case, and it was a hassle to remove it every time. This dock is 5-Stars all the way!

reviews.title: Too complicated for the layman...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
-------------
* Terrific build quality. Good heft
* USB-C

THE BAD:
-----------
* Not for layman. Manual is useless. You are basically on your own from the get go, and you just figure out things blindly. I figured the FLYDIGI app is what I needed, and sure enough I found it on the Playstore. The app uses lingo and terms only gamers probably understand. Classic mode, native mode, mapping mode, Flashplay mode, etc. There is a big learning curve to understand what all these modes mean and does. Next to word CONNECTED, is the word UNACTIVATED. Apparently you need to activate something, and it gives you a choice of using U-Tool or the PC. What is U-Tool? I don't know, but the app assumes you do know. So I googled "U-TOOL flydigi" and I discover it's some sort of rooting dongle. So then I figure, I'll check out the PC method. For this option, they tell you to go to their website and download the PC tool. Except, the only option is an Android APK. SMH.

They have an email, and they seem to have a community, but I'm not that much into gaming to put in this type of effort. I wanted a controller that would hold my phone, so I can play roblox with my kids, that's it. LOL! Because I hate the touch controls in Roblox. This is too complicated. I'll go 3-Stars! I'm sure this is 5-Stars to people into gaming. Knocking 2 stars for the lack of directions.

reviews.title: Good organizer, price seems on par with competitors...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Can hold 10 cases
* Can hold 4 controllers
* Can hold 2 headphones
* Nice drawer for more games without cases, or joycons.

THE BAD:
-----------
* Looks kinda empty if you don't have headphones yet. LOL!
* It's all plastic, and not thick high quality either. The main frame that holds the cases is hollow. So you can see the back of the cases on the other side.

I won't be too harsh. This seems to be on par with what others are charging around the internet. I'll go 4-Stars.

reviews.title: Very nice steering wheel if you're not a hardcore nitpicky gamer...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Wheel has good heft. The unit is a little over 7 lbs.
* Wheel cover is made of genuine leather.
* Buttons are nice placed and in close reach.
* Wheel has a table clamp.
* Pedal unit is also high quality at over 7 lbs as well, no flex.
* Trueforce feature with strong feedback. This feature helps with increasing immersion.
* Compatible with PC as well as Xbox

THE BAD:
-----------
* Braking can be difficult, seems like there is more resistance the more you brake.
* Price point is not competitive with previous models. The improvements are slight, so unless you can get this on sale, I would look at their older models and pay below $300.
* Although Trueforce feature is a positive above, in reality, there are not many games currently that are compatible with the Trueforce feature.
* The pedal unit made me bleed. LOL! When you pull the pedal unit out of the box, naturally your hand will want to support it by holding it from the bottom of the base. Something pricked me, and my finger started to bleed. I flipped it over to see what could cut me, and I realize their is a rectangular mold with really sharp corners. Look at my pictures to what I'm talking about, so you can avoid getting hurt yourself.

Honestly, I'm quite annoyed that I bled while reviewing this thing. You don't expect to get hurt by game accessories. Because it's such a naturally tendency for your hands to support things at the bottom, I'm 100% sure others will get pricked by those corners as well. If Logitech is reading this, please provide a warning to your consumers. As for me, I will just round out the corners of that rectangle mold with a Dremel. Subtracting 1 star for the price point and value proposition compared to pervious models, and I'm subtracting another star for being the first game accessory ever to make me bleed. LOL! 3-Stars.

reviews.title: Awesome Nintendo/Mario color scheme without the Nintendo price tag...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Nintendo/Mario color scheme without the Nintendo price tag. LOL!
* 4 stage vibration
* Gyro sensor
* Turbo function
* USB-C

THE BAD:
-----------
* 550mah battery is slightly lower capacity than most controllers I've reviewed. But it does claim 8 hrs battery capacity. Despite this, we love the look so much, it's 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Awesome bumblebee looking mechanical keyboard with great heft at 2.8 lbs...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
-------------
* Solid build. This keyboard weighs 2.8 lbs.
* RGB backlight.
* Nice media control knobs.
* Detachable wrist pad that sticks to the keyboard via magnets.
* Aesthetically, if you have a Bumblebee transformer displayed on your desk. How cool would this keyboard look next to it?

THE BAD:
-----------
* Mechanical keyboards are loud. So if you're a night owl, and you have a significant other in your room. They will not be happy. LOL! Too bad, I'm suing it. 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Great features, perfect for N64, a little on the light side...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Specially marketed for N64, but works with Nintendo Switch, PC, Retropie, etc.
* USB receiver for the N64 port is included to make this wireless with the N64. Sweet!
* Built in rumble pak and memory card port.

THE BAD:
-----------
* Doesn't feel substantial at only 5.5 ounces. It works very well, but it just feels a little cheap. I'll go 4-Stars!

reviews.title: This Cyborg, Mr. T looking figure is now my son's favorite...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Bundle pack of 3 figures.
* 1 Training dummy.
* 1 Joystick controller.

THE BAD:
-----------
* You cannot start off with this kit. There is only 1 controller. You need to purchase an extra controller, or start with the Battle Arena kit, then build your collection from there. Or, purchase any kit that includes a joystick controller, so that two can go to battle. My kids are having a blast with these. 5-Stars!

reviews.title: A very nice mouse with many bells and whistles, but build quality is questionable...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Very smooth working mouse.
* 7 programmable buttons.
* Bluetooth or usb dongle connection.
* Two battery slots. You don't have to fill both slots, you can use either one AA, or one AAA battery. I've never seen this before.
* The best mouse I've ever used in terms of adapting to different surfaces. You really don't need a mouse pad.
* Mechanical switches.
* Razer brand-name and dependability.

THE BAD:
------------
* This is a high end mouse that feels like a cheap $10 mouse. It weighs virtually nothing. With a AA battery installed, it's 3.5 ounces. Keep in mind, I'm not a gamer. Is this what all gamer mouses feel like? They need it lightweight for some sort of advantage? I don't know. My cheaper $30 Logitech mouse has more heft than this mouse. So if you don't like lightweight plastic stuff, then don't get this.

I'll go 4-Stars.

reviews.title: High quality, beautiful ps5 controller charging dock...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Razer brand... they make good stuff.
* Aesthetically very nice. Looks great next to the PS5.
* Build quality is rock solid.
* Easy dock charging. The usb-c charging cables are ugly. You can hide this dock's cable by letting it hang off the back of your cabinet.
* Quick charging in less than 3 hrs.

THE BAD:
------------
* Nothing at all. 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Awesome headset with a brilliantly designed wireless usb-c dongle...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Razer brand... they make good stuff.
* Aesthetically very nice. Color coordinates with the PS5 perfectly!
* Build quality is terrific, and the sound it delivers is awesome. I'm not an audiophile, so if you're not either, you'll be more than impressed.
* Mic is bendable allowing for great voice capture.
* The foam cushions for your ears are very comfortable and snug.
* For wireless connection, the usb-c dongle takes into account that the PS5 has USB-A ports to the right of the USB-C port, so they efficiently designed it so that it doesn't cover the USB-A ports. Brilliant!
* The dongle connects to our phones and Nintendo switch with no issues either.
* Packaging is very premium. The foam cut-outs that the headset sits in are high quality. You're not going to want to throw away the box.

THE BAD:
------------
* Nothing at all. We love this headset! 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Nice convenient dual docking station for your PS5 controllers...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Aesthetically matches the PS5 nicely.
* Easy docking as advertised.
* Fast charging as advertised as well.
* Price.

THE BAD:
------------
* Lightweight, cheap build.
* The charging port is on the side. Which prevents you from hiding the entire cable. If it's in the back, you can just drop the cable behind the cabinet. So to hide the cable, I have the dock in a, I guess you would call it, lengthwise position instead of width. This way, the cable port is now in the back, but your controllers are no longer displaying horizontally. Look at my pictures, you'll see what I mean.

I'll go 4-Stars.

reviews.title: Works with my X-Arcade stick out the box...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* 10k games!!!
* It recognized my X-Arcade stick, so I was then able to configure other usb controllers.
* Works for Pi3, and 3B+
* Basic, non-confusing skin.

THE BAD:
------------
* As mentioned above, the skin is basic, which is good if you're a beginner, but might be bland if you're used to all sorts of arcade skins.
* Learning curve is very small. You need for it to recognize at least one controller so you can start moving around and learn the settings.

You know what? For $20, this is 5-Stars! Here's a tip, If the system doesn't recognize any of your controllers, plug in a keyboard and navigate by the arrows to get your game controllers configured.

reviews.title: A superior horizontal stand to the PS5's version, but you should put the case holder on the left...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Love how this idea creates a nice gap at the bottom to truly create venting.
* The brackets can be fitted on either side. Which is a good thing because if you follow the stock photos, they put it on the right which blocks existing vents. So I put my case holder on the left.
* This method also makes moving and budging the PS5 easier, so long as your hands are supporting both brackets while you're moving it. The PS5's round stand always comes off when I budge the system.

THE BAD:
------------
* Something I missed when I was looking at the product photos. You actually have to flip the console upside down. So the PS5 logo is facing the ground. This is a little concerning to me. This means you'll be inserting your discs upside down, meaning silver shiny side facing the ceiling when you insert a disc. Does this have any long-term effects on the hardware? I've done some research, and it seems there won't be any harm done to it. You should read for yourself. Just search google for "THE TRUTH ABOUT LAYING YOUR PS5 DOWN 'INCORRECTLY." It's an article by SVG.

I give this idea and product 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Awesome cable! Got the job done for me...
reviews.text: I use a HDMI hub, which is also a universal remote. The cable that came with my PS5 has to go out from the PS5 and into this hub. This hub then goes out into my projector. I could never get 4k. However, if I connect the PS5 with it's original cable directly to the projector, then I could get 4k. So basically the cable I have connecting my hub to my projector is not getting the job done. I replaced it with this PowerA cable and voila! The PS5 is now delivering 4k even with the hub as the middle man. 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Perfect bundle for the new Nintendo Switch Sports game...
reviews.text: Got this set in anticipation of buying the new Switch Sports game in the near future. Everything in this bundle is plastic, but they're sturdy, high quality stuff, not dollar star quality. I especially like the feel of the Zelda sword, really high quality plastic. 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Gets the job done, a must have accessory for retro gamers...
reviews.text: Worked like a charm for my N64. The greatest game ever is possibly 007, and the best Mario Kart version ever is from the N64 system. We can now play both games in 2022 on our big 120" projector screen. Gets the job done, 5-Stars!

reviews.title: Works out the box for Minecraft and Roblox, that's all I needed...
reviews.text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Very nifty controller pad accessory for your smartphone.
* Built in thermoelectric/Peltier cooler.
* Telescopic and will adjust to your smartphone length.
* The cooler on the back is not fixed in the center, it is adjustable. This allows you to clear any camera humps your phone may have.
* Buttons are mappable using the GameSir app, so you can play virtually any game.

THE BAD:
------------
* Honestly, I don't know what's bad. I'm not a hardcore gamer. I just wanted something that will allow me to play roblox and minecraft out the box with my kids. I can never keep up with my kids on my smartphone because I hate playing games with touch controls. LOL! I've tried other brands like Flydigi, and I was completely lost in their mapping directions. This GameSir simply works out the box for Minecraft and Roblox. I didn't need to do any mapping. So that's 5-Stars from me!
