reviews.title: Nice storage bag for stock Occulus
reviews.text:
After I got the Occulus, I quickly realized that there was no good place to store it when not in use. I thought a storage backpack would be a good idea, in case I took it somewhere.
Its a decent quality fake leather, looks well constructed. All of the pieces fit nicely for a stock unit.
I didn't end up using it for long, as the Occulus will not fit in this bag with any aftermarket head straps.
I got several head pieces with batteries, and some without for a better fit. However, there is not room in this bag for anything other than the basic unit and the 2 controllers. If you stick with the original strap, then this bag will be just fine for you!
~~ I hope you find this REAL review helpful! ~~

reviews.title: Works great! Very long with nice adapter
reviews.text:
Nicely constructed cable, does not feel cheap at all. I expect this to last a long time.
I am using it to charge my Occulus, as well as connect it to my computer with the included adapter.
Not much to say, its a cable, but it is well made and doing its job great so far!
~~ I hope you find this REAL review helpful! ~~

reviews.title: HUGE improvement with the battery
reviews.text:
I originally got a different aftermarket head strap, which was an improvement over the original.
Then I saw this one, with an additional battery. It is comfortable and the adjustment dial on the back works well. We have not had any issues with slippage or discomfort.
The battery adds a TON of time to our VR time. Without it, I was lucky to get 2 hours without the Occulus dying. With it, we have been able to play all night with a full charge of the unit and the battery. I really like the Occulus, but I think a battery pack is a MUST have accessory, and this one is working like a charm!!
~~ I hope you find this REAL review helpful! ~~

reviews.title: Helps keep the controllers cleaner
reviews.text:
I wasn't sure if we needed something like this for our Oculus, but it can't hurt.
The cover fits very tight, and it feels its a little stretched over the top. But it keeps my children's grubby hands from actually touching the controllers, so that is nice.
Its been a few weeks and it looks like they are holding up!
~~ I hope you find this REAL review helpful! ~~

reviews.title: GREAT remake of one of my favorite controller designs
reviews.text:
I have always loved the Gamecube controller, especially for Super Smash Bros.
This is a very nice recreation for the Nintendo Switch. Obviously, its great for Smash Ultimate, but I really like using it for most games that I play in docked mode on the Switch. If you like the GC controller, you will love this one. It has all the regular buttons, as well as the + and - in the middle. In addition, this controller also has TURBO, if you like that sort of thing. I don't use it myself, but its nice to have as an option. Battery has lasted an acceptable amount of time, no issues.
~~ I hope you find this REAL review helpful! ~~

reviews.title: Uncomfortable, feels cheap
reviews.text:
I have gotten a few aftermarket straps for the Oculus. This one isn't as good as the others I have tried.
It does have a nice big battery, so it keeps us playing for longer. But the headset itself feels like it ridged and stiff. The padding at the back of your head is not very soft. Some other headsets offer braces on the side that give a little more support to your head. This one only has the strap over the top.
I would recommend trying out one of the other options
~~ I hope you find this REAL review helpful! ~~

reviews.title: Fits with an Elite battery pack headset
reviews.text:
I have tried a few different cases for the Oculus, but this is the first one that I have gotten that will fit the Oculus with an aftermarket Elite strap with battery. As I mentioned in other reviews, you almost need a strap with a backup battery to make the Oculus last long enough. The problem I have had is that almost all of the cases/storage options are made only for the stock Oculus.
This one comfortably fits the Oculus system, both controllers, and the aftermarket strap with the battery.
This is the first one I will suggest others to get. Nice case!
~~ I hope this REAL review was helpful! ~~

reviews.title: Lots of accessories in this pack
reviews.text:
I got this kit mainly for the brush to clean the lens on the headset. It is irretractable, and nice and small, so easy to find room in my storage case for it.
The kit also comes with a variety of cleaning cloths, wipes, and solutions. I am not sure if I will use most of these other parts, but they could be helpful in the future, so I am glad they were included.
May not be needed, but they could be a lifesaver!
~~ I hope this REAL review was helpful! ~~

reviews.title: Works great! Front facing is nice
reviews.text:
I liked this dock because it is a front facing dock that you can see while the device is docked, unlike the stock Switch dock. This way you can play on the TV, or just sitting in the holder while charging. All the ports are working fine for me, and as advertised, its 1 button press to switch between the Switch screen and the TV screen. Added benefit of not scratching your screen when your kids JAM it in the dock!
~~ I hope you found this REAL review helpful! ~~

reviews.title: So far so GREAT!
reviews.text:
We have had the Quest 2 for about 4 months now, and one of the biggest issues I have had was where to put it SAFELY while not in use. I got a case, but didn't want to put it away every single time.
This is not only a very nice storage space for the device and controllers, but charges everything as well!
It was very easy to assemble and setup, took only a few minutes. I have seen charging stations, but they don't normally have battery packs for the controllers. This is all nice and compact and tells you with LED lights when they are charging and when they are full. I would definitely suggest this for your storage and charging needs.
~~~ I hope you find this REAL review helpful! ~~~

reviews.title: Nice for long term gaming
reviews.text:
I got these for my son, who is spending more and more time gaming with voice chat. It seems to be a requirement for gaming these days. This headset is doing a fine job of providing clear sound and ease of use, particularly. We joined these up with the included dongle, and have had zero issues since with the headset connecting. The audio clarity is very nice, almost too loud at times I have been informed. The microphone is clear and mutes/unmutes by flipping it up, which is very convenient.
Battery lasts at least a whole "day" of gaming. He plugs it in at night and it is always powered up.
The only complaint I have is that they feel a little cheap, plastic-y. So far we haven't had any issues with durability, but I have concerns on how long they will hold up. They don't feel as well made as some other brands. I will update if it becomes a problem.
~~~ I hope you find this REAL review helpful! ~~~

reviews.title: Probably more than I needed, but high quality
reviews.text:
I am not sure that I needed a mouse of this quality, as I am not a hard core gamer. I wanted a quality device, that will last and work with NO issues. So far, that is what I have gotten.
It is very comfortable in my hand and I am able to reach each button comfortably with no awkwardness. The
buttons are responsive and feel solid. I have put quite a few 4+ hour sessions in and my hand felt fine afterwards.
I have not had any issues with latency with this mouse so far, or other "glitchy" episodes.
Battery life has been great, I go days without having to plug it in.
Also, this mouse LOOKS great, you don't see many cool looking white mice!

reviews.title: Does NOT work on all surfaces
reviews.text: I almost exclusively use my laptop (and mouse) on my couch or recliner. The infrared would never pick up any surface that was not a table/desk/mousepad for me. I changed the DPI settings, I updated drivers and looked for software solutions. Not matter what I could not get it to work on a fabric surface. I have had mice that work with no issues on these surfaces, and this is not one of them. I will try another brand.

reviews.title: Mass Effect 2
reviews.text: I don't have a whole lot to say about this game, there are others out there with better graphics and story lines, but this one was okay to pass the time.

reviews.title: Nice Games
reviews.text: This was a pretty good price for two games and both games are really fun to play. Only downside to these games is once you beat them it's not really fun to play a second time.

reviews.title: Very comfortable and adaptable
reviews.text: First off the headphones were very well packaged. The actual headphones swivel so it makes it easy to find a comfortable position even when moving your head around. There is some noise reduction properties to the headphones, which is nice, but they aren't noise cancelling. Overall the material is well made and sturdy, particularly the cables. The only downside to the headphone for me is the microphone, the bracket that holds the mic itself doesn't feel like it's made of the same sturdy material as the rest, so I am a little bit concerned with it holding up over time. I have used it with my computer, XBox, and Switch, and I have enjoyed it a lot. If you are a person with bigger ears, these headphones work great, especially without squishing your ears.

reviews.title: Fun game would have been better without the toys
reviews.text:
I thought the concept was cool, and that the actual game itself was really well made but that the toys kind of took away from the game play. When I opened the box I was actually really kind of excited about the toys aspect of it, it was definitely an interesting concept. I liked the starter ship and how you could alter it based on what you had plugged into it. The thing that bummed me out the most about the toys was that you have to pay to get new parts of whatever, so this is one of those games that are a bit of an investment and I didn’t enjoy the toy aspect enough to want to make that kind of investment.
About the gameplay, it was good, I enjoyed it. The controls are really fluid and intuitive. The air combat was really good, a lot of times those things made me motion sick, but this didn’t. The graphics were nice. The story was good and it kept me entertained. The game would have been rated better for me if you could customize without the toys.

reviews.title: Comfortable controller
reviews.text: I seem to go through controllers more often than I would like, so I’m always in the market for a new one. I have to say I like this control a lot. The controller itself is a little sensitive, but other than that it’s just like a regular controller. I have to say the feature I like the best about the controller is the nerd material on the back. It makes it super comfortable to hold especially if I am playing for a long period of time. If you are someone who has sweaty hands I think the backing would really help with grip.

reviews.title: Decent carrying case
reviews.text: I got one of the nerf controllers for my x-box and I really liked the cushy material on the underside of the controller, so I figured I would try out this case and see if I liked it as much as I liked the controller. The material that the case is made out of is not the same as the material on the controller, it’s similar but its a little bit harder. The case fits the switch very securely and snuggly, there is room for you to put games if you want. Overall it’s a pretty good carrying case, and I like it.

reviews.title: Great for indoor exercising
reviews.text: We love our switch in our house, but honestly we hadn’t really thought about using it for the whole fitness aspect. We finally buckled and bought this and honestly, I didn’t have a lot of high hopes for it. Thankfully, I was wrong. I like the game that comes with it, it’s easy to do the exercises, but it’s entertaining enough to keep me interested. I didn’t have the best success with the heart rate monitor thing, but other than that it works great and I really like it.

reviews.title: As good as my last one
reviews.text: It’s very comfortable, the cable length is really good, the dpi is good and responsive. It looks nice and gets the job done. I’m happy with it. It works great for my level of gaming.

reviews.title: Easy
reviews.text: For some reason I couldn't get the Live Gold through my Xbox, so I went here to get a digital code and it was super quick and easy and worked great.

reviews.title: SKIP this game- NOT necessary to play Nier Automata.
reviews.text:
This game couldve been so good, but it turned out to be somewhat of a poor game. First the good. Combat mechanics are fun, not great like dark souls, but its fun. The magic spells are fun to use and execute throughtout the game. The ability to change out spells in mid combat makes it not a complete real-time combat, but thats fine. Its a nice compromise considering you are limited to using a joystick. The graphics are good for its time, if not a little gray. But it becomes really good and the colors and motion become much richer and fluid with an upscaler.

The bad: Dialogue, I appreciate that they are trying to wax poetical but its too verbose. I understand that they had alot to say, and alot of ideas, but they werent organized very well. Its also not elegantly written either. Its just all over the place. That being said, it does have to be translated so its probably better in Japanese. If you take a look at games like Demon's souls, Dark souls, Bloodborne, you dont have to write volumes to get the point across that life is harsh, brutal and cold, but with some beauty sprinkled into what we call life that sometimes makes it all seem worthwhile. Souls series does it through focusing intensely on creating a visual atmosphere and sparse dialogue that hints at what is. But what this series does is try to expound verbally, what can hardly be expressed through words. Even the epilogue is completely verbal. Could they not just throw in some animations to carry the message and make it worth watching?

That brings me to the next huge negative- Kaine. She could arguably be the most annoying supporting character Ive run across. Even her walking around half naked couldn't make up for it. She could even beat the handler in Monster Hunter World. The only saving grace is that you don't hear Kaine all the time unlike the handler. And at least in the PC version of monster hunter world you can mute her and even change her face. Thank goodness for that. In any case, I understand what they were trying to do, make a volatile, seemingly complex character, likeable by helping the player empathize with her background through small but meaningful moments throughout the game. But no, it just fails to work. Perhaps the Japanese version works, but this utterly fails imo.

The last negative- Music. Sound quality is fine. but the music is so repetitive. If they were going to recycle the same music over and over again, could they not use low impact, no vocal instrumentals? Or just use it once in a while to create a nice, lasting impact? Its fine to hear the full track a few times, but over and over again, it just becomes hard to bear. This is really a huge negative as music is a huge part of any game. They need to master things like this, which I will say, in the newest Nier Automata game, they seem to have done. So bravo for that.

All in all, this game is not necessary to play Nier Automata, a complete standaline, which so far plays like a masterpiece of a game in all areas. You can avoid this game and really not miss a thing.

reviews.title: PROS and CONS- Updated
reviews.text:
Im usually very critical when it comes to products. But when they work and they are good, I give them their due. I rather NOT spend 100 bucks on this thing. But it works and it works well. It upgrades your consoles whether your console directly outputs via HDMI or has to go through upscaler like an OSSC. It improves the visuals output from every single console from retro to ps4. The colors generally are richer and images are cleaner with more depth.

For example, I have a RGB modded Genesis Model 1 Non TMSS with every improvement you can think of to soup it up to get the best visuals possible. The problem is the tech is old and so you are prone to some blurriness when random motion occurs. If you are used to slow paced games, then you wont get the max benefit from it, but you still will because of how much it cleans up the signal making it look nearly HD. Most reviewers show static pictures or pre-recorded intros rather than actually playing on the thing to show how effective it is.

Fast paced, quick random motions- this is where its improvement is noticeable. It produces a smooth experience. It wont add more pixels or any of that. But it will clean up the image and get rid of that haze that your console is producing. This will make the image look richer, NOT brighter. It will also actually seem to reduce the lag in your gameplay because of the clarity and smoothness of the relayed video. You will respond much quicker because of this. If you like shooters like I do, it is helpful here. Also, the 4:3 mode is very nice. When using OSSC on some modes it stretches the image mode too much and this helps bring the image back into a more proper ratio. YMMV

On a PS3/PS4 you should get a similar improvement, but in a subtle way, believe it or not. If you have a discerning eye, it will be readily apparent. Games like Nier, which has an obscene amount of blurriness, will greatly improve. Colors look richer and visuals will have more depth. PS3 and PS4 are especially prone to blurriness because of the heavy demand on the processors. When you pop in the McCLassic, its like playing on your PC without the additional resolution. Just more clarity, richer colors, rock steady visuals. I play alot of Bloodborne, and your reaction time will be better because of the reduced motion blur and increased clarity. If you get one, turn the MCClassic on and play it for a while. If you dont see the difference turn it off after a while by putting it on bypass mode. You will never go back to it off. You can see this clarity clearly in scenes where there is fog rendered. I hadnt noticed the fog as much before, but with the McCLassic, it adds so much more to the experience. Did I mention reduced lag experience? Those times you got hit and you swore you didnt see what hit you? Thatll happen much less often, if at all. When you get hit, you'll know why.

As for whether its worth it? If the above doesnt convince you and dont find as much worth in it and assuming you get marginal improvement, think of it this way. If you own more than 1 console, and you own an HDMI switcher and you plug it in the output, you can effectively upgrade every single console you own. Divide the price by how many consoles you own and thats the real cost for the upgrade.

Cons
You need to reset the Mclassic from time to time. For whatever reason, when you switch consoles and it puts out different resolutions, the image doesnt register. This happens rarely so far. I believe this is when it usually doesnt work temporarily. The only solution is not to go to bypass mode, but to completely unplug the mini/ micro HDMI power cord from the Mclassic and power it down. Plug it back in and you're good to go. Assuming this issue doesnt keep cropping up as well as other potential issues, its a straight up buy recommendation. I will update as I spend more time on it.

Edit: I use OSSC line doubler. X in photos 2x,3x, etc. can only get 2x line doubling with ossc + m because of the unstable output from OSSC. (May be related to the retro console itself rather OSSC.)

UPDATE: Still works fine as it is supposed to. Any issues encountered in switching as noted in this review and comments below can be solved by simply unplugging the power and hard resetting it. Even if its on "off mode." Another item I would like to add since Ive had this since its inception is that some people may prefer the pixelated blocky look. Personally, I like this blocky look, but it only looks good when you have razer sharp output from your console, which usually takes modding, decent monitor and, what people dont mention, power quality. If you have poor power quality, it will affect your visuals. However, solving power/electricity quality issues costs more than this upscaler. Having a good power/electricity source, I prefer to NOT use the Mclassic just because I love the blocky, crisp, detailed look. Improving the quality of your power/electricity source will make everything look and sound exponentially better WITHOUT altering the original content. Doing this is better than the result you get from MClassic. However, it costs more and takes experimentation and certainly not easy to do. All in all, Mclassic is an easy way to upgrade your experience.

reviews.title: SHMUP as Art
reviews.text:
This game is art as its finest. You can tell the personnel involved from top to bottom are professionals and makes other SHMUP makers look like amateurs. Its what Demon Souls/ Dark Souls is to the modern action RPG genre. Even though the first game was a groundbreaker, this "final" reiteration is at the top of my SHMUP list.

Sound 10
Graphics 10
Gameplay 10
Story 10 (extremely minimal but effective)

From the opening scene to the end, the creators did a great job taking you into their world. Its dark, its foreboding and its beautiful Its not about having super fast reflexes, dodging a million bullets at a million MPH, which has its place and is fine for other SHMUPs, but this franchise is different- you weave your way through traffic as if you are in the matrix- thoughtfully and deliberately, moving your force back and forth and angling them at just the right place. As the game moves along, it builds upon each stage, getting darker and presenting you with more unique and interesting challenges and bosses.

This game should be played with sound via the digital out port of the PS2 and into your stereo, properly attuned for best sound. Video wise either you use a component cable or RGB and have it line doubled via an OSSC or the like. It will be worth it because they did not skip on any facet of the game. It will suck you right in. Unlike other games which sound like you are in a techno club, (which can be fun) this game takes a different route and throws you into the midst of a cinematic experience with the quality sound and visuals.

This is one of those buy and keep games, no matter what console comes next.

reviews.title: What is this?
reviews.text: Its a piece of cutout foam, akin to an acoustic foam that you stretch and fit over your analog stick.  Avoid.  I put one on mine, and tried to take it off to try the other stiffer ring and it just tore apart when stretched out. Basically if you manage to put it on without tearing it up the first time, dont take it off.  In any case, buy it from amazon, bc their return policy is better than FREEK.  I didnt and regret doing so.

reviews.title: PROS & CONS for retro enthusiasts LF wireless
reviews.text:
Surprised to see all the five star reviews

Positives:
1) I will say that it looks nice, the design is nice;
2) Somewhat comfortable, good size, weight which is not heavy, and form factor;
3) Comes with nice packaging, which I do appreciate but I have mixed feelings about it which I will go into below;
4) very reasonably priced

Cons:
1) Build quality is poor- feels rather light and flimsy. I like that it doesn’t feel heavy but it feels too light. If you have ever held an 8bitdo controller you know how solid it feels yet it is light. This does not. They really should have used the extra plastic on the controller instead of the “fancy” packaging. 8bitdo used the cheapest packaging possible and saved the plastic for the controller, yet it was all tastefully well done and executed.
2) Tactile feedback is lacking. Compared to 8bitdo, very poor. Retrobit's you can kind of tell you pressed the button because you pressed the button but there is absolutely no feedback. If feels loose and flimsy. As if the buttons can just come off. This goes for the D pad as well which does not feel solid and responsive. There is a feeling of hollowness.

3) USB connection to Nintendo switch is not 100% supported apparently because it seems to lose its connectivity midway through use at times. This can be sporadic- I don’t know why it happens. This is also not strictly limited to USB. I also bought a Genesis receiver and while it seems to work on the majority of the games I have tried one game in particular- terminator sega cd, does not work properly for whatever reason.

4) most importantly connectivity. It works on its saturn and genesis. BUT there is noticeable latency. Easy to see/experience if you play streetfighter or any fighters. Pulling out next to last second uppercuts are very difficult. Use a wired joystick/controller and its back to normal.

With that being said, This is the only wireless solution for Saturn. Its a nice controller overall especially but mainly bc it is relatively cheap BUT only if you arent playing games that require instant responses.

Best controller is the original WIRED saturn controller obviously.

reviews.title: Very Nice offering
reviews.text:
This is a good retro controller.

1) Size on the small side, still manageable because the buttons aren’t too far apart which makes for quicker reactions;
2) Form factor smooth and rounded without any odd shapes making gaming more comfortable;
3) D pad is okay not bad, not great. Its nothing like the original genesis's improved controller. That one by far is the best I have ever used.
4) Connectivity is superb. You never lose connection and responsiveness is good. Latency ill have to do more testing. This is obviously one of the most important qualities. It is a good thing that they did not stop there and went the whole 9 yards with the controller itself. The edges on this Dpad are hard and unforgiving. Thumbs get tired quick.
5) Build quality is good . nice weight and solid without feeling heavy.

Their hyper dub limited edition controller is better. DPad feels better and better tactile feedback.

VS other wireless. Havent tried retrobit and joyzz. Retrobit version im not sure I want to spend the money to try since I wasnt thrilled with their saturn offering although it is the only wireless solution for saturn available. Joyzz is quite a bit expensive but if its the same as the original genesis improved controller, it would be worth the money.

reviews.title: Dissapointing
reviews.text:
Bought two of these. First one had issues loading. Returned, tried another one, had some issues but wasnt as frequent so thought it may be my cart slot. Spent many many hours cleaning cart slot. Thought I was just out of luck. A few months later, this new cart completely died out. Doesnt load at all. Its just trash now. Cant return it.

Turns out, it was just really poor quality control, absolute bargain basement parts. Ultimately, it wasnt my saturn cart slot. I bought an ALL IN ONE 4mb expansion cart with psuedo saturn kai preloaded. Worked the first time and every time. Never had a single issue. Still working after many months without any issue. Another plus is the all in one cart is black and not this ugly, beige, rainbow colored case. Good grief.

reviews.title: Phenomenal
reviews.text:
Works flawlessly.
Button clicks feel premo.
Easy to customize the button.
Designed to fit and work naturally.
Very impressive.

These are the other backbutton controllers I have/had- razer ps4 TE; Razer xbox wolverine; xbox elite 1; SCUF controllers. Out of these the best by far is the razer wolverine. The only problem is its not wireless. Compared to the wolverine, they are both great. Feel is the only difference and obviously the build material. Wolverine is metal. This one is plastic. Both are responsive and clicky. SCUF is an avoid. So is the Razer ps4 TE.

If it had extra two back buttons like xbox elite/wolverine, that would make it perfect, but really not necessary. Made a decent ps4 controller great. Add a pair of analog stick height extenders and you are set.

reviews.title: Beautiful BUT some GLARING imperfections
reviews.text:
4.5 out of 5.

This remake, overall, is excellent. However, what plagues this game is what seems to plague a lot of the modern games which is that while it is technically superior to its predecessor, it doesn’t quite live up to the same level of emotional experience that you would get by playing the original. I am not saying this just to be an originalist or a video game snob. Here are the reasons:

1) The musical arrangements are elevator musicesque in some ways. Compare opening sequence. It doesnt have the sense of doom and dread that you have with the original. The opening cutscene art direction suffers from this as well, albeit still stunning.

2) visuals are fantastic and so detailed and is a wonder to see BUT it also detracts in a way bc it takes away from this dream state like nightmarish experience. Don’t get me wrong I love the new visuals but I became more of an observer than one who was actually experiencing. The PC emulation version was great for that reason, retaining the dream state like experience but with updated technicals with 60 FPS performance. That was really what PS3 version lacked. It would have been great if they could have included a technically updated ps3 version as well on the ps5 or even be able to play original ps3 discs with improved performance like xbox series x is doing with all their legacy titles. As an aside this is why I am a huge fan of the new xbox again.

3) for all its beautiful graphics and performance, what happened to the wonderful cut scene artwork that was in the PS3? They added depth and substance to the game. It wasn’t just an afterthought. While I grant you that the load times are so fast that it would have been hard to have the time to appreciate it. Why not at least include a section for it as a homage.

Anyways still an absolute must play.

reviews.title: Best of the Hori stick?
reviews.text:
I like Sanwa parts, and although it doesnt have them, the hayabusa parts turns out to be just fine for me. Very easy to pull off split second moves. the stick and buttons are light, quick and responsive. Low effort and accurate. Its lighter than a sanwa, which in turn is lighter than the seimitsu. The only thing necessary to swap out imo is to replace the square gate with an octagate. For reference I have other Hori arcade pro sticks- 2 and 3. Also a few other retro sticks.

I prefer the shape of this stick vs the other Hori ones, which are too wide. Why would you need anything that wide? The shape and size of this model is similar to the RAP 1, 2, 3.

Overall, almost perfect imo. But can we get a wireless 2.4ghz version? Its 2021!

reviews.title: Fantastic on PC
reviews.text:
Highly recommended.

Used the Virtua Stick on PC. No perceivable input lag judging by how I was able to pull off split second moves. I imagine the controllers work on PC as well judging by others comments.

What would be great is if they could allow it to transmit bluetooth signals to the PC so you could use the controllers "wirelessly" so that itd work with say an 8bit do receiver. Id pay more for that.

Another suggestion for Mayflash would be to create a saturn to multi retro console converter. Saturn on one end and snes/megadrive/pc engine on the other. And another model going from saturn to gamecube/ps1/xbox.

Anyways good job!

reviews.title: Quality plugs.
reviews.text: Surprised to see these are actually quality plugs.  I tried other PC related ones and they were absolutely awful and flimsy

reviews.title: XBOX ELITE NO GO
reviews.text:
Supposed to work with Xbox Elite wirelessly. Doesnt. Need to clarify,

Im sure it works with others, but didnt test it. I bought it so I could use an xbox controller on an xbox but it didnt work. I worked with them to try to make it work for a few days. They said it doesnt work.

reviews.title: IT WORKS
reviews.text:
Thats the best compliment I can give anything these days. Most are made cheaply and it doesnt work. This one works- the included fan is top notch but the plastic is cheap and flimsy.

The most important thing though is that it works and ps2 is quiet. Noctua fan is great! Before this I stuck a Noctua fan in there by breaking off pieces on the PS2 grill and securing it with some sort of putty/dampener so it didnt move around.

Good job.

reviews.title: Plates are fine but the rest no
reviews.text:
Plates look fine and fit fine. Logo is just a sticker. Not cutout/laser etched.

Controller stickers are not sized precisely Resulting in a sloppy fit and wrinkles along edges. Looks nothing like what is shown in pictures. They most likely just photo shopped standard photos.

All in all it is expensive considering that you can get others for half the price for just the plate. The controller stickers are not even worth putting on. That being said the plates fit fine.

reviews.title: NEW but may need work
reviews.text:
First, about the Dpad. It is awful. Even playing low-demand turn based rpg games becomes fatiguing and painful to use. The dpad doesnt feel right. Its too shallow and have to press firmly for a decent response.

The 2.4 GHz aspect of the controller works fine. No issues. However, it does not make up for the D pad issue. Personally I would rather use something with a better D pad with Bluetooth if I have to.

As of now I just swapped in Im my PS 1 to snes adapter. And then plugged in an old wireless ps1 logitech receiver /controller with a superior D pad. (For those who dont mind wires- performance ps1 dpad is one of the best and happens to be very cheap used) It does end up costing more, but not having to aggravate about the D pad is worth it plus with the converter you can actually use a real joystick on the SNES for shmups and whatever else you can think of.

Their other controllers arent any better. The NES is the worst of the controllers. The Genesis is a bit better but not as comfortable as the original.

UPDATE:

Tried to figure out the cause of the poor performance. I was able to improve the responsiveness by cleaning up the dpad pcb with a cotton swab and IPA. Its new but why so dirty? Possibly these pcbs have been laying around the warehouse for a while before entering production. Who really knows but now the responsiveness is instant and feels a bit better but still the dpad design needs work because it still is not comfortable. I still prefer the other solution even if it isnt as cheap/elegant.

reviews.title: Spoiler-FREE Review
reviews.text:
Rating:

Graphics/Art 5/5
Gameplay a 4/5
Modernized Music 5/5
Translation 5/5
Added Scenes 4/5
Voice Acting (English) 3/5
Voice Acting (Japan) 5/5

4 stars doesnt seem that great, but its a nice remake. Not on the level of a Demon's soul remake, but still nice. Whats important is that they kept to the spirit of the original.

My favorite part of the game is how wonderfully they redid the music. For me, retrogaming is a good part about the music. I didnt think Id like it because I enjoyed the original so much. It was quite tastefully done. I think everyone will enjoy it. The only bad part is the option to play original compositions. It didnt come out so well. They must have paid very little attention to the transfer. The original compositions come off somewhat harsh. They shouldve borrowed my original SNES, which is modded for digital audio output with upgraded caps, audio quality internal wiring and power supply.

Main quibble with the game is the voice acting. Budget must have run thin considering they may have had trouble gauging what kind of reception the game would garner. Id opt for the japanese voiceover, although the English voiceover for Popoi is fantastic.

I really like that they added character development scenes, but the drawback is I ended up liking certain characters less- probably due to poor voice acting.

The other nitpicks are some of the animations which are needlessly long and drawn out- i.e., when talking to an NPC. Otherwise the art work is very nice.

The other notable thing is the difficulty. It has been modernized so that you can beat it without any effort or grinding. Kind of sad really. I dont like the grinding, which is fine. But the difficulty is skewed too much to the easy side for the bosses.

Overall, I think the gameplay experience is much better on the SNES even though this version is very much worth experiencing for the music, upgraded artwork and additional scenes.

reviews.title: Nice job
reviews.text:
PROS:
* Fits perfectly. Doesnt look sloppy
* Color looks professionally done. Got the silver. Silver + White + Gray backbuttons look nice.
* Oem look and feel

CONS:
* Plastic not as sturdy/durable as OEM. After installing and having to unassemble, plastic clips broke off. So once you install it, beware of this in case you want to swap out any other internal parts such as new back buttons. That being said, it still went back into place without issues.
* Kind of expensive for a piece of plastic. Should be 9.99. But inflation.

reviews.title: Thumbs UP?
reviews.text:
PROS:
* Clicky responsive buttons. Nice feedback. Very impressive.

* Nice aesthetics. Looks quality.

* Assembly not too involved if you dont have two left hands (or right if you're lefty)

CONS:
* Plastic not as good as OEM. Noticed a crack on tabs and some falling off after assembly and reassembly. Main problem with back buttons is that the plastic seems to wear down or get bent out of shape just enough that it doesnt make enough solid contact with the pcb trigger. This is a huge issue bc it results in missed inputs and the trigger no longer “clicks”. I had to return mine and get a new one after about 3 weeks.

* Somewhat cramped. I have average to above average size hands and I keep accidentally pressing the middle buttons. Itll take getting used to since Ive used the razer xbox, razer ps4, ps4 backbutton attachments and xbox elite. The others have a more comfortable layout for me. Still great. Just happy they have something for PS5

Ultimately though the biggest problem is the cheap plastic that they use. Otherwise design is fine. I just hope that they can address this issue in future revisions. I see that they will be making a real metal button option which would address the main issue I have. Still highly recommend it Since there really isn’t any other alternative. Itd get 4 to 5 stars if it wasnt for the cheap plastic.

reviews.title: save glitch solution FOUND
reviews.text:
Okay, I have just figured out how to save! When you click on the NEW GAME option DO NOT put your name in. Just leave INDY1. otherwise {even if you go through the whole game it will never SAVE}.By leaving INDY1, when you play the game, every time you pass a "loading" point, it will save.

And if you don't want INDY1 to be your save... get ready to play the WHOLE ENTIRE GAME IN ONE STRETCH {really we don't know how long it will take us to finish it}

reviews.title: impossibly difficult

reviews.title: My son love the scroll wheel

According to my son this is a great all around mouse. Only thing that could make it better would be a rechargeable battery. However, you can overcome this with a rechargeable energizer battery.

Fits in his hand nicely, he is 12 years old. It is comfortable for me as well.

He loves the fact the scroll wheel can be either notched or free spinning. This comes in handy for mining in his Star Citizen game. Responsive is great and can be easily adjusted. Programming the thumb buttons are quick and painless.

It’s Bluetooth capable if you do not wish to use the usb transmitter.

I have not heard him complain about the mouse.

reviews.title: Awesome fit, great protection!
reviews.text:
The product came nicely package and once my son unboxed it, installation was easy. The cover snapped into place with no issues. Very good fit, all cutouts aligned. There were no issues with the BoboVR m2 head strap, fitting in the case and CNBEYOUNG VR Face Cover he has installed on his oculus.

The shell itself is hard plastic with a soft texture coating that appears very durable. It does allows for a better grip which is good when a 12 year old uses it. Definitely provides much needed protection from bumps and handling. My son and I are both satisfied with the product and have no complaints or issues.

Update, his mom made vinyl stickers eyes which adhere great!

reviews.title: Good fit and excellent grip.  The company stands behind their product.
reviews.text:
My son has been wanted some grips/protectors like these. He has a habit of losing the controllers when he plays which cause me to get excited.

First, good quality material, appears durable. The grips are easy to install, fit tight, and all cuts out match well. My son had on before I could blink. The grips themselves have a good feel and provides much needed additional grip especially when hands get sweaty. The material thickness is just the right size in my opinion. The lanyards has a wide range for adjustments to accommodate various hand sizes.

Completely satisfied and my son is happy as well.

Update…they stand by their product. I had an issue with the hand strap related to the bottom grommet breaking. The company responded quickly and provide a replace set. Great to see quality customer service.

reviews.title: Good beginner wheel but expected more for the price point.
reviews.text:
[[VIDEOID:499ac84584cf56f9db85b46180571b61]] This is my first experience with Thrustmaster and a wheel in general. My expectations based on price and the Thrustmaster name were not completely met with the T128P for PS4/5 and PC. It’s a great $100 wheel but slightly above average $200 wheel. Primary user of the wheel is my 12 year old son but for testing purposes I have been driving race cars like I stole them, lol.

Arrival: The wheel arrived nicely package all component were in working order with no issues. However, I immediately notice some of the creature comforts I expected were missing based on price of the wheel such as cushion wheel or higher quality buttons with smooth action.

Instructions: Th instruction for setup were clear except for the computer driver download portion. A little more emphasis and larger font would be nice. Took me a second to locate them due to size of font.

Wheel: The wheel itself is made of hard plastics, buttons appear of low quality and make a loud audible click when pushed, especially the paddles shifters. They lack the quality you see with PS5 and the Xbox elite 2 controllers. The clamp worked fine but make sure you have room underneath your desk to attach, see pictures.

Pedals: I have similar thoughts when it comes to the pedals. The pedals assembly is very light and lack common sense in the design. It doesn’t take and engineer to understand center of gravity and how a lever works. To explain the pedals will slide forward when in use and have a tendency to want to pitch forward off the floor due the center of gravity begin shifted so far forward and the lack of weight to counter this affect. The design seemed to completely overlook that someone had to actually use this in game under various conditions. I guess that is why a pedal stand is sold by Thrustmaster as an accessory for ~$90. Just my thoughts but human in the loop and ergonomics should be considered in the design process hint…hint. You have to hold the pedals in place with your off foot, use a weight or hey buy their pedal stand.

Hooking up: Once everything was hooked up it was first tested on the PS5 with no issues. Worked well with GT7. For the computer…driver download was easy. Thrustmaster done have control panel for making adjustments to the settings. We first tried with Forza 4 and had issues. The game would not recognize the wheel. However, after some internet research we found this is a common issue across many brands of wheels and Forza 4. I found no immediate work around so we tried using the wheel with Forza 5. The wheel was recognized as a T248 and Forza auto-configured the wheel. The wheel worked as intended with all features being functional. My son did adjust the button layout to his liking. When also tried the wheel with the Crew 2 demo and it worked but not as well. Not all function worked on the wheel, mainly the center shift lights were not operable. This could be due to the game being only a demo though.

So to wrap this up the wheel is a good beginner wheel but without the creature comforts I expected for the price point. The design lacks in key areas of functionality and quality, especially regarding the pedals and use of quality components such as buttons. The dynamic functionality of the wheel lacks the feel I expected and in my opinion is cheap considering the price.

Note: the cord routing and layout could have been incorporated better considering it is a clamp on type mount. The cords are easily pinch during mounting and do not stay in the routing channels.

My review is solely based on my experience with this wheel and isn’t biased as I have never owned another.

reviews.title: Nice mouse but design hinders hand placement and comfort some.
reviews.text:
Overall the mouse is good. The left and right buttons are quiet clicks. The mouse scroll wheel works well does squeak, is smooth to spin only indentations. The digital display is handy and easy ti read. The led lighting can be turned on or off via the switch on the bottom. The mouse tracks well on screen and the adjustable dpi is useful. Forward and back buttons work as intended. It does have an auto off feature that increases battery life if not used for a period of time. Wiggling the mouse brings it out of hibernation.

My only complaint is with the design. Due to the curve of the base my forth and fifth fingers do not have a comfortable resting spot. I can live with it but that should have been taken into consideration. I have small hands and a person with larger hands is likely to have more of an issue.

So these are worth checking out but if you need to use the mike a lot and/or you have a bigger head, keep the shipping container handy just in case.

reviews.title: A Good Headset With An Irritating Learning Curve
reviews.text:
THE BOTTOM LINE - Getting the headphones and mic to work properly took some irritating effort for a newbie but was worth it for how it immediately enhanced my online gaming.

The headphones themselves are nice. The sound is excellent and the headset is the most comfortable for extended wear I've found yet. Wireless Bluetooth speakers often stutter while streaming audio but these non-Bluetooth headphones worked flawlessly. The controls are positioned a bit awkwardly, on the lower back end of the right side ear cup. I've hit the wrong controls several times while trying to do something as simple as adjusting the volume.

The set up was extremely irritating for me. The minimal directions are on one very large sheet with 95% of the content being the same few sentences in a myriad of different languages. I don't mind multi-lingual instructions, it was just the layout on this particular broadsheet that was frustrating. I had to keep flipping from one side of the sheet to the other trying to figure out what to do. Then it took me 20 minutes to get the headset to actually work simply because I had pushed the USB cords in as far as they seemed to go but they needed to be pushed in even further.A google search showed that folks have had similar problems with other Astro gear. Someone used to these kinds of headsets will probably have a much easier time but for a first timer like me, this was a very irritating exercise indeed. It turns out that the Astro website has a set up video that is dramatically easier to understand than the included instructions so keep that in mind.

Then, after I finally got the headphones plugged in and working, it turns out I can't get the mic to work. A google search did not help here as people have had problems with a variety of Astro gear but I couldn't find anything pertaining to mic issues with this particular headset. About 45 minutes ago I put in a support request on the Astro website. So I also get to test how good their support it. Once I've dealt with them and hopefully gotten the mic working, I'll update this review and adjust the rating accordingly.

EDIT: Upgraded the rating from 3 stars to 5 stars. Customer service got back to me within a day as promised. They gave me a check list of things to try (included below). Testing the headphones on a different computer was the one that worked for me. They worked flawlessly on a different machine so the mic problem had something to do with my first computer, not with the headphones themselves. The reason for moving the ratings upwards to 5 stars is that setting up and using the mic was pretty straightforward and using the mic opened up new game realms for me. Just now I used headphones and mic for the first time ever in an online game, running some missions with my guildmates. Being able to talk to my guildies was a whole new level of companionable gaming, one I thoroughly enjoyed.

Even with the 5 star rating though, I do have to reiterate a caution I gave earlier in this review. Using this gear will likely be a cakewalk for a techie who knows what they are doing. For a newbie though, getting to the sweet spot with this gear took some frustrating effort. If you are a newbie, I suggest that you start with the appropriate astro a20 set up video on youtube and if you have any problems, try this checklist from Astrogaming support. Good luck.

The suggested trouble-shooting checklist:
- Watch the set up video to check your settings.

- Check to make sure your A20’s Base Station is in PC Mode. The PC/Console Mode switch is located on the back of the Base Station.

- Resync the A20 Headset by plugging the headset into the A20 Base Station as if it were charging.

- Test the alternate USB ports on on your computer. Test your equipment on an alternate computer or console. Use a different voice program (Discord, Skype, Teamspeak, etc.)

- Hard reset your A20 Headset by simultaneously holding down the GAME Button (Located below the volume wheel) and the EQ Mode button located below the power button. Please note: When doing the hard reset, have the headset plugged in directly to a confirmed power source, without the Base Station. Let charge for 15 minutes, then retry.

reviews.title: An Abrupt Crash From 5 Stars To 3 Stars And Possibly Lower
reviews.text:
EDIT: I'm leaving my original review below to show you why I initially loved this keyboard and gave it a glowing 5 star review. Sadly, just a few days after posting that review things took a sudden turn for the worse. For unknown reasons the G Hub software controlling this keyboard crashed and burned completely. Not only is it no longer working beyond the basics but the crash also pushed the keyboard into default mode. That means the extra macro keys that were so helpful in my game reverted to being standard F1-F5 function keys. My game already uses those function keys for essential combat moves so now, after deliberately training my muscle memory to use the macro keys, those keys do entirely different things.. Even a casual gamer like me knows how that destroys one's game play.

A google search showed that this G Hub crash is a common enough occurrence that there are YouTube videos and reddit articles on how to try and deal with it. I followed some of the basic suggestions - rebooting the computer, reinstalling the software, unplugging the keyboard and plugging it back in again, all to no avail. The G Hub loading screen just spins endlessly and I have no way of altering the default settings of this keyboard. The next step is to trying dealing with Logitech support, which does not have a good reputation online. At 70 years old, I'm too tired to deal with much hassle so I don't know when I'll have the energy to take that on. If they can't, or won't, help me, the rating on this review will go even lower. If they can show me how to fix the problem, the rating will stay at 3 stars or possibly go back up to 4 stars depending on how much difficulty is involved. In any event, the first bloom of 5 star love is definitely over.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
First, let's give this review some context. As a retired guy I'm too old and slow to be a hard core gamer. I have five grandsons in high school and junior high who are hard core and their game play is in a whole different universe than mine. This review is not for them. I'm a relaxed, casual player and that's who this is written for. With that in mind, let's move on to this keyboard, starting with the fun stuff.

Fun - The Bright and Shiny Lights
A lot of gear branded for gamers seems to feature brightly colored lights and this keyboard revels in them. Before it arrived I wondered why it bothered to even have lights. When I first took the keyboard out of the box and plugged it in, the lights were so bright and were flashing so quickly that I was like "Whoa, how the heck can I even use this thing?? Those lights are just way too distracting and confusing!!!" Silly me. When I downloaded the control software I quickly discovered that I could tune the keyboard to my own liking, using other people's lighting designs or easily create my own. With a vast array of colors to choose from as well as a variety of shifting patterns and lighting sequences, I happily set about creating a lighted keyboard I really, really liked. Heck, you can set each key to have it's own color sequence if you want and you control how much the whole thing flashes and how often it all changes color. As far as I can tell, the colored lights have no impact on my game play but it's like having your own Christmas light show all year round and I love it! Why would anyone want one of those old, unlighted keyboards?

Fun - Clicky, Clicky, Clicky and Other Sound Stuff
When you order one of these keyboards you have have a choice of three different keyboard sounds. I got the Clicky version which sounds and feels a bit like an old school typewriter. The sound is unobtrusive but nice. I couldn't tell you why but that clicking in the background as you type feels comfortable to me. It's letting you know that you are actually doing something when you hit the keys. Again, why would anyone want one of those old, noiseless keyboards? They are so boring. 🙂

Another sound thing is the volume control on the keyboard. I don't particularly need it with my current set up as I have a small speaker, with volume control sitting right next to my keyboard. Still, my previous computer was an all-in-one who's volume control was awkward to use. So the keyboard mounted volume control would have been handy then.

The Serious Game Stuff - Macros and More Macros
Here's where we get down to the serious stuff. For those who don't know, macros are small scripts for doing a series of actions by pressing one key instead of having to press one for each action. For example, say you are playing a cowboy shooter and you ride into an ambush. You need to dismount, draw a rifle or pistol, aim, shoot, and reload when necessary. Normally each of those actions would require a separate key stroke. With a macro though, you could set it up to do all that with one key instead. As you can imagine, macros can be powerful, powerful tools in the game world. They are so powerful that the main game I play forbids using macros for more than one action at a time. Even with that limitation, the macro capability of this keyboard is still very useful.

There are five new keys on the left side of this keyboard that can be assigned to any use you'd like. Currently I have them set up to quickly mount and dismount from the various critters I can ride. That in and of itself is nice. However, you can also set up different macros on those keys which can be swapped in and out at the push of a button. There are a variety of professions and skills I can use ingame so if I wanted to, I could set up different macros to use with different characters in addition to the mounting/dismounting. I haven't done that yet but I fully intend to.

Just as nice is that the control software makes macro creation easy peasy. The control interface is minimalist in design and you have to poke around a bit to figure out how to use it but the learning curve is not onerous and once you have figured it out. using the software makes macro creation incredibly easy.

In case you can't tell, even as a casual gamer I love this keyboard. Hard core gamers will probably appreciate it even more than I do.

reviews.title: The Lights Are Pretty But Otherwise It's Just A Mouse
reviews.text: As a plug and play mouse this one does the basic job expected of a mouse. As a gaming mouse it may be a bit more problematic. The teeny tiny instructions direct you to a website to download a driver. It took a bit to find the correct download on their site and when installed it doesn't seem to do anything. The download did put a shortcut on my desktop but when I double click the shortcut or the application file directly, nothing happens. The mouse itself works the same as it did before installing the driver. If I click the DPI button it does indeed change the cursor movement on the screen but there is no way for me to know what the actual setting is. So if I accidentally click that button again, it's a matter of blindly clicking until I get back to that setting or something close to it. Also, for my gaming style, a 6 button mouse doesn't offer much more flexibility than a regular mouse. The two extra buttons aren't enough to make a significant difference in my game play. So as a regular mouse it works just fine with some pretty lights flashing continuously.  As a gaming mouse it doesn't do much for me.

reviews.title: Adequate Bur Not Particularly Awesome
reviews.text:
As a cranky old guy who spends a lot of his retirement time gaming in MMOs, I had some mixed reactions to to these headphones. On the plus side, they really are plug and play. No special software is needed, no tricky set up issues, just plug them in and they are good to go. MMO means massive multi-player online and it generally indicates the kind of game where you cooperate with some players while combating others. In a situation like that, headphones with a mic are essential to fast coordination. Gamers I know generally use Discord or Teamspeak to verbally communicate with each other. Once again, the set up was basically plug and play. With the headphones connected to my computer, I had no problem using them with either of those programs.

There were a few things that kept me from giving these headphones 5 stars. For one thing, the sound is okay but is nothing special to write home about. That's fine for gaming but if want to listen to music or watch movies, you'll probably want to switch back to your regular speakers. Which touches on another thing, this one positive. Some headphones and mics show up as unique items in my audio settings. So when I want to use them I have to plug them in and go into my settings to select them. This headphone and mic just show up as generic default input/output devices in my settings. So I can just plug them in without having to also adjust my settings.

Another negative is how flimsy the headphones feel. It took some effort to pull the earphones out enough to fit them properly on my head. It felt like I might break the thing if I pulled too hard so it took a bit to get the earphones extended as far as I need them. Moreover, the padding under the headpiece is similar to other headsets I've tried, only to have that padding rip and fall apart after only a few months of use. One other positive should be mentioned. There's an on/off switch for the mic on the headphone's cord. That's very handy as a mic that's always open can lead to echoes and squealing feedback that the other folks playing with you will not appreciate.

Oh, and there is one neutral thing to close with. Like most "gamer equipment" these headphones come equipped with pretty lights. That always seems like a silly marketing ploy to me, one aimed at 11 year old gamers. Those pretty lights are even more ridiculous than usual on a pair of headphones. The headphones are on your head, you can't even see those pretty lights like you can with a keyboard, mouse, or other "gamer gear".

So all in all, this headset/mic seems like it will do the basic audio job I need it for, talking with other gamers in the midst of fiercely fought battles. There's just nothing outstanding enough about it to boost its rating up from 4 stars to 5.

reviews.title: Excellent Headphones
reviews.text:
The sound is very good. The headset is perhaps the most lightweight and comfortable I've used so far. It's also completely plug and play. You plug the headphones in and you are good to go, no drivers or other software needed. Some headphones show up as unique items under the audio settings. So when you want to use them, you need to go to your settings to manually select them after you plug them in. Not these. Just unplug your speakers, plug in the headset and go from there.

A lot of manufacturers seem to think all gamers are middle school kids who need and want flashing lights on everything. The last set of "gaming" headphones I tried put ridiculous colored lights on the headphones. I say ridiculous because you can't see those lights when you are actually wearing the headset. So I appreciate the fact that this headset eschewed such nonsense, focusing instead on audio quality and the comfortableness of the headset.

There are two cautions I need to add. Though neither was a big deal to me, you should be aware of them. The first is that the cord on this headset is shorter than other headsets I've used. My set up is a main computer that I actually game on with a second computer to the side that I run Discord on. That way I don't have to flip in and out of the game to deal with Discord issues. The cord on this headset is fine for use with my main computer but is too short to reach the secondary machine. Depending on your set up, the length of the cord may or may not be an issue to you.

For me that also means I haven't tried the microphone on this headset, just the headphones. Given the quality of this product I wouldn't expect there to be an issue with the mic, but you might check the other reviews here to see what they say about that. Thanks for reading this and I hope you enjoy this product.

reviews.title: Pretty To Look At, Not Much Practical Use, But Ants Seem To Like It
reviews.text:
As a casual gamer I can't tell if this keyboard is serious overkill for me, is just filled with unnecessary frills, or is some combination of both. In any event, it has no noticeable impact on my gaming.

Let me give a bit of context. As an old, retired guy in the midst of a pandemic, I actually have a lot of time for gaming and easily spend 6+ hours a day in my favorite MMO. I call myself a casual gamer because I am too old and slow to be a hardcore, competitive player. So I don't play to beat others but to simply have a good time. My favorite MMO is Guild Wars 2, which has a variety of game modes, from relaxed casual to hardcore competitive. One of those game modes, World vs World is a series of open maps where players can roam as individuals, in small groups, or in massive zergs fighting other players to capture keeps, towers, supply camps, shrines, and the like. It's a nice mix of casual and competitive and even an old, slow guy like me can run wild there and the ingame rewards available make it worthwhile to do so. The action is fast-paced, fluid, and always changing and I usually spend a couple of hours a day or so in WvW.

That's the context in which I tried this keyboard and it worked no better than the basic $15 keyboard I had unplugged to try this one. Guild Wars 2 does not allow the use of macros so that feature did me no good at all. Roccat's macro set up seem clumsy anyway. You need to hit two keys, while looking at the keyboard to get the right ones. Other keyboards I've seen have a much better implementation of macros. My favorite option was one that had a dedicated set of extra buttons just for the macros. One button to hit and once you got the muscle memory down, you wouldn't have to look at the keyboard to hit the right key.

The "swift, precise key stroke" touted in the product copy had no practical effect for me. At times when my group was being swamped by a larger enemy horde, making swift action imperative, this keyboard seemed no faster than the basic keyboard it had replaced. Several times I had to hit a key twice before it responded.

Even something as simple as the audio controls seem clumsily implemented on this keyboard. There's three buttons and a knob. One button is for muting. One says FX and I still haven't figured out what it's for. The third button seems to turn the volume knob on, and the knob then adjusts the volume. The basic keyboard this one replaced had three audio control buttons - mute, volume up, volume down. Much simpler.

This is also not a plug and play product like basic keyboards are. After plugging it in, I had to go to the company website to download the necessary software. Once that was installed, I had to download/install an update. Once that first update was installed, I immediately had to download/install a second update. Not only was it a lengthy process, but the keyboard locked itself down during the download/install process, meaning I couldn't do other things on the computer while all that was being done.

Once all the software and updates were finally installed, I learned how unnecessarily irritating it was to use the software. The only instructions included with the keyboard were to go to the company website to download the needed software. On the website itself, there were no directions for actually using the software. So for me, it was a clumsy, hunt and peck process, trying different buttons to figure out how to do such basic things as set the color scheme, select the sound played when hitting a key, and set the profiles to change those settings depending on what I was doing. The company website was very pretty to look at but some simple step by step instructions for using their products would have been much more useful.

That description of the company website, "pretty to look at but of no practical use" is pretty much the way I would describe this keyboard. Yes, the lights are pretty. Yes, it's fun to choose the sound that plays when you hit a key but none of that does a thing to improve my gaming. The local ants really do seem to like this keyboard though. This morning when I sat down at my desk, they were swarming all over it, running around through its maze of colored lights. I have no idea what that was about but they seemed to be having fun.

reviews.title: The In-Game Sound Is Truly Beautiful, But...
reviews.text:
These headphones really do have the deepest, richest, most immersive in-game sound field I've heard yet from any headphones or speakers in the under $100 price range. For me though, that is not enough for a 5-star rating. Your mileage may vary of course, depending on how you use headphones but let me lay out the issues I had with this headset.

While the in-game sound was awesomely good, the audio quality for movies and tv shows as well as music and audiobooks were the same as most other headsets and speakers in this price range. The MMO I play the most has separate volume controls for music, environmental sounds, dialogue, and special effects while movies, music, etc, generally have a single volume control. I don't begin to understand the technical issues involved but that may have something to do with why these headphones can take the different sound files in a game and weave them into a very real sounding, three-dimensional sound field while being unable to do so for other types of audio files. Where this becomes an issue for me, and where your mileage may vary, is in what I use headphones for.

There's two times I plug in headphones - when I'm gaming with fellow players via Discord or when I'm listening to something loud at night and I don't want to disturb my upstairs neighbor. Other than that, I don't use headphones to listen to the sounds of my video game. Instead, I'll be listening to music or audiobooks on some decent computer speakers while gaming solo. Their sound for such things is as good as these headphones. The advantage of speakers is they don't start getting uncomfortable after extended use, like headsets do for me.

Which brings us to another issue I had with this headset. The product page touts their comfortableness. When I first put them on, they did feel more comfortable than other headsets I've used. After two hours of running ingame raids with some guildies though, the headphones were becoming uncomfortable. I was glad when we finished our group raid so I could sign off of Discord and take off the headphones.

So it really comes down to how you use headphones. If you game with them on all the time and are comfortable wearing a headset for an extended period, you will love this product and it will likely be 5-star headset for you. If not though, this item will likely drop to 4-stars for you, excellent in one area but average in most others.

reviews.title: Buy it now.
reviews.text:
If you have the computer to handle the Rift, you need it. With the price down all the way to $399 for the Oculus Rift + Virtual Reality Touch System, you truly can’t pass up this deal. The Oculus Rift is by far the most fun I’ve had with video games in some time.

When it comes to the actual physical system, I’ve noticed a significant amount of complaints with the excess wires. The Touch System includes the headset, 2 sensors, and 2 wireless remotes. The headset requires an HDMI port and USB, each sensor requires a USB port. I can admit the wires can be a bit frustrating, but honestly I really haven’t noticed them at all. In fact I’ve actually used the wire from the headset as a reference to stay centered in the room.

The tracking is amazing and the boundaries you set up for yourself around the room make punching the wall a rarity. The controllers, as designed, feel like natural hand motions and are easy to use even with my toddler hands. The headset is a bit big for my tiny-ass head, but no one else seems to complain about it, so I’ll live with it. All the features lead to a truly immersed feeling for the player.

I am really blown away by this system, along with everyone I’ve also had try it out. If you’re even questing the Rift, the answer is yes. For the love of god yes.

reviews.title: Might as well
reviews.text: I stream game play, bought a special edition controller for funzies. I'm glad I did. Light, durable, well lit, battery seems to last longer than the original controllers [at least the ones that I have, which are probably a little dated]. With it being the same price as the previous DualShocks, you might as well make it look cool.

reviews.title: Yaaaaaawwwwww
reviews.text: Have been using the x56 with flight sim to practice a few checklist things and can't complain. I think a beginner would probably be overwhelmed with the options, so I'd recommend starting with something simpler. Definitely could use some weight to the bottom, but the pre-installed holes for stabilizing to a desk are nice. Like it so far.

reviews.title: What VR always should have been
reviews.text:
Far exceeds my expectations. Boyfriend bought it and I set it up while he was away. Couldn't put it down.

Works I incredibly smooth compared to the rift. No sensors is life-changing. It's cool to be able to take it with you anywhere and not lug an expensive pc around.

If you want VR, get this.

reviews.text:
I was worried the lighting would be too much, but it's just enough. I love this mouse pad. I'm so glad I went for the cheeper brand, the price is perfect. The pad it's self is thick and comfortable for the hours I spend editing videos. The lights are soft and I don't even notice them when I'm working.

Get it! You'll be happy with it.

reviews.title: Smooth Boi
reviews.text:
I use Mad Catz because I have unusually tiny, child hands. I hate that they're so expensive, but it's worth the price. I've had 3 Mad Catz models before and this one by far provides the most customization on any of the previous products. The replaceable parts are awesome. I definitely prefer the gripped, but it's an easy switch. Removing the weights is also a breeze.

If you're looking for a smooth moving mouse for tiny hands or giant mitts, this'll cater to you. Worth the buy.

reviews.title: Smooth
reviews.text:
This mouse is light as AIR. It's a bit bigger than I anticipated, but the weight compensates for the size.

The battery life is something to be desired. I followed the instructions on charging out of the box, however I have yet to hit100% battery charge despite long hours of charging. 97% is the closest to full. I game and work on social media and spend roughly 2-4 hours at least on the device daily. I have had to charge the mouse every day I have owned it.

The connection fails randomly which has not helped my KDR. If this doesn't fix itself I'll be returning it. It's a shame because my AK spray has improved significantly since using this mouse.

I am not a fan of the buttons on both sides. I ultimately disabled the buttons on the right, but I can appreciate the fact Razer is keeping it's left-handed customers in mind.

All-in-all, I am a big fan of Razer products, but disappointed in the price of this mouse and the quality. I'm dedicated to the company and hope to find resolutions to these issues.

I'd give it a 5/5, but the product is not easy to cut down to fit your device. The product is rather large and I use a smaller mouse. Otherwise it does exactly what I need.
