reviews.text: Love it, works great with my Samsung S7E Android device and VR headset.  Great price for a great product.  Wish it were made in the US, but as with almost all electronics it isn't.  Even so incredible product for price.

reviews.title: Great Product,  Simple yet elegant
reviews.text: Fits nicely in your hand works perfectly.  I never thought about buying a remote for my Xbox One until I started using it for movies then it's much better then messing with a clunky controller.

reviews.title: Simple, clean, easy
reviews.text: Exactly what it says it is.  Can't go wrong with OEM products.  Have tried most of the other charging options and with the new Elite controller the old ones no longer work.  Their are some nice charging systems out there I will probably try out, but for now this works with all controllers for Xbox One and is Li-Ion. So for my Elite controller this is the best solution.  It is Microsofts fault that their elite controller will not work with the other charging systems because the used a different battery cover.  I have tried the other charger and battery options before my elite and they all took up too much space and usually had cheap batteries.  So I will stick with these until I see something new that has the same quality battery.

reviews.title: Great Product
reviews.text: Great idea for a product. Instead of having all the extra cables from a USB hub it just connects directly to the front USB port of your Xbox One S.

reviews.title: Great Product lots of fun!
reviews.text: This system works very well with the  Alienware AW17R4-7345SLV-PUS 17" Laptop (7th Generation Intel Core i7, 16GB RAM, 1TB HDD, Silver) VR Ready with NVIDIA GTX 1070 that I purchased from Amazon also.  I took of one star because I have had problems with the sensors not calibrating correctly and it wants you to configure it standing.  I got the Oculus Rift over the HTV because I wanted a sitting VR experience to start.  I am still working on the configuration and playing with settings.  So far I have gotten it to work but have never gotten a perfect calibration of the sensors which makes it hard to use the controllers that come with it.  I also have not been able to get it to work with steam VR as of yet.

reviews.title: Decent if all were there
reviews.text: Instructions very limited and hard to follow. I was missing a button.  Not sure why one is much taller then the others see pic for example.  I haven't installed them because of a missing button.  So unfortunately I can't say how good or not good the feel installed.  I will contact vendor and see what can be done.  Will update review accordingly.  The concept is great the product not so much I would keep lookiing.

reviews.title: Decent product, Easy to Install
reviews.text: It causes annoying interference with the microphone.  The paddles are in a strange and uncomfortable location in my personal opinion.  The fact that it doesn't work with other micro-USB cords is horrible because the cheap cable is worthless. It was very easy to setup and configure.  I would much rather have a MS Elite controller but they are junk also now.  If you are going to make a USB cord proprietary then at least make sure it has the clips that lock it in place.  I can't say I have tried the mods because that's cheating and wouldn't be fair.  However, if I had to guess I would say they would work great based on what I have seen.  It was a waste of money for me because I just couldn't get over the location of the paddles because they weren't natural to me and I didn't want them to become muscle memory encoded.

reviews.title: Standard Xbox One Controller
reviews.text: Nothing exceptional just your standard Xbox one controller replacement after an older one died.  Works like all Xbox one controllers it did appear to be the older version but I am not that worried about it to investigate further.  To me it does the job and is a backup controller anyway.

reviews.title: Didn't help
reviews.text: These were absolutely worthless and a complete waste of time and money.  They didn't even improve my grip on the remote let along any of the other claims.  This is just my personal opinion and I am sure there are people who believe it has helped them.  It was easy to install is the only reason it's getting 3 stars.

reviews.title: Well made but not much improvement
reviews.text: On the plus side it is very well made and easy to install considering.  It doesn't improve your trigger pull by a whole lot.  It's not like a competition trigger installed on a real life SIG SAUER or anything close.  I was kind of expecting something close to at least a competition trigger on a real handgun, but it's nowhere close unfortunately.

reviews.title: For work, nothing beats this
reviews.text:
I waited to purchase a keyboard, wanting the right deal, and this one is definitely it! Rosewill used to be a bit bargain basement, but they've really stepped it up recently, and this is a great, low-cost option to get some real Cherry MX switches under your fingertips for cheap.

I was originally looking at [[ASIN:B00S5E4KH2 Rosewill Mechanical Gaming Keyboard with Cherry MX Blue Switches (RK-9000V2)]], which I am sure is a great keyboard, but I did notice that the reviews stated that the cord left something to be desired. I purchased this for typing in an office with a sit/stand desk, so a weak USB would not do. I didn't want to pay too much through, so I waited it out with my membrane keyboard.

When this dropped to $79.99 (blue backlight only), I jumped on it. The Cherry MX Blue switches are clean, precise, and sound great. I need a wrist rest when I work because I stand, and find the one that comes with this to be sufficient (it's hard, but I like it that way).To top it off, the cord is a gorgeous, heavy-duty braided nylon. It's not detachable from the keyboard, but I didn't want that anyway. The extras were nice... I don't need gaming keys, but I appreciate the cleaning brush and the keypuller (in case these wear over time).

Overall, this keyboard is easily worth much more than the $79.99 I spent. There are better choices for gaming, but I doubt you could do better if your main goal is simple, quick, precise typing. I highly recommend this.

reviews.title: Perfect. Holds Switch, Games, Cables. You won't be disappointed.
reviews.text:
I did a lot of research before buying a Nintendo Switch case. Reading reviews here on Amazon, searching for case buying guides on Google and even reading a few long and opinionated threads on reddit. I then decided on the Butterfox case. Before I tell you my opinion, here's what was my requirements.

- sturdy, solid case, able to protect from bumps
- handle, so it was easy to carry
- storage for cables, joy-con straps (not the joy con grip, just the straps)
- storage for games
- no pesky elastic straps that might rub against the console

Happy to say the case delivers on all accounts. Starting with storage, it has enough room for a USB-C cable (6ft Anker cable) and the joy con straps. It's probably too tight for a charging plug as well, but I carry an Anker 5 port charger separately anyway.The cables all sit in a zip pouch.

There's a center flip part that can hold your switch games. It holds a lot. I haven't counted how many, but more than enough.

The switch sits snugly in the case. Not too tight but tight enough to hold it snug. So it's easy to get in and out. Butterfox were smart and there's a handy piece of material to make it easy to lift your switch out. The game card flap then velcro's down to provide extra protection of the screen and hold the switch in place.

All of the zippers are smooth. There's no weird plastic smell. Overall, very impressed.

Negatives
None. Wish I had purchased one with color zips. I purchase the entire black one. Which is great, but I wish I had some color to make it stand out in the bottom of my bag.

reviews.title: Headphone stand WITH wireless charging
reviews.text: I have this in my office and use it to hang my headset when not in use. BONUS is that it has a wireless charging base, so I charge my airpods on it as well. Great value and quality. Love it. The only confusing thing is the top piece for holding your headphones has a wireless charging logo but there's no way for it to do that (no power). Not sure why it has the logo twice. Kinda weird. Otherwise, love it.

reviews.title: Harvest Moon: A Wonderful Game!
reviews.text:
If Animal Crossing was good, this is great!
It's so nice to find a game that's human-scaled, cute and friendly. And the game arc goes on for virtual years. Compared to a Star Wars game, this is a MUCH greater value.
Water your crops, feed and brush your animals. Find a wife. Raise a child. Grow prize melons, create new hybrids.
This is such a unique game that you've really got to try it out for yourself. My kids (5 and 9) love the game. Some reading ability is necessary to play the game.

reviews.title: Rent, don't buy. Boring. Mean-spirited, decayed.
reviews.text:
1. I didn't like the idea of a female character.
2. Rolls up into a what?
3. Every enemy is killed with sidestep-fire, sidestep-fire.
Looked cool. Not too much beneath the paint. Tedious, evil, ugly monsters to the left and to the right in great abundance, some stuff that looks like fungus on the ceiling... it's not just another shoot-em-up, it's another shoot-everything-in-sight-two-or-three times games.
In a word, it was a boring game. I'm sorry I bought it when it was new and that I paid full price for it. Animal Crossing has a far, far greater play value.
Ugly, jaded, sad, disspirited -- I did not like Metroid Prime.

reviews.title: Best game I've played in YEARS!
reviews.text:
I read an article on wired.com/news about this game and couldn't wait to get a copy. Got the Prima guide with it, which has been worth the money so far (third day).

I bought a Gamecube and later a PS2 and only recently bought an Xbox (I don't like MS) and I hate to say that the graphics, at least in this game, are out-freaking-standing. Approaching photo-realistic. The scenery in O:SW is PHENOMENAL, great late-afternoon sunset lighting with beautiful little touches like bits of fluff from weeds providing counterpoint to the action and firepower. The graphics really pop.

The "live ammunition" takes some getting used to in much the same way that it took me a while to figure out how to play the PC version of Lemmings oh-so-many-years-ago. It's GREAT fun, very imaginative, and the mazes are terrific so far. The villians are as rotten as they ought to be and the Stranger is a brilliant idea. I'm really looking forward to getting through my day and firing up the Xbox to play some more, and I just don't play that many games (I'm an OLD fart). Or maybe I'm just picky -- it's not every day, or every YEAR, that I find a game that I like, and I **LIKE** this game!

The game feels really tight overall, they did a great job producing it. Good concept, great art direction, the gameplay is a lot of fun -- I love this game! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!!! THIS ONE'S WORTH THE MONEY!!!!!

reviews.title: What's all the excitement about?
reviews.text:
My 10-year-old son loves this game. I just do not see the appeal. I played Castle Wolfenstein on the PC back in 92 and this feels like a retread. The first-person view is difficult to control. The scenery is somewhat plastic-looking.

The first-person/third-person switch in Oddworld: Stranger's Wrath is MUCH better. Halo 2 has NO sense of humor. I just don't see the appeal. Not that great a game for the money. Wait and buy it used, or just rent it for a day or two.

What's all the excitement about?

reviews.title: Fantastic "M" rated shoot-em-up!!!
reviews.text:
I loved the original Castle Wolfenstein on the PC way, way back when. I was pleased to pick this game up, it's a BLAST! The graphics are sensational, particularly when compared to the original. The mazes are challenging, the bad guys are bad, and the monsters are REALLY bad!!!

Want to turn off your mind and relax? Check this game out! NOT for kids, it's correctly rated.

reviews.title: The essential modern kid's toy
reviews.text:
I love the backlit screen! This toy has more bang for the buck than almost any other I can think of. The internal battery and recharger is brilliant -- no more asking for new batteries (though I now have a nice collection of rechargable AAs!). Great titles, Nintendo's strong point.

Can I think of ANYTHING negative about a GBA? No, I cannot! I wish they'd had these when I was a kid!!!

reviews.title: Outrageously great fun -- my favorite PS1 game EVER!!!
reviews.text:
This game is imaginative and FUN with a lot of play value. The mazes are damnably clever, the music is GREAT and Phil Hartman as the voice of Blasto MAKES the game!!! You'll play this one a LOT. It's worth finding.

The cut scenes are hysterical, like Captain Blasto piloting his ship through the cosmos when he gets a call from Galactic HQ telling him that Uranus is in danger -- to which he responds "So what else is new?"

"Better get a mop -- there's going to be guts on the ceiling!!!"

Really one of the best games I've ever played, and definitely the best PS1 game as far as entertainment value goes. I wish that Phil Hartman had lived to be the voice of Captain Blasto in a sequel! Did I mention the mazes being difficult? They'll have you pulling your hair out. It all takes place in a cartoonish universe full of tongue-in-cheek humor and obscure science fiction movie references. Or inferences. GREAT FUN!!! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

reviews.title: Pretty, but significant playability issues
reviews.text:
Killzone is nicely detailed, the graphics are very good and it's got a sophisticated European feel to it, but several issues significantly reduce its playability.

1. Sluggish controls. It's like you're trying to move in chest-deep water. Everything moves slowly.

2. Enemies are stupid, yet difficult to kill.

3. Members of your squad just get in the way -- excess baggage. Get out of my way! I'm trying to play a video game, here!

I wanted to play a good game, but this hasn't turned out to be even a halfway decent game. I can't recommend it.

reviews.title: Not my cup of tea
reviews.text: I had a hard time getting into this game. For some reason it felt more like work than the distracting, fun experience I was looking for. Gameplay seemed convoluted and I had a hard time controlling the character's point of view. Weapon selection and use wasn't intuitive or comfortable. The overhead "radar" view of enemies didn't make sense to me. This game just wasn't very much fun for me to play, a disappointment.

reviews.title: Very good for a Star Wars game
reviews.text:
I've got to state up front that I suffer from major Star Wars burnout -- the first movie (1977) was great, everything else has been merchandising -- so my praise for this game is not given lightly.

Gameplay is smooth and dynamic, some Star Wars games we've had in the past have been really dreadfully behind the times, this feels like it's state-of-the-art.

The space combat is a welcome addition. My son clued me in on new characters previously not available to be played. It looks great on the screen.

Overall? For a Star Wars game, very good. For any other game, ok. It's an improvement on previous Star Wars games, but for my money I just do not want to hear Obi Wan Kenobi's voice encouraging me to trust the force or take a droidica apart or anything like that. I'm just sick of Star Wars in general.

Now, my son, who's eleven, thinks this is the best game he's played since Halo 2. So go forth and figure.

reviews.title: Intense, nonstop, realistic combat action
reviews.text:
Intense and gritty game. Great graphics. Motion of figures and vehicles is somewhat jerky. Controls are smooth and the game runs well, no lag at all. There are a LOT of options and command combinations to remember to communicate with your team members.

Good game, lots of play value, but way too intense for anyone under 17 or so.

reviews.title: Delightful, fun game with no laser blasters or mayhem
reviews.text:
Really an endearing little game, the robot is adorable and there's plenty of play value wandering around exploring the robot's new home and taking care of its new family.

A game like this, with no Star War tie-ins or laser blasting mayhem is really something to be cherished when you've got a couple of young kids at home. Watching them play together to solve the puzzles in the game rather than trying to virtually slaughter one another is a real treat.

Excellent graphics, clever gameplay -- this game is a good example of why Nintendo is the best value of the three big consoles -- THEIR TITLES ARE BETTER, more original, more inventive, with greater long-term play value.

Find a copy of this game TODAY! It's a good one!!

reviews.title: My 11-year old loves it
reviews.text: From my grown-up point of view the gameplay is frenetic, I can barely keep track of what's happening. The Spartan has near-superhuman strength and stamina. The battles are intense. My kid LOVES this game, which is all I'm concerned with. It's somewhat violent, but nothing objectionable. Overall I'm impressed with the design of hte game, the graphics are really spectacular. But I've learned that all that really matters about video games is whether or not my kids find play value in them, and this one gets TWO THUMBS UP -- great one-player game.

reviews.title: Another brilliant step forward for Nintendo
reviews.text:
I bought a pair of these for my kids and I've gotta say these are impressive little items, it's hard to call them "toys" -- my kids love the wireless text chat feature, and the play value in that feature alone is considerable.

The screens are surprisingly large and bright (remember the old GBC screen?) -- there's a cool little slot to store the stylus in, the sound is incredible compared to GBA or GBC sound. The games are incredible compared to the old graphics, far more detailed than I'd imagined and they really run quickly and smoothly.

Kids have a good school year? This would make a VERY nice reward/reinforcement!

reviews.title: This is a piece of manure from Microsoft
reviews.text:
Short version: It. Does. Not. Run.

Take your money and set fire to it, you'll save time trying to troubleshoot this piece of crud -- it just wasn't written very robustly. Or, if you'd rather, buy it and spend three hours downloading various patches and trying to tweak various settings on your machine trying to get it to function.

The emperor wears no clothes. This is badly written software and it should not be purchased by anyone for any reason. Microsoft produces trash as far as I'm concerned and I'm angry with myself for not remembering that, I wanted to play this game, I wanted it to FUNCTION on a basic level AND IT DOES NOT DO SO. THIS SOFTWARE DOES NOT FUNCTION. DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME!

reviews.title: Great fun, much better than other Sims games
reviews.text:
My Sims has a lot in common with Animal Crossing and Harvest Moon -- it takes a while to play and you're not blowing things up with laser guns, both of which I feel are GOOD things.

You arrive in town and meet the mayor and get a tour of the town, then you design and build your house using the Wii controller and nunchuk by rearranging blocks and clicking them into place. If you don't like designing and building things, you might not like this game.

Other Sims games I've played on the computer or other consoles have struck me as being kind of creepy and not so much fun. I like My Sims MUCH, MUCH better than the other Sims games. The graphics are good and the overall spirit is much lighter and kinder. There's a sense of humor throughout the game. I still like Animal Crossing better, but this is a VERY good game and I recommend it if you have a Wii!

reviews.title: Fun FPS w decent graphics
reviews.text: In spite of the absence of HD graphics, this is a fun First-Person Shooter (FPS). Not too gory, but definitely 13+. Some excellent mazes and puzzles with terrific alien weaponry. Overall a very good game, worth the money. An interesting sci-fi plot. It's not going to make you forget Halo but it's a good game, and the motion control Wii remote and nunchuk make for something interesting.

reviews.title: Unique fun with huge play value
reviews.text:
What a great game! All the activities are set on an island resort. So far our favorites are basketball and the airplane tour of the island. The sensor that fits onto the Wii controller is a great improvement (buy some new batteries, though, to get the most out of it). This is an ideal game for these hot summer vacation days when it's too hot or too expensive to go anywhere, really. Which brings me to the play value of this game. It's a phrase I like to use with my kids when they want a toy that I think is going to interest them a total of about twenty minutes. This game, on the other hand, has almost UNLIMITED play value between solo and team efforts and then the various permutations on each game which you unlock as you play.

Couple this with the unique and brilliant motion controller concept and this is a MUST-HAVE GAME! It's fantastic!

reviews.title: The wheels came off
reviews.text:
I *still* play Animal Crossing, but "City Folk" was severely lacking most of the charm and fun of the original. The way the character moves and the way the scenery rolls by has changed, which I felt was a bad mistake, and the Gyroids are gone. I was hoping for an extension of Animal Crossing, but this game was more of a foul ball, it just missed its target something fierce. I do not know what Nintendo was thinking making so many changes.

As I mentioned, I'm still playing Animal Crossing. Nine years later!!! I wish that "City Folk" had been even half as good as the original.

reviews.title: Ugh
reviews.text: Endless annoying pop-ups interrupt you as you play. The graphics are stale. There are glitches and sons of glitches along the way, including one which ended game play for me, two characters inexplicably crawling on the ground like serpents -- and that was all they did, could not move the character at all. Could not save over the game file. Maddening. This might have been a terrific game -- in 2000. Don't buy it, don't rent it... it's just a dud IMHO.

reviews.title: Flowers DIE?
reviews.text:
Sometimes I'll go a week or more without playing my old Gamecube Animal Crossing game. A New Leaf has flowers that wither and die! So that's kind of an issue. The trees are too small compared to the humanoid figure in A New Leaf, too. Look at a Gamecube version capture and a New Leaf capture. Why are the trees so small? Weird.

In my old Gamecube save, after 12 years, I have *LOTS* of flowers. And they look great. And I don't need to water them constantly. This is kind of a big deal with me. I really like planting flowers in the Gamecube version. I'm not so sure I want to commit to watering so many flowers in New Leaf.

I'm not wild about being the mayor of the town and having to organize things. I just want to play the game. I don't particularly want to be responsible for the whole town.

The area at the back of the shopping district / high street is disturbing -- some kind of showcase for home designs? Why is it so big? It's not a pleasant area. I wish it had been devoted to big garden plots to grow vegetables on, something like that. I don't like the Happy Room Academy in the first place. That big wasted space on the map is creepy, makes me think of nightmares where stuff doesn't make sense. Why is it on the map?

I still prefer the point of view in the original game, the way the camera moves as you run along.

The flowers are too detailed in A New Leaf. They just are.

The Island is fun to visit, but I miss Kapp'n rowing his boat, and his songs in the Gamecube version were a lot more fun. He seems to have gotten married and settled down and become... boring. He traded his rowboat for a motorboat? Why was that considered to be an improvement?

The mini-games on the Island are amusing but something I'd think of more in a Monkey Ball game. You collect medals, which you use to buy items on the Island.

The wet suit and goggles are great, but you can't see anything under water, which is something of a disappointment.

Interaction with Tom Nook is minimal, his nephews run the store on alternate days from one another.

You know, all the pieces are there, but it's not as much fun as the Gamecube version. I never played Wild World and I was seriously unimpressed with City Folk. I was hoping this would be another great version, to the point where I spent $275 or whatever it was buying a 3DS XL. And I haven't been playing the game constantly, or even often, really. Meanwhile, I *STILL* play the Gamecube version nearly every day.

I wish they'd expanded the Gamecube version, not reinvented it. Maybe over time I'll grow to enjoy New Leaf more. Right now it feels like work to play it. Kind of like a cartoony Sim City.

I still love the Gamecube version. I'd like to think that I'll grow to love New Leaf. I remember feeling excited and happy first playing the Gamecube version and I wonder why I don't feel that way about New Leaf.

reviews.title: UPDATE FROM PREVIOUS REVIEW
reviews.text: I posted a review while sony was having network issues so i couldnt review on everything. Been playing it as it should be for last few days. The console seems to be fine but still seeing this orange light on standby when the system should be shut down. Perhaps its only setting issue. Recieved a LOU download which works fine but wouldve preferred a disc. Also i wish id have waited for the deal where u get LOU and could pick your game. Im not a GTA fan so id have preferred Far Cry but for 414 still was a great deal. Also as i was digging through the box they also gave me a 10 dollar ps store voucher which was pretty cool considering all the free stuff already. One HUGE complaint is the earphones. Ridiculous earbud...one mind you. Ill give Xbox credit for actually giving us a real headset with the One. It was also a 100 dollars more so that could be why. Graphics are very nice and no more diesel truck noises when the fan comes on like our ps3 does...sooo loud! Wish it wouldve came with a bigger hard drive too. Download some games and check your system memory...blow your mind. I bought 7 games for it and i dont think they will all fit...not sure what to do on that one. LOU is almost 50GB...huge game!

reviews.title: RESIDENT EVIL 4...I THINK NOT!
reviews.text:
I will start by saying im on Chpt 12, but i feel ive played enough to write a review. I only payed 19 bucks for this..so i cant complain too much. If id have paid 60 id have been a bit let down.

First of all, for me the controls didnt bother me. I didnt notice all the glitchy/clunkiness everyone is talking about. Im just a normal gamer and mostly single player gaming so maybe the advanced gamers know something i dont.

The story is all over the place. I thought i understood the main point but after a while i was clueless. All i do know is Im looking for Kidman and Leslie is the patient.

The really neat thing is the save room. The ability to find keys and use on the lockers is awesome. Its mostly green goo in them but thats ok. Being able to upgrade is a plus too and you being able to choose what comes first.
Very frustrating with the limited checkpoints because one touch and your dead! You will start all over and that gets old quick! You have to keep dying to figure out how to kill t
he monster...im speaking of safehead monster..which gets annoying.
Lastly like i mentioned im on ch 12 and just got a new handgun.. magnum. That wouldve been useful throughout the game. Also i have received it and yet to find any ammo for it.. kind of a joke.

Overall it is a decent game. If its offered for 30 or less pick it up. Definately worth that much because of the enjoyment factir. All i can say

reviews.title: REALLY WANTED TO LOVE THIS!
reviews.text:
I absolutely love TellTale games so i was excited to play this one from Gamefly. I love the premise for this game. Has a real "Whodunnit" feel to it. The only issue I have with it is the dialogue scenes seem to really drag sometimes. I have to admit i actually dozed off a couple times. I love the fable characters and you seem to be able to early on pick who you like and dislike.
Over all its a good game and the price is low but only warning i would have is do not play if your getting sleepy.

Has multi-colored lighting, is 2.5ghz wireless, decent DPI, robust construction, and decent ergonomics. Fits the bill for a gaming mouse so far as aesthetics. The only downside I would say is that the dongle can't be stored in the mouse itself. Small issue in the scheme of things, but worth noting.

reviews.title: Solid compact mechanical keyboard but odd font/layout choices on the keycaps
reviews.text:
I'm a software dev and gamer and have been using mechanical keyboards exclusively for around 15 years so I own and have used quite a few of them. This keyboard features the Razer 'Orange' switches, which have a pretty similar feel and sound to Cherry MX Brown, I'd say these feel slightly 'spongier' than the Brown keys, but not bad. They are definitely not silent, but are not obnoxiously loud like Cherry MX Blue switches, and with the included rubber dampers they are pretty quiet to the point where I doubt they would bother anyone except the most picky of office-mates.

Build quality is good, as you would expect from Razer, and the backlighting works well and looks slick. That said, I'm not a huge fan of the low-profile keys which facilitate the backlighting.. they look odd if the backlighting is not on and I don't like the way it feels if I rest my finger below the spacebar. That said, at least the low-profile keycaps do prevent things from getting lodged between the keys and make it easier to clean.

The other thing about this keyboard that I really do not like is the lowercase font used on many of the keys (ie enter, ctrl, alt, shift are all printed in all lowercase). I've never had another keyboard that used lowercase characters on those keys and I don't know why but something about it really bothers me. Also, on the number keys the position of the symbol and number are reversed compared to every other keyboard I've ever had. On most keyboards you have the @ symbol at the top of the key, and the 2 underneath it.. but this keyboard has the symbols below and the numbers on top. Again, this seems like a minor issue and probably wouldn't bother most people, but it really triggers me..

All in all, this is a well made keyboard with great key feel and relatively quiet switches, I would recommend it to most people but if you are a graphic design purist who gets frustrated by poor font choices and misaligned characters then you may want to look elsewhere.

reviews.title: Great weight and ergonomics, hope it lasts!
reviews.text:
I had the old RAT7 years ago and loved it but they had a notoriously high failure rate and Mad Catz went through a bankruptcy which made it impossible to get a warranty claim, even though my RAT7 only lasted a few months. I was pretty salty about this and probably would have never bought another Mad Catz product but when I got the opportunity to try out the new RAT8+ via the Amazon Vine program I knew I had to give them another shot.. and I'm glad I did because wow I forgot how much I love the RAT series shape and ergonomics.

I have been using the Logitech G502 which is an amazing mouse with a great feel out of the box but the customizability of the RAT8+ is just on another level, and once I get it tweaked to fit my hand just right I do prefer the RAT8 over the G502. One thing to note though is that the RAT series is pretty wide compared to many other mice and some people with small hands may not like it.

The 16000 dpi sensor is probably overkill for most uses (I play FPS games alot and run low sensitivity, typically 800dpi) but the sensor works well and I don't have anything negative to say about it. I don't use the RGB feature personally but its nice to have for those who like that kind of thing.

Overall, great mouse and highly recommended for those who are fans of the RAT series or anyone with medium/larger hands looking for a highly customizable mouse.. I'm hoping that after all the turmoil Mad Catz went through with the RAT5/7 series that they got their act together and made a reliable mouse that will last because I do love the RAT series!

reviews.title: Flashy accessory with a few minor issues
reviews.text:
This is a sleek looking headset stand / usb hub. The RGB lighting looks nice and works as expected, I didn't experience any issues with the v3 software that some other users mentioned so maybe they've finally fixed them.

There are a few minor issues that lead me to take off one star: First is the short cable. The cable for the USB hub is only 3 feet long. Unless you want to have your headset stand sitting on top or directly adjacent to your CPU tower then you are going to need a USB extender cable. I feel it should be minimum 6 feet in length..

The second issue is the fact that all 3 USB ports are on front. While this may be ideal if you are plugging in flash drives or some other temporary accessory, it looks sloppy if using it with things that have a cable and stay plugged in all the time, It would be imuch better if they had one port on front and 2 on the back or something.

Other than those two issues this is a great stand and sure to attract attention to your desk with the customizable RGB lighting.

reviews.title: Best wireless gaming headset but I still prefer my wired sets
reviews.text:
I'm a musician and audio geek, have been collecting high end headphones, amps, etc for 20+ years and have been playing PC games even longer than that. For the past few years I have been using the Sennheiser Game One headset with the GSX 1200 Pro amplifier as my gaming setup. While the Game One doesn't sound quite as good as some of my other high end headphones, it sounds amazing considering the price and is super comfortable with an excellent mic for voice chat. I have used a number of other wireless headsets and never been that impressed with any of them but I was excited to see what Sennheiser came up with. A good friend of mine has the Bowers & Wilkins PX gaming headset which is probably the closest competitor to the GSP670 in terms of sound quality for a wireless headset (and also in a similar price range), so I will include some comparisons to that headset also.

First off, I think it is worth pointing out that all wireless headsets make some concessions compared to wired ones, so you may want to keep that in mind when considering whether a wireless headset is appropriate for you. All wireless headsets have a degree of latency, this GSP 670 seeks to reduce the latency using the 2.4GHz dongle connection instead of bluetooth and it is notably better than others but there is still some latency. It seems that the headsets prioritize incoming data over outbound data, so the latency is much more noticable when using voice chat but I also notice it while playing FPS games (for instance when playing McCree in overwatch or using the Deagle in CSGO, both have a very sharp sound that makes the latency more apparent). For this reason I would not recommend any wireless headset if you intend to use it as your main headset for competitive FPS gaming. If you aren't super competitive though and you are the type of player who doesn't spend time worrying about your refresh rate and other peripherals input latency then it probably won't bother you.

Aside from the latency issue, all wireless headsets are heavier and less comfortable than wired ones due to the included batteries. While this usually isn't an issue for shorter gaming sessions, it can cause fatigue and discomfort if using the headphones for an extended period. Lastly, all wireless headsets tend to have a compressed sound due to the wireless transmission protocol which is most notable in the low frequencies. The best wireless headsets (such as this one from Sennheiser and the aforementioned B&W PX) do a lot to mitigate these issues but they still can't match a good wired headset. For that reason, I feel that wireless gaming headsets are generally best suited for situations where you are going to be sitting a good distance from the screen, ie gaming from the couch or something. If you are just sitting at your desk in closed proximity to the PC then it doesn't really make sense to use a wireless headset in my opinion.

If you've considered the drawbacks and still think a wireless headset is the way to go, then I would definitely consider the GSP 670 as it has arguably the best sound quality of any wireless gaming headset I have tried (after firmware update and some EQ tweaking). It has better bass response and to my ears a more balanced soundstage than the B&W px. While the GSP 670 wins in terms of sound quality and battery life, the PX is in my opinion much better looking and more comfortable than the GSP670.

I normally wouldn't comment on the aesthetics of headphones since I'm usually not planning to wear my expensive headphones outside the house.. but for a gaming headset it is perhaps noteworthy since some people wear them when streaming. The GSP series are without a doubt some of the ugliest headphones I've ever seen, and the 670 are even uglier than the others in GSP series since they are slightly wider due to the internal electronics for wireless. Unless you have a ridiculously wide head these are going to look really silly on you. Its very confusing considering that almost all of sennheisers other products have a very sleek and refined appearance, including the older Game One/Game Zero series. While I do prefer the sound of the GSP 670, I would feel like a fool wearing them on an airplane despite their good noise isolation, whereas the B&W px are much more travel friendly (and have better active noise cancellation).

So if I were in the market for a wireless gaming headset it would be a tough call.. the GSP 670 is slightly ahead in terms of sound quality, battery life, latency and mic quality but the B&W PX has better active noise cancellation, more portable, lighter and more comfortable and has a much more stylish and refined look. Personally I would probably go with the 670 since sound quality is most important to me but again it would be a tough call and I don't think you can really go wrong with either of them.. both are much better than the average wireless headsets on the market.

reviews.title: Understated looks but exceptional build quality
reviews.text:
Aside from the subtle metallic outlines around the buttons and pads, this looks like your average xbox controller but once you pick it up you can feel the difference right away. This controller is heavy, heavier than most wireless controllers yet it is perfectly balanced because the weight comes from the dual rumble motors instead of a single battery. The non-slip coating on the back has a great feel and is useful to prevent the controller slipping during intense gaming sessions.

The mappable pro-pack that slots into the back has 4 programmable triggers and can be super useful in certain games that require button combinations which are uncomfortable or non-intuitive.. simply remap the triggers to create an alternate way of performing the combo.

The included carrying case is very high quality and should offer great protection when travelling with the controller. Overall, this is a very well made controller.. it is a bit pricey but you get what you pay for in this case.

reviews.title: More than just a pretty Kitty
reviews.text:
The Kraken Kitty edition are undoubtedly the cutest high end headset out there. They are more than just cute though, they have excellent sound quality for both gaming and music, THX 7.1 spatial audio which is awesome in FPS shooters that support it, and some of the most comfortable earcups I've ever used on any headphones.. not to mention the chroma powered lighting effects.

The only downsides to these headphones are the short mic which doesn't seem to be as sensitive as the one on my Sennheiser headsets. The mic is still pretty good though and I do like how its fully retractable so it doesn't get in the way if you use an external mic. The other downside is that these have a USB connection only (due to the chroma lighting effects) so that limits their use to devices that have a USB port, it would have been nice if they included an adapter to standard 3.5mm audio jack

reviews.title: Finally a set of key caps that won't wear down
reviews.text:
I'm a software developer and gamer and have been using mechanical keyboards since the late 90's.. so I have quite a few of them. One problem that almost all of them have is fading of the letters on the key caps, which can happen rather quickly on the most frequently used keys. And in my case, I also play the guitar and have calluses on my left hand that wear the keys on that side down extremely quickly.. within a month or two on some keyboards.

Having worn down keys doesn't bother me *that* much really but it would be nice to have a set that doesn't wear down for once.. so I hope these PBT keycaps are as durable as they claim to be. I've only had them on for a week now so can't really speak to long term durability but they do seem well made.

I like the font and layout used on them much better than the default keys that came with my Razer blackwidow lite keyboard. The keycaps also seem to be more transparent than most default keycaps which looks cool with backlighting effects.

Like most razer products these keycaps are a bit pricey for what they are but probably worth the cost to me as long as they are durable. It is nice that they include numerous variants of several keys to fit various keyboards with US or UK layout

reviews.title: Works well on windows.. bit glitchy on Android
reviews.text:
I have several PowerA controllers for various systems and they generally make a good controller. This one is no exception, it is well made and thoughtfully designed.. it works flawlessly for me on PC with low latency but I have had some issues with it on Android. I'm not sure if the issues are due to my phone or glitchy Android drivers but there seems to be more latency when using BT on android and also get random disconnects. Most native Android games do not include controller support but it does work well with emulators (aside from the disconnects and slight latency)

Despite the issues using this on Android I still think this is a great controller since it works flawlessly on PC and has great battery life, hopefully I can get the android issue resolved either through drivers or system updates (my phone is low on resources and not running the latest version of Android, so its likely it could be an issue with my phone

reviews.title: Good keyboard for the price
reviews.text:
This FIODIO mechanical keyboard is similar to other budget mechanical keyboards such as Redragon and others. It uses the KRGD blue switches which are clicky similar to Cherry MX blue but these do have a bit different feel as they have a slightly longer overall travel and higher activation force than Cherry blue. (KRGD blue has 2.4mm travel and 60cN activation force compared to 2.0mm and 50cN for Cherry Blue switches). That won't make a noticable difference for most users.. but if you have been used to typing on a Cherry MX blue keyboard for a long time this one may feel slightly awkward to you at first. I installed spacers on mine to reduce the key travel a bit to make it more similar to Cherry switches that I'm used to. Overall the switches feel similar to Cherry in quality except for a slight bit of key wobble on the space and shift keys.

Note that this isn't an RGB keyboard, the switches have predefined colors and cannot change colors but you can change the pattern of lighting effects using predefined key combinations. I wish it were possible to change the colors but at this price point that is probably not feasible. One other minor qualm I have is that there are no markings on the keycaps to indicate the media key functions on the F-keys. Overall though this is a nice mechanical keyboard for the price and feels similar to pricier boards with Cherry switches.

reviews.title: Exactly what I needed
reviews.text:
I love these. I needed a new set of mic’d headphones for work from home calls and gaming, this fit the bill.
Features I like:
Comes with a little carrying bag
Comes with ear cup covers so if you don’t like the original leather ish ones, you can use the foam/cloth covers.
Long headphone cord with a remote to mute mic, increase/decrease mic and headphone volume.
The headphones have about a 2-2.5’ cord from the headset to the aux jack, and the extension portion contains the remote and converts to a usb input.

Things I dont like: the cord links easily. When I take them off, I have to lay them down in a very specific way to keep the cord from tangling. Something about the material feels like it wouldn’t be good if it linked. Also the headphone line does not disconnect from the headset, so if the audio line breaks, you’re SOL and would have to buy a whole new headset.

Mic seems to be good, way better than my previous headset. I like that it can be detached. The mic attachment bends / adjusts really well, much better than the headsets with the fixed straight mic

reviews.title: Exactly what we needed
reviews.text: After a night of gaming with friends, we all had to sit claw handed for a few until we got the feeling back into our hands. I bought these the next day. They are perfect for our needs and while I do wish there was a way for them to be a little bit bigger, they are still way more comfortable than trying to grip the tiny controller. My hands do still hurt afterwords (we play co-op games and when I get stressed I white knuckle) But nowhere near how much before we had these holders

reviews.title: Great for group play

We often have game nights were 2-6 of us take turns playing, and at least 3 of the people will saturate the original face shield thing with sweat--it's gross. And it never dries completely. This was our solution, and it works great.

It DOES make you hotter than the normal one, but it blocks out light better, and is super easy to wipe off so the next person isn't dealing with your sweat.

reviews.title: Fantastic

My husband uses his on an inset shelf next to his computer, mine is on my desk, and my brothers is on his ikea table--they are sturdy, and do the job. We didn't use the adhesive portion.

We've had our quest 2 for about a year and a half, and while it is amazing, the handles are super smooth so sometimes it feels like you'll drop them. We always wear the wrist straps, but we wanted something else.

These are a rugged rubbery-feeling material and as shown, have an opening to easily access the battery compartment. I love the weight these added to the controllers. I thought they were comfortable before, but the little extra weight feels really good to play with.

The controller seems solidly built and is very comfortable in the hand. It does have some weight to it, which you may or may not like (I don't mind).

reviews.text: This case is basic quality and kind of pricey for what you get. It does work OK. Lightweight shell with molded base and thin padding in the top keeps your game console and accessories protected and organized. The molded base is sewn into the case, so you cannot easily use the case for anything else. I would have given this case 5 stars if the price was $10 to $15, but I expect better quality for $30.

reviews.title: sturdy keyboard, lots of gaming features, great for productivity too
reviews.text:
This is a very nice keyboard for the price. My previous keyboard was a no-name mechanical keyboard that cost about the same as this one. The keys on this Razor keyboard are much smoother and robust. The spill-proof feature is bound to come in handy some day. The keyboard installed plug-and-play to my WIndows 10 desktop computer. There is a (200MB) driver that you can download from the Razor website to give you even more gaming macro and lighting features, but that isn't required to use the keyboard. You can control basic lighting and macro effects just from the keyboard without using the driver.

My only complaint is that the number and function keys on the keyboard have 2 rows of symbols on them, but only the top row is lit. The symbols on the number keys are unlit, so unless your memory is really good, you can't use them in the dark.

reviews.title: good quality 10 foot USB-C cable, fast for charging and fast for data
reviews.text: This is a good quality 10-foot-long USB-C cable. It feels sturdy and durable. Charging speed and data speed are both excellent, as I expect from USB3.2. The right-angle connector helps keep the cable out-of-the-way. No complaints. 5 stars.

reviews.title: good sound quality, USB-C adapter included, no League of Legends logos
reviews.text:
These are advertised as "League of Legends" earbuds, but other than one blue control button and the blue ear pieces (that no one can see when they are in your ears), there is nothing to indicate that these are associated with League of Legends. I like that the package includes a carrying case for the earbuds, but the carrying case is solid black and they missed a big opportunity to put a League of Legends logo on the carrying case.

Sound quality is as good as I would expect from $50 earbuds with crisp clear higher frequencies and somewhat boomy bass. They are definitely better than cheap earbuds, but you are paying $50 for these and should expect reasonably good sound quality.

The earpieces are basic silicone and come in 3 different sizes. There are no memory foam earpieces like some brands give you (and I prefer).

I like that they included a USB-C adapter since so many smartphones need that these days. The adapter works fine with my Google Pixel phone's USB-C jack.

reviews.title: red switches are very fast and quiet, great value-priced keyboard
reviews.text:
I got the red linear switch keyboard. The keys have a nice light and quiet action. Great for gaming as well as word processing and web surfing. The blue switches give you the noisy mechanical sound that no one else wants to be around. The keyboard has a very solid durable stable feel to it. I love that it is waterproof since I have killed more than one keyboard by spilling coffee on it.

This keyboard works plug-and-play out of the box. It has default function key shortcuts and basic lighting effects. For PC only (Windows 7 or later), you can download software from their website for more control over lighting, macros, and key mappings.

Overall, this is a great keyboard for the $55 price. It is almost as good as my last keyboard that cost almost twice as much.

reviews.title: good performance for a non-mechanical keyboard
reviews.text: This keyboard isn't as quiet as fast and clicky as a mechanical gaming keyboard, but the price is much cheaper, especially for name-brand keyboard. Build quality is solid. The keys have a comfortable and consistent amount of travel. Semi-compact size is great for travel or for working in confined spaces.

reviews.title: good quality USB-A to USB-C charging cable, no data connectivity
reviews.text: This cable is labeled "for PlayStation", but I don't know if that means anything special other than having a PlayStation logo printed on the cable. The cable appears to be a normal USB-A to USB-C charging-only cable. It can charge any USB-C device (including smartphone and laptops). It does not work for transferring data. They don't say what the maximum charging rate is, but I assume it can support whatever the PlayStation can support. It does not support USB Power Delivery fast charging. The cable seems to be well built with sturdy connectors and housing. If you shop around, I'm sure you can find similar quality cables without the PlayStation logo for half the price.
