reviews.title: Best back buttons for under 25 dollars
reviews.text: Playstation made a solid product, it adds a nice feature for a low price.

reviews.title: Exceeded Expectations!
reviews.text:
When Sony first announced the Move controller, I'm sure everyone was scratching their head with questions like: Why bother, Nintendo already has this covered? What's with the glowing ball? Why the camera?

Forgot all you've learned with the Nintendo Wii. I have the utmost respect for Nintendo for getting the motion control ball rolling, and I enjoy the Wii system for what it is, however, the motion control on the Wii is not all it's cut out to be. I'm sure like many of you, when you first got the Wii at launch, thought the motion sensor would track your every move. You couldn't wait to bowl, box, or swing a sword, just like you would do in a real environment. The sad truth is, all of the wiimote's movement which "talk" to these games could easily be accomplished on your couch - even laying down. A simple flick of the wrist would translate to an on screen action. No need to stand up and bowl, why bother doing a full arm swing of your sword when it can be done without much effort on your part. In 2009, Nintendo released the Motion Plus add on for the Wii mote which certainly make it a lot more accurate, but not enough games support it just yet, and it still doesn't come close to what Sony has done.

So what makes Sony's PS3 Move such a big deal? Well, for one thing, we're dealing with true 1:1 motion control. That funky glowing ball that was the brunt of many jokes happens to be the key to tracking your every moment; this, in combination with the PlayStation Eye. Once you begin to play any of the Move's games, you immediately sense you are not dealing with anything like the Wii. Not only does it sense anywhere in view your hand is, but it also detects how close or far you are to the TV.

Sports Champions is amazing. The Table Tennis is so realistic, it's almost eerie. All the sports included are a blast to play (well, except for the Frisbee thing which I don't find interesting even in real life). Unlike WiiSports or Resort - you WILL work up a sweat because you will not get anywhere trying to sit in a reclining chair while the PS3 reminds you that your not in range. ;-)

The other two games I've checked out were the EyePet and Start the Party. Both games use live camera feed, so now the player is inside the game! Yes, true augmented reality here folks. Your pretty illuminated PlayStation Move Controller, suddenly becomes another object. Just look at the screen, you're now holding a Paint Brush, a tennis racket, or Ray gun! Folks, you have to see this to believe this. Yes, combining the player with the game's objects and its surroundings is another thing the Wii can't acheive.

Overall, I'm so blown away by the Move's accuracy, The starting line up of games isn't much yet, but there's something for everyone and any choice will put a smile on your face. Plus, Sony and other manufacturers are already releasing patches to incorporate Move control into existing games like Resident Evil 5 Gold Edition, Tiger Woods 11 and much more. Oh, and loving the demo of "The Shoot" - can't wait for October. The system is very easy to set up -- and calibration is easy and super fast.

reviews.title: Ignore the journalists!
reviews.text:
I've very troubled by many gaming journalists and top reviewers for some of the major on-line gaming magazines. Apparently, Start the Party was not much of a game for them, It's as if they reviewed this with 16 year old Call of Duty fans in mind. Come on folks, lighten up and have some fun.

While Sports Champions is without a doubt the strongest launch title for the PS3 Move, there's no denying that Start the Party has plenty of charm and some kick-ass augmented reality effects. Matter of fact, it's the best "show off" game of the bunch. Yes, there are only so many mini games you will take part of before they get repeated, but there are difficulty settings and various modes to break things up. This is not the kind of game you lock yourself in a room with and play through out the night. You invite some friends/family in front of the large screen TV and laugh your butt off! I'm sorry, but watching yourself on live feed holding various in-game items is absolutely eye popping hilarious. The mini games are actually quite fun, and technically make any WarioWare micro game look fossilized. Both young and old will have a blast; the very young will be hypnotized by the visuals, and teens will probably have fun but won't dare admit it (the sorry state of adolescent males).

reviews.title: UN*BE*LEIVE*ABLE!
reviews.text:
I so wish it wasn't 2:47 in the morning, as it's late, and I am shot from an all nighter with friends and family playing Kinect. Amazon came through - and the Kinect came through even further. People people people, trust me and anyone else who owns it. Nothing, I mean nothing compares. Every once in a while the debut of new technology comes out which gives you that rush of excitement that you want so much to share it with the world. Every Kinect owner in forums, on Twitter, blogs, etc.. is flipping out over it; I know exactly what their feeling. I have a PS Move and a Wii. I thank Nintendo for starting the motion craze, I thank Sony for improving Wii's technology 10-fold with accuracy (I love PS Move) and I thank Microsoft for totally bringing gaming to a level like no other. Oh and some quick points:

- Lag - hardly noticeable a total non issue.
- Set up - easier then Wii if you can believe that.
- Space - we had 2 players at 6.5 feet and one at 5.5 feet all night. No prob!
- No detection problems, no voice command problems.
- Dance Central, Kinect Adventures, Kinect Sports & Kinectimals - a must!
- Sonic needs practice. Once you 'get it' it ROCKS - more complex then others. Some editors and reviewers should be kicked repeatedly for not giving it a chance. Must be a Sega vendetta for all the previous Sonics.
- The future: It's only going to get better in the hands of creative developers. I can only imagine what will come out of it. Give this baby a chance, and watch when they start combining control pad and Kinect for hybrid craziness too!

reviews.title: Be Patient - it Pays Off
reviews.text: Well, Sonic Free Riders starts off with this frustratingly long/annoying tutorial, and once you're past it, and hit a few rounds of "World Grand Prix" you BEGIN to get the movement down.  The first day of playing, my body was all over the place, trying to lean left & right way too hard and by habit, turning my body forward instead off to the side (like a skateboarder). The character was drifting way off course and I was just getting angrier". Well,  After a about the 3rd track in, the frustration began to dissipate, as I was able to nail a good deal of the controls,  which felt rewarding. Sonic feels more like a non-Kinect launch title - as it has more depth then the other titles. Yes, it's definitely true that sometimes, the game can be super finicky with your movement, but not enough to ruin the game like I originally thought.  Sega crammed a lot of moves in this game, so it's going to take practice, as this has a bit of a learning curve. I also like that it's the only debut game (I think) that has menu driven voice commands. Overall, thumbs up - but I would not recommended Sonic Free Riders to the casual gamer (lol - the irony).

reviews.title: Game of the YEAR(S)!
reviews.text:
I'm an adult..lets just say..well over 40, and I've seen and experienced just about everything in the computer and video game world. Of all my years of electronic playing, only two games kept my attention for years (no not days, months..years!): The RollerCoaster Tycoon series on the PC and Little Big Planet on PS3. Perhaps because I love anything which lets you use your creative skills and doesn't end via three day completion or quarter of the way boredom.

Little Big Planet 2 goes so way beyond the original to the point that, I don't think I ever want to play anything else - ever (well at least until part 3 is released lol). There is so much to do that you get your money's worth in a way that no other game can provide. It's a bit overwhelming at first: Do I play the brilliant Tutorials and collect all the goods? Should I explore the millions of Community Levels, or do I begin playing the epic story devised by Media Molecule. Perhaps I should design my moon, or earth, or just queue up a bunch of recommended levels for later play. And after all is said and done, there's still the core part of the game: Create Mode!

There's no end to the types of games you can build with this insanely epic sequel. The original Little Big Planet, paved the way with games which later went beyond the general theme. The original tool set was obviously designed with side scrolling platforming in mind, but creative individuals thought out of the box, and created games that you'd never thought could be accomplished. It was quite obvious creators had to go way beyond the limits of the tool set to come with something, other than what the game was intended for. I'm sure every creator hit a wall at some point and thought.... "If only Media Molecule would have included..."

Well folks, they DID! Little Big Planet 2 has more tools than your hardware store. Plus tons of new objects, materials, stickers, special effects, and more. With the crazy new power ups, you conjure up unbelievable ideas. One major break through is definitely the "Controllernator" which actually lets you map commands to the entire PS3 control pad. This revelation lets you create games in just about ever genre. The rage has just begun, and already we're seeing sports games, RPGS, puzzle action, adventure, retro games, casual, casino, 3D shooters, even cinematic movies! Not to mention, games specifically designed for versus multi-player which are identified by a special icon. Let's put it this way - many of the new creations will have you thinking you're playing a completely different game. With over 3 million levels, there is no end to this spectacle. Every day you venture into Little Big Planet 2 is a new experience. So, go ahead, jump in and choose anything your heart desires, or build your own epic arcade adventure. Rest assured, you will not be leaving this planet any time soon.

reviews.title: My Kinect has Blood on its Sensor!
reviews.text:
One Step Forward..

I have to agree with the higher critic scores on this one. Let me start by saying, this is a Kinect game like no other. The story is cliche, with over the top acting, but that never stopped the Resident Evil series from being loved to death. Besides, what's a campy horror flick without bad acting? Maybe we should inform some "professional reviewers" that this isn't Hamlet: The game.

Gross Fest Dead Ahead

The graphics are dark and foreboding, like they should be --- with shades of browns, rusts, gold and a ton of blood red; actually, make that a more than a ton. Rise of Nightmares seems like part Saw, part House on Haunted Hill(the awful remake) and a "rail-less" House of the Dead. There's even a creepy sprinkling of Silent Hill here and there, but don't expect any type of complex adventure which sets that series apart. The sounds are disturbing, with moans, groans, screams of torture, footsteps, clangs, electric shocks and much more, backed by a wonderfully eerie music selection.
The gore in RON is generally over the top, though there are a few scenes which I found disturbing, and as for being scary? Well, at moments it actually can be! Go ahead, play it at night on a big screen with the lights out; raise the volume and make sure you don't have on dark clothes so the sensor can find you in the darkness. Now, don't tell me you won't feel tense as you turn each corner. Not to mention, the game does have few jump scenes which were gladly welcomed. Perhaps those complaining about it not being scary should try not playing it with the sun shining into their room or at a dorm party with six drunk dudes.

Self Control

The controls seem to be an issue for some reviewers, yet according to the real audience, they're working out fine. Now and then, I had a bit of trouble backing up or turning - but for the most part, I've been plowing through this horror ride, kicking all sorts of zombie flat butt without a problem. If you're really stuck, you can use the auto icon by raising your right hand, allowing the game to walk for you. It won't help with encounters, but it aids in getting out of weird spots or when you're feeling disoriented. Your arm will tire quickly, which I feel is a good thing, otherwise, you'd be using it throughout the whole game..and come on, that's no fun! The game uses check points, which sometimes can be a hassle when you've just made it past the wall to wall buzz saws, or a unhealthy large party of the undead; luckily, most check points are not painfully spaced. As for saving the game as in, I've had enough for tonight, well, that's done at the end of each chapter, so be sure to complete an entire chapter before hitting the eject.

I'll trade you - my pocket knife for your machete.

There are lots of weapons to find which is part of the fun, especially when the more devastating weapons come in to play. When you find something like an ice tong or chainsaw, you can't help thinking - oh man, they are SO dead now...well, dead for good this time. Think about this... instead of pressing a button the conventional way, you mimic the motions of actually holding one of these babies. Trust me, it's very satisfying, but you didn't read that here. Sadly, weapons wear down with use, so you've got to find a new one soon or you'll be fighting with your hands and feet. Speaking of feet, I love how the Kinect senses your foot as you kick a zombie down while preparing to slice and dice. It also gives you a second to breath while other zombies are lunging at you.

Yeah, So?

Overall, I'm loving Rise of Nightmares, though admittedly, I'm more of a fan of subtle creepiness over gore. Sega's mature rated release is easily the most interactive on the Kinect yet, utilizing a host of clever, immersive gestures that help keep the game from feeling repetitive. Rise of Nightmares is what Kinect is all about, and hopefully, will pave the way to even grander scale games which will utilize this device in more innovative ways. Bravo for taking the risk, Sega!

reviews.title: If you own one, you'll know......
reviews.text:
As a gamer for many years (since the Atari 2600), I've experienced just about every form of entertainment technology, including today's high end tablets. A few months back, I was not even thinking about getting a Wii U. I saw the Gamepad and TV combination and thought, so what's the big deal about playing a game on the big screen, and having its map and inventory in your hand? And if you already have a tablet, then why bother playing Wii U games on the supplied Gamepad? Well, when you have one at home, it's a W H O L E different ball game.

When you first get the unit, you do have to be patient as the system updates to the latest OS. This process can take a few hours as the file is large. No one told you to sit there and look at the screen, yet Nintendo came under fire from the media because consumers actually had to wait an extra few hours before they can start playing? Imagine that? How dare they update the system to add new features? Grant it, those should have been included before the release, but this happens with various forms of tech these days, just not a long! If you're a parent setting this up for your kid(s), I would suggest doing it while they're asleep, unless they are one of those rare, patient gems (if so, pat yourself on the back).

The battery life on the GamePad is short - like three or four hours. I keep my charger cable nearby so I can still play while the pad is plugged in and charging , or periodically drop it on the cradle for a quick recharge while I take a break; It's really no hassle at all! It's not like you're taking it outside anyway. I have the screen brightness cranked at max which is visually pretty impressive by the way. It's no "Retina" display like an iPad, but it's still very sharp and a lot better than I expected!

MiiVerse is amazing - like a huge on-line community which is tied into every form of media on the Wiiu. Play a game, press a button, and switch to Miiverse to comment on it, or ask for tips! Then, jump right back to your game! Watch a YouTube video, and swap to Miiverse and you're in the YouTube discussion area. People can leave straight text messages, or use their stylus to hand write or DRAW a note; a lot of the sketch drawings submitted by users are amazing! MiiVerse alone is a very involving atmosphere that will keep you quite busy even without playing games. Sony's been trying to improve their similar social community known as "Home" for years, as for quite some time, it was not well received, yet, Nintendo's MiiVerse hits it out of the park at launch. The Browser for the WiiU is by far the best of the game console browsers - it's lightning fast, and works brilliantly to utilize both TV and GamePad. In addition, the GamePad can double as a TV/Cable Box remote which is ridiculously-easy to set up. Come December, Wii U owners will be able to download TVii which will turn your Wii U GamePad into an excellent TV companion, with visual programming guide displayed on the GamePad, including access to DVR controls.

I've only played three games so far: NintendoLand, ZombiU and an Nano Assault Neo. NintendoLand is packed with mini games for solo and group play. I'm not going to go into details, but there are so many layers of things to discover, that it reminds me of the original Nintendo days! When you begin to play NintendoLand and see how the various games interact with the GamePad, you can't help but getting that technology RUSH! Where you suddenly realize how brilliant this system is and begin to imagine what's in store! At that point, you're already looking for which game to buy next. You'll want to see what other games are like and how they work out with the GamePad. Most games can even be played directly on the GamePad, so if someone wants to use the TV, a quick finger touch switches the game to the small screen; All intact, full speed ahead! You've heard of console quality gaming on a small screen - well, this is LITERAL! I love how both displays can act independently, or show off the same information which you can flip between. The Gamepad even has surround sound and a headphone jack!

ZombiU is no doubt one of the scariest games you will ever experience. The atmosphere is so daunting, you'll be horrified to take the next step. The GamePad becomes your survival kit, with inventory manipulation, mapping via surveillance cameras a 360 degree, Augmented Reality-style scanner, and even voice navigation. There's a ton of functions UbiSoft intelligently incorporated into the GamePad. Trust me, you play one evening of this and you'll know you're in a different league then the 360 and PS3. I own both units, and I still adore them, but already, Wii U takes the top spot for me.

Nano Assault Neo the WiiU's answer to the PS3's lovely Super Stardust HD. Nano's environments are amazingly-detailed, as you blast away the enemies in this twin stick delight. The Wii U's GamePad becomes a live map showing the baddies swarming around, as well as locations of the game's currency to purchase upgrades. The acquired drones can be positioned and rotated for angle of fire right from your GamePad. It's polished, arcade goodness backed by a fantastic techno soundtrack. This was the first game I downloaded in the E-Shop. Next I'm going for Trine 2!

There is SO much more to elaborate on, as the WiiU has many other features to cover. After a few nights or learning the system, I've becomes more and more anxious to get home and play! I've come to realize, all the negativity that is getting spewed are from people who simply don't own the machine. These are haters of anything that they don't own themselves, plain and simple. Then there's the irresponsible journalists, who will induce head scratching as you wonder how they got their job. Many who have this need to fuel their articles with controversial quotes or useless top 10 ten this or 10 worst that ; they seem to get off finding even the most minute issues. Sure there are a few kinks for Nintendo to iron out, but it's only been out just over a week (as of this review). Remember when the 360 and PS3 launched? BOTH systems had haters and whiners, along with visions of doom and gloom. Heck, the 360 even survived one of the highest defective rates (Red Ring of Death anyone?), and still came out on top after a number of years.

Overall, I'm incredibly impressed and can't wait to see what the most creative developers do with the GamePad / TV combo. Plus, based on recent reports, this could be the Indi Game developers platform of choice which is a win-win situation!

reviews.title: + for Xbox One and Amazon & Microsoft
reviews.text:
I purchased this from an eBay member who secured a Day One Edition, which is why my review doesn't show as an Amazon verified purchase. The original buyer purchased it from Amazon back in June and had it delivered to me when I did a "Buy it Now" from Ebay. Well, it turns out, I was one of the unlucky ones with the infamous, faulty grinding drive; no games would load.I spent the first half of the evening mastering the voice commands, checking out game highlight uploads from the community, setting up the TV integration, and firing up a little Killer Instinct. Who knew, later in the evening this excitement would all come crashing down, when I tried to load up RYSE, only to discover my unit's disc player sounded like a paper shredder.

I didn't want to deal with Microsoft and its complications to send back, so I simply looked up the order number that the original buyer provided me with and thankfully I was able to return it to Amazon as a gift (since i wasn't the original purchaser). Amazon is shooting out a replacement immediately. THE BAD NEWS: It's going to be the "Standard" version, after paying a pretty penny (above list) for the Day One Edition. The reason why I'm not giving this a one star review (as angry as I am) is because the console is too amazing not to get the stars it deserves. I also have the PS4 and I have to say, I like them equally for different reasons. I will say,the Xbox One does feel a bit more next gen thanks to the TV integration and the new Kinect, which makes the old one seem like a disposable camera from the 90's.

Once you tweak the settings and spend a few hours learning the way of the console, you will have it at your demand using a pretty extensive library of voice commands. Yes, sometimes, I had to repeat myself, but for the most part, it works surprisingly well. As for gaming, there's not much I can do with a broken disc reader, but I'm already loving Killer Instinct with its insane, larger than life characters and sick amount of detail. It seems like the Xbox One can blast around graphics without breaking a sweat. The demo for Kinect Sports Rivas (the jet ski racing) looks like Wave Race on steroids with its gorgeous, vibrant visuals, and the level of control through the new Kinect is pretty impressive. I think having the new, advanced Kinect being standard will finally push motion control out of gimmickville and into welcomed arms. Oh, and dig into your apps and install this hidden gem called "Xbox Fitness". Gold members will be in for a big surprise with this compilation of free work out programs that go as far reading your heartbeat. There's some pretty extensive workouts here which read your body sort of Dance Central-style, and even includes achievements among other great features. I'm surprised Microsoft didn't emphasize this great set of extras. Overall, I'm very excited about the future of this console (and the PS4).

UPDATE: Got my replacement unit super fast (love love love you Amazon) and Microsoft is giving away a free XBOne game to all those who had a defective unit. Thank you for handling the situation very well, Microsoft.

UPDATE: As for the big name titles, so far, I've only played Ryse: Son of Rome and my jaw has dropped below sea level. I've never seen such amazing character models in my life. This is no FMV nonsesne either! I love the extensive fighting techniques and stats tree that can be increased as you progress. The story is intriguing (not historical, though), and the acting is top notch. Despite the mediocre reviews, I am SO SO glad I generally never listen to game journalists. I am enjoying this game immensely, and I love the way it ties in with SmartGlass support on my iPad. I've yet to play Dead Rising 3 and Forza - those are up next....

reviews.title: The Best Choice for Motion Control. PERIOD
reviews.text: I really hope Sony continues to support this peripheral. Personally, it's far superior to Nintendo's WiiMote and Microsoft's laggy Kinect (360). The software available is a lot more innovative then the above mentioned, and set up is a breeze. The accuracy of the Move is dead on and super responsive and I love the way games can superimpose an item (hammer, torch, you name it) over the Move Controller, so when you're looking at yourself on screen via Eye, it really does look like you're holding that object. For FPS, you can't beat it - - check out BioShock Infinite and you'll understand.  More support for this, Sony!

reviews.title: A Smashing Good Time for All Ages
reviews.text:
Just finished off the 2.0 Avengers campaign. I have to say, it was a total blast from start to finish (no pun intended). The character sculpts are wonderful, and in game, Iron Man and Thor are the two you're going to play with the most. The Black Widow is fast with hand to hand combat, but she just doesn't have the same impact as the other two heroes. I must admit, however, building up her skill levels results in some very cool dual handed bullet bursts. This makes her one deadly force in the Power Disc game, Escape from Klyn. In the main adventure, Black Widow's disadvantage is that she can't fly, so getting around New York City at decent pace requires a vehicle. Oh, they're readily available right from the start, but it kills the high energy flow when having to make pit stops to summon fast transportation. With Iron Man and Thor, you press a button, you levitate and another button sends you soaring at heart pumping speeds - - no wheels required. I can't comment on the other characters, as I haven't opened anything additional, but I'm getting ready to dive into Guardians of the Galaxy.

Yes, there are TONS of enemy frost creatures on the Loki side of the fence, so get use to fighting the same type of icy cold enemy over and over (with variations in their sizes and abilities). Also, like the 1.0 edition, missions can feel repetitive at times. This may bother some, but between the number of awesome moves, and the very welcomed Skill Tree, every fight felt like grand scale mayhem The insane abilities and special moves of your Super Hero are a sight to behold. Even the interaction with the surroundings is so well done. I also found the missions to be less frustrating then some of drawn out ones from 1.0 (except for Pirates which was my fav from that set).

There is so much to do with the starter set, that you really feel like you're getting your money's worth. You have the main campaign, plus the two power discs, each containing their own full game. These power disc-based games are of much smaller scale when compared to the main adventure, but believe me, both games are beefy enough to stand on their own. Interestingly enough, it appears there are two more games (as the menu shows) ready for when Brave and Stitch are released. Plus you have the official playsets that are sold separately ( Guardians of the Galaxy and Ultimate Superman).

Then of course, all roads lead to the beloved Toy Box where you can do just about anything. Avalanche studios packed in an insane amount of new toys, gadgets, interiors (now you can build indoors), landscapes, skyboxes and more. If you don't feel like you have the skills or time to build your own game, then download one of many offerings from the community. One of the best changes to the new 2.0 system is the way you obtain new objects from the Toy Box. Gone is that annoying, random "Wheel of Misfortune" style toy dispenser where you had to rely on luck to get the item you needed; now you simply purchase items with blue sparks which are easily earned throughout your adventures. No more spending your life backtracking through a completed game to try to find toys you may have missed. Not all items are readily available, but as you make a purchase, more goodies are unlocked through a branching system.

There are a number of other areas I didn't cover (hall of heroes / Super heroes, survival mode, the game-like tutorial, etc..), but overall, I say if you're a Marvel SH fan, this is the game you want. In fact, this makes the best use of the franchise yet! You may find yourself addicted enough to start collecting all the characters, even the 1.0 cast, who work perfectly in the 2.0 ToyBox (they too have stats now!). And in closing, I'm of many fans who have a feeling that the next in the series will be Star wars (2015). Talk about a new hope!

reviews.title: Ridiculously-Amazing
reviews.text:
(Purchased the Plush Edition which is why it's not showing as a Verified Purchase)

Sumo Digital has taken Media Molecule's masterpiece to a whole new level. Right from the start, you can see how much brilliance they've added to this game. The challenging campaign is simply off the charts this time around, with so much going on, in every delicious layer. Trust me when I say, if you're a fan of the series your jaw will be on the floor the entire time. The new, crazy weapons, inventory-style system and quest objective list really transforms this into an grand scale adventure. Forget just platforming, wait until you see how many RPGS the community comes up with this time! Not to mention, a whole new array of shooters, puzzle, pinball, sports, and other games which will exceed anything created with the previous version (and those were superb!).
Check out the campaign maps which will remind you of moving from level to level in a Mario World game. I also love the fact that the game is backward compatible with just about everything, including your already owned costumes and adventure packs.

The music .. seriously the best ever in the series. LBP 1 and 2 had their share of awesome tunes, but LBP 3 is a continuous treat to the ears. One level sports a brilliant Rock & Roll setting, which features licensed 50's-style music. I couldn't believe I was hearing "Mr. Sandman" while bouncing off walls (I'm old lol), and "I only have eyes for you" while drifting in and out of space. Oh, and don't even let me get started with Ziggurat, a Russian-themed level with an incredibly-kicking symphony (just found out it won awards). You will be blown away both visually and audibly.

Between the new characters, top down view, 16 layer depth and a monster load of new tools and other features (you'd need a book the size of War and Peace to list), you're going to be exploring and playing for a long time to come.

One of the main draws to the Little Big Planet series is collecting as many of the tools, stickers, costumes, goodies, etc.. as you can find along your journey. There are gamers who just want to play, and not get involved with the building aspect. They'll race through all main story levels either solo or co-op, however, this will cut down their time spent to complete the campaign. Luckily, they have thousands of community levels plus a number of official expansion packs to explore. If you're the creative type, and plan to build something of your own, you'll want to hit everywhere, including all the side games/missions. This will certainly make for one long, rewarding campaign. I've been playing for 10 hours and I'm just about to find the second new character. The joke of it is, I haven't even touched the community levels yet, which I expect to be mind boggling.

Almost forgot to mention (thank you edit) -- just like the former LBP's, there are numerous tutorial levels which introduce you to the main building tools/features, however, now it's called the "Popit Academy". This hybrid tutorial adventure combines learning how to use the tools while playing through a good number of brilliant levels. You see, there's lots of fun to be had beyond the campaign! You'll want to stick with it as you'll earn lots of valuable items to fill that goodie bag. Early tutorial levels may set off a bit of restlessness with those well trained in the land of LBP , but nevertheless, they'll be hooked. Not to mention, vets can also skip the academy and head to the database of tutorials to watch instructional videos for the newer and advanced features.

There are definitely a few quirks (as there are with most launch titles) that will surely be sewn up with patches (no pun). As I type this review, Sony has been doing a lot of behind the scenes maintenance as well.

LBP2 was the only game I continuously played on my PS3, long after other games developed cobwebs, and LBP3 is the main reason I purchased my PS4! You guys/gals at Sumo Digital are magicians! Oh, by the way, wait until you unleash "Oddsock".....

reviews.title: Garbage Worthy
reviews.text: Does not work with OS12, despite ramblings that it does. Loses Bluetooth Connection on an iPad Pro within 3 seconds. Went back to settings over a dozen times to find it disconnected. Updated firmware, same problem. Tried on 3 different games and only got a few buttons and directions to work, and all for seconds before it shut off. Awful product. I can't believe this was once a much higher price.

reviews.title: With all my Consoles and phones, THIS is the device I use them most
reviews.text: Not going to write an extensive review - as others have already covered that. Just wanted to mention that the 3DS is still one of the most cleverly designed pieces of hardware to date, and hasn't aged a bit in my opinion. The New 3DSXL line is just superb, with its large screens. Did someone day 2DS? Blahhh.. spend a bit more and get the REAL DEAL. Some people say they never use the 3D. I absolutely love it -- it makes the colors even stand out more. Most of the 3DS games are well thought out, and I find more fun than those same ol' post apocalypse FPS that high end consoles are drowning in. The SNES theme is kind of cool, but I actually purchased it because of the price and color (when opened I like that gray purple combo of the original SNES system).  I have a PS4 Pro and iPhone XS (plus a PS3, PS2 and 2 old Xbox 360), and the 3DS is what I game on most. There's nothing like a Nintendo product!

reviews.title: Goodbye Rift CV1 -  The S is the S#@!
reviews.text:
Let me start by saying, I've had every Oculus under the sun. From the various developer versions, to the Rift Consumer. Days before this review, I actually had the Quest! I was so excited, but in the end, I returned it for the Oculus S. Read on:

First off, I found the Quest to be way too uncomfortable.. The all in one tech, means it has more hardware packed into the front than you PC powered headset, making it front heavy. I've read every suggestion and watched every video on how best to make it wearable, but nothing worked. I figured, OK, it's a trade off - I have no cords attached, isn't that alone amazing? Well, turns out, not really. See, I started going on a "Quest" to compare games between my ol' Rift and the new kid on the block; I tried Rec Room first. The frame rate on the Quest seemed good enough, but wait, why are the signs on the walls a bit blurry, and their edges, jagged? Maybe it was always like that but I never noticed? I walked up closely, and now they were super sharp. So now I'm looking at the play panel and notice, not every adventure is available yet (they will be coming though). OK, I switch to my Rift, and load my Rec Room from the lovely Oculus Home (something the Quest doesn't have). First thing I noticed, the colors weren't as vibrant as on Quest, and yeah, there's that screen door effect which is more noticable. But hold on! All those same signs, from the same distance are not blurry or jagged? I realized, that's how they compensated on the Quest as it's not as powerful as a high end PC.

Now I switch to Robo Recall. On the Quest, it looks really good, but now what's this? Something doesn't feel right. The shooting just feels a bit off. The frame rate seems to struggle at certain points. I switch back to the Rift version, and now things are how I remembered - super fast and every action you pull off is instantaneous. Next up VR Chat. The Quest version looks good - the frame rate is not a problem. Someone informs me that not every avatar will show up on the Quest due to the hardware limitation. At this point, I've beginning to have second thoughts. I was planning to sell off my Rift and just stay Quest, but I feel the link cable may not be the answer, at least for me. I don't want any shortcomings, and I want my entire Steam Library to work as well as my Oculus Store games. My battery is beginning to get low... and so is my enthusiasm.

This is what made me decide on switching it out for an Oculus S. My laptop is a powerhouse, and it has a mini displayport, so I was set. Hook up was super simple. The S was instantly recognized, and my Oculus Home loaded up with all my previous purchases. The Screen... killer! Much sharper than the Rift. but the black level is not as black as the Quest (another beautiful screen), as the Quest uses OLED. I went back to the Rift, still plugged into my desktop computer. It seemed so washed out and almost blurry compared to the Rift S.

As for Rift S sound, it exactly like the Quest...firing out of the headband, and like zero bass. Good not terrible. The Rift's built in awesome headset will be missed. Still, I can always plug in my own, even better than old Rift headphones. Problem solved. As for comfortability.... perfect! Oh my goodness, it actually beats out the original Rift which I always considered the most comfortable (I also had the original Vive which was a head's worst enemy). The S uses the "Halo" system, similar to Playstation VR, but even more comfortable.

Yeah, I have one long cord attached to my headset, but I don't mind. If I kept the Quest and went for the link cable, I'll be back to where I started anyway. No sensors taking up space, and awesome full room+ scale. So now, I have all my Oculus Store games, along with my Steam VR purchases, without any sacrifices, limits or coming soons. I finally can put the original Rift up for sale. I'm super satisfied and quite blown away.

A final note: If your PC is now powerful enough, than the Quest is a no-brainer. It's an amazing accomplishment. If it's your first VR, and not coming from a high end PC experience to compare, you'll love it. If you have a high end gaming PC, then I would totally go for the Rift S, as you will get the whole nine yards, without compromise.

reviews.title: Great multipurpose headset at an amazing price point.
reviews.text: I play lots of videogames. I also do lots of studying. With these cleverly designed headsets, I don't feel the need to carry around two different headsets to do both. Buying the day they are perfect for my commute to listen to music. I store the mic part in my bag with my laptop for gaming after hours, where ever I may decide to go to. These are a chameleon. You can't even tell they are gaming headsets when the mic isn't in. The only down size is that it is super easy to loose the mic nub. I wished it came with a few replacements in the event that you do. The sound quality is great, while not completely sound canceling. I find this as a good thing since I can still be aware of my surroundings while I'm gaming in case someone calls my name or needs my attention.

reviews.title: Great for gaming long periods of time.
reviews.text: My nephews and I love playing games together when we get the chance, and my fingers are too big to easily hit the buttons. It always felt awkward, so I decided to get an actual controller. This fits the bill and works great. It's a nice color, and stores easily. Can't wait to buy more game in the future to play soon!

reviews.title: Feels very plasticy. Does the job.
reviews.text: These work well, but my only problem is the feel of it. The plastic is very thin, hollow and kind of flimsy looking. I don't expect this to last very long, especially with teenagers. I'll get a new one once this one breaks, but for now it does the job.

reviews.title: Pretty awesome for MMORPGS
reviews.text: I play a ton of MMORPGs and I have been on the hunt for a solid keyboard for a while after my keys from my gaming laptop started coming off. I have been using my laptop for college for years, so it was about time to get a new set up after graduating. This works great with my Razor mouse. It has very nice clicky keys with a nice spring back. The keyboard is solidly built, and surprisingly heavy despite being so thin. I personally like clicky keyboards since they tend to last longer, especially for games that use repetitive key strokes like MMOs use. For the price I feel it is fair, especially since a good gaming mouse costs around $100. My favorite feature are the side keys. They make setting macros for skills easier and within easy reach.

reviews.title: Great gaming headset!
reviews.text: This isn't second turtle beach headset, and it did not disappoint. my first headset,I've used for over 5 years and still is going strong, but I was looking for something with a detachable mic, as well as easier storage. This fit the bill in every way. The cups are very nice and squishy, while the tension against your head remains flexible. It don't hurt your ears over extended periods of wear unlike my old ones. It also self adjusts to fit all head sizes. I also love the metal band as it makes the set look so much sleeker. The ear cups and so swivel and lay flat for easy storage. Has a mute button on the controller.

reviews.title: Very nicely made!
reviews.text: I was surprised to find that this is a mostly metal keyboard. I got this as a gaming and working keyboard since my keyboard on my laptop is kinda broken. Works very well, even for just typing for assignments and other work related stuff. They keys are nicely placed for gaming especially if you play lots of MMOs like I do. I love that the keys light up so you can actually see the letters in dimmer light. You can also turn off the light if it's not your thing. I personally would just get they keyboard even if it didn't light up since it's genuinely just a good keyboard,..even without all the frills attached.

reviews.title: Super responsive and reliable
reviews.text: This is my third razor mouse. I have used them for the past 12+ years and they have been great. With every day use, they have lasted me at least 4 years of constant use. This is my second wired razor mouse. It is nicely contoured for comfort, and I love the side buttons for MMOs. Easy to create custom actions in game. I personally set one of my side buttons to 'auto-run' and it has made traveling longer distances so much easier. Great for working as well. I'm constantly doing work on my computer when I'm not playing games and this works just as well. Honestly one of the best mice on the market. Will be buying more razor mice in the future.

reviews.title: Great for worn keys
reviews.text: I love my nephews, but they can get really intense playing on my computer. Doesn't gelp they they tend to eat lots of greasy foods, and sticky drinks while gaming. I got this to protect my keys from wear..and I got it in pink to remind the boys who the computer belongs to. Haha. They snap right on and stay in place. the sides are transparent so you can still see the keys light up if you have one of those razor keyboards like I do. It also fits most standard keyboards. Overall, it's an easy solution to a common problem. If you use your keys very often and are starting to seek wear on your keys, I highly recommend this product.

reviews.title: Great sturdy gaming keyboard
reviews.text: I got this keyboard to replace my old one from college. I was surprised how heavy it is. The frame is metal. They keys light up and you can change the colors as well as brightness. You can also turn off the lights if you prefer. Feels very well made. Since it is so heavy, it stays in place while playing. The only down side to me personally is how loud the clicks are. If you don't mind the noise, I'd highly recommend it. Great for MMORPGs. The caps on the keyboard feel sturdy and very high quality. Overall, highly recommend it.

reviews.title: Hard time setting it up.
reviews.text: I have 5 other headsets, and this is by far the most difficult to set up. I use this to talk to team members on Discord for dungeons and according to my friends, the sound quality isn't as good as the older pair from Turtle Beach I was using. You have to configure your sound settings to work, and sadly for me, I couldn't get the mute button to work. The frame feels nice though. It is made of both metal and plastic components. The mic itself is removable. Overall, If you plan on using this for team based games, I recommend getting something else. PvE games are good with these. The sound quality is okay, and the volume control is easy to adjust. It's all a matter of preference in my opinion.

reviews.title: Very unique mouse
reviews.text: I have never seen a hollow gaming mouse before. It really is lighter than my normal mouse. I don't feel as if it is any different than any other gaming mouse. The hollow part looks cool, but it collects dust and dirt very easily. It is also a bit difficult to keep clean, especially if you hat at your desk like I do. I play MMORPGs and FPS games and it works well. I do like how it has limited buttons. It's comfortable to use for long periods. Overall, It's a nice mouse, if you can keep it clean.

reviews.title: this is not actually a game, but a case for a handheld device
reviews.text: My daughter saw this case and fell in love with it.  She had been using a cast off case of her brother's to store her ds.  She is very pleased to have her own case featuring "Princess Peach" who is a favorite Mario Brothers character.  The stars at he top of this review form ask "how much fun is this game" and "how do you rate this game overall" but it is not a game at all, but a zipped case made to hold a handheld Nintendo game.

reviews.title: just a hollow plastic shell
reviews.text: This is not a controller of any sort, but rather a plastic wheel shaped shell that the wii remote is supposed to fit inside.  My kids felt it was not a great tool and they prefer to use the wii without the device.

reviews.title: meh.
reviews.text: Poor game mechanics- it was hard to tell how to make things happen such as switching menus or moving. The storyline was that Smurfette was caught by the Naughties and befriended them. Her Smurf buddies attempt to rescue her and she has to choose which group to stay with. The player is a smurf who is trying to rescue Smurfette.

reviews.title: He has been raving about how great they feel
reviews.text: My husband has been playing online games for years and says these are the ONLY headphones he has ever used that properly fit his ears. He has been raving about how great they feel. The sound quality is excellent. Took only seconds to set up. Thank you Kingston!

reviews.title: works great!
reviews.text: The gamer in my household was initially alarmed to find a cord on this gaming mouse, but it is long enough that it has not been an issue. The mouse glides nicely and can be adjusted to different speeds. which is quite handy for gaming. A nice mouse for the active gamer in your life!

reviews.title: good quality case
reviews.text: This case seems durable and has slots to hold games for travel.

reviews.title: cute Mario theme
reviews.text: This controller works as expected and my kids like the cute Mario theme. The bright red color is different from all the other gaming system controllers we have had over the years.

reviews.title: seems to work well
reviews.text: This charging dock seems to work well. We have only had the SWITCH a short time though, so I can't say how it holds up over time.

reviews.title: works as expected
reviews.text: This nerf themed controller is cute and works exactly as expected. We have not had any issues with it.

reviews.title: no point
reviews.text: This set does NOT include electronic game controllers. It is just two plastic steering wheels that have a hole in the middle where standard Switch controllers can be inserted. They are purely decorative and not functional.

reviews.title: works as it should, looks cool!
reviews.text: This controller for the Nintendo Switch is made of transparent blue plastic. It's sort of fun. It works as expected with the Switch.

reviews.title: Still Playing This One
reviews.text:
UPDATE: Two Years Later My Son and I Both Revisit These Games Frequently ENough to Make This One of the Best Values Ever for a Pokemon Game

Original Review: I have been playing these games with my now-10-year-old son since he was three (I bought used GBCs and color pokemon games and let him figure it out - he also learned to read). Together, we have gone through the Gameboy Color, Gameboy Advance, the Sinnoh games, and Heart Gold/Soul Silver. I almost didn't buy a copy of Pokemon Black, because the games had been getting kind of stale for me. My son still loves them (as do his classmates - if you have a fourth grade boy on your gift list, and he doesn't already have this? You will be making a little boy ecstatic.

Anyway, my son really wanted me to play, and I gave in a bit reluctantly, but, now that I'm playing the game, I love this iteration for the following reasons:

1. I do not want to spoil the storyline, but the antagonists' issues and ethical positions are fairly sophisticated. Team Plasma is actually asking some interesting questions about trainers' relationships with their pokemon. Those questions also apply to our own relationships with other (real) creatures here in our world.

2. The smack-talk from rivals and other trainers is toned way down from generations past.

3. The game helps you along, which makes it much less frustrating (at least for me). For example, before each of the three gym battles I've done so far, you get an opportunity to get a pokemon who has a helpful type and a high enough level to ensure that you don't spend a ton of time fighting and re-fighting the same battles.

4. The graphics are really amazing for a handheld game, and the towns have lots to do besides gym battling, so your kid isn't likely to beat this game in a day and toss it aside. You get your money's worth.

5. There are new battle modes, new pokemon, new ways of interacting with friends in person and over the Wifi Connection. Nintendo also made Black and White just different enough from each other to make it worthwhile to purchase and play both.

I deducted one star because my game cartridge arrived glitchy. In the first battle, my pokemon, a female Oshawott could not execute any attacks. Every time I selected an attack, the game went to a screen describing the attack and showing my trainer statistics. I had to shut down the game and restart several times, all with the same result (except never again did I get a female starter), before I decided to try cleaning the cartridge, which worked (use a q-tip and rubbing alcohol gently to clean the game cartridge and let it dry completely). This is the first time since the Gameboy color games (which I bought used) that I have had a quality control issue with a pokemon game.

I recommend this game for kids who enjoy the anime and the other rpg and for adults who either want to play along with their children or enjoy gentle (mostly) nature/environmental-themed rpgs. It's fun and has good replay value for the money.

reviews.title: Excellent for older and/or mobility impaired adults
reviews.text:
I have SLE with mobility issues (inflammatory arthritis) and chronic fatigue, which puts me in a catch 22 situation of needing to exercise to keep from losing ground with both my mobility and my stamina, while having to fight an uphill battle just to get to the point that I CAN exercise. Going to a gym with any kind of regularity is out of the question. I used to be really active before I got sick, and I much prefer doing "something" to jogging on a trampoline or working through a list of exercises from my physical therapist. So I thought I would give this a try.

I love love love it. Unlike the Wii Fit game, your mii doesn't shame you over a one star performance (okay, I think that's funny, but your mother or your grandmother might not). Also, Just Dance makes it extremely easy to start from right where you are, mobility-wise. You can start sitting down, if you need to.

The game is also very flexible in terms of how you structure your sessions. You can use the Just Dance feature to browse through songs and move to what you like to hear or to learn the moves (which actually seems to be helping with my cognitive function) to the dance routines you like the best. If you're just looking to get in, get some cardio, and get out, you can go into the Just Sweat section and do that. You can even set weekly goals for yourself.

My favorite part about the game is that it is so low key and hassle free. You turn it on, and get right to whatever you want to do. When you are finished, it's fast and easy to shut the thing down. The songs are eclectic (some content might not be appropriate for young children), and replay value is high. I like it so much that I got Just Dance 4 for Wii U.

The only thing I don't like about it is that it doesn't always record your movement correctly or save your progress. It's no mean feat for me to hit my daily goal, so when I go back the next day after meeting my daily objective and the last dance I did didn't get its points saved, it's a bit of a disappointment. Not a super big deal, though. I'm not exactly getting graded or paid by the point : )

reviews.title: Harder than Just Dance 3 - Mobility Impaired Can Still Do, Though
reviews.text:
I'm playing this game with lupus and inflammatory arthritis. I can't do all the moves. I will never be able to do all the moves, but I have a really good time doing what I can. The Just Sweat mode is a lot harder than it was on Just Dance 3. Instead of being able to pick a goal and then pick your way through the songs you like, this one has you commit to an amount of time (up to 45 minutes, give or take) and pick a style (cheerleader, martial arts, salsa, etc.) and then it blasts you through alternating dance sessions and workout sessions (dance - kick box - dance - kick box - like that). It's more like a traditional work out video in that respect.

As for the Just Dance function, I have arthritis in my hips and spine, so, as I stated above, I cannot do all of the moves. But you can get through the Wii U version of this game without being able to do all of the steps as long as you can do a pretty good approximation of the arm stuff. And it's really fun, even for an old geezer like me.

My 12 year old son refuses to play it with me. He's pretty mortified at the very thought that I *dance* *at* *all* - so watching me do it isn't high on his to do list. He's also kind of a little rock snob, and this game does seem to have an even higher concentration of dance-y, disco-y new music than Just Dance 3 had, so I probably wouldn't recommend this as a gift for the little metalhead in your life - stick with Rock Band for that one. I still highly recommend it for anyone who needs to exercise but gets bored easily.

P.S. There's no training mode for this game and no way to back up in the middle of a song. If you want to practice/learn the steps, and you're slow like me, you can go to youtube and search for videos. Watch them and rewind to your heart's content. Then, pop in your game and head to town.

reviews.title: Waste of money
reviews.text: Dead spots, lags, and broken within three months.  Absolute junk.  Do not buy, not even with someone else's money.  Awful.

reviews.title: Still The Best
reviews.text:
I'm writing this review from the future.

Well, not really, but this is one of several classic games that, in 2014, is still worth buying and playing. While it is supposedly playable on most PS2s and some PS3s, do yourself a favor and pick up a good used PS1 from a reputable seller. The whole bundle of stuff will cost you less than most new games.

reviews.title: Worth the Money to My Kid
reviews.text: Works well and can be fun to play around with the cheats.  That is a direct quote from my son, who also says that the pokemon cheats can be especially useful, though there isn't a code for everything he would like to do.  Still a solid 5 stars from him.

reviews.title: Mario!
reviews.text:
NOTE: We did like this while it lasted, but it didn't last very long.

_________
This takes some getting used to. The mapping isn't the same as what you might be used to if, like this family, you are a big fan of the original gamecube controllers. The controller is also slightly bulkier than the gamecube controller.

However, this has zero latency and works great. Even though it's a little bit bigger than what my son and I are used to, we both thought it was very ergonomic. Also, having it plug into the wiimote, instead of the console, makes it a lot easier to use (again, NO latency - this is amazing).

The button layout may not be what you are accustomed to with brawl-type games, where your combinations happen quickly, but my son and I traded back and forth with this on a couple of platformers and cruised along just fine.

reviews.title: Love love love this
reviews.text:
This is a gorgeous game that requires a lot of thought and skill. My husband and I have been watching our son play through while an adult friend of ours also keeps us updated on her progress.

That's how much fun it is. You don't have to be playing to enjoy it. Getting a used copy can be tricky and expensive, but if you judge value by play/replay time, you get a lot for your money.

reviews.title: You will save money buying this
reviews.text:
This is necessary, according to my 14 year old, for playing Xenoblade Chronicles.

And, once again, the name brand controller is so much better than the knock offs that it is more than worth the extra money to skip the cheap knock offs.

We have had three knock offs die since Christmas at an average price of $9 each. All - and I mean all, from our N64 controllers on up - of our Nintendo branded controllers still work. Some are as old as my son.

reviews.title: Great Value Over the Ear Gaming/Skype Headset
reviews.text:
This is a very good quality gaming headset - excellent, in fact, for the price.

The headset is well-padded and still reasonably light weight. The padding is put on very well, unlike some over the ear headsets I have tested in this price range, These can be expected to last quite well through normal use. UPDATE: my 14 year old decided that he loves these. He sleeps with them on, and the padding is not peeling, and everything continues to function brilliantly.

Initially, I could not get the mic working in OS X Mavericks, but it did work in Yosemite. However, toggling the input preferences got the computer to recognize and use the headset.

The seller provided a review sample of this product. A year and a half later, my son is still using this.

reviews.title: Branded Nintendo is the way to go
reviews.text:
Always always always buy the branded ones.

You may think you will save money with a knock off. You won't. They all have problems with button action or they break. The japanese versions of the Nintendo controllers are often cheaper than US version, and they are every bit as good (they are the same). If you are looking for a bargain, that is as far as you should look.

reviews.title: Back for Charizard X
reviews.text:
I picked Pokemon Y when this generation was released, and I am still playing it. I'm here for Charizard X.

I'm also here to replay the story and side quests. I'm a late middle aged parent, and I've played pokemon from the Gameboy Color on up. This particular series has so much to do, and the IV checker makes the game a dream for people who like to hatch eggs.

reviews.title: Great Console - Would Buy Again
reviews.text: I haven't seen my son or my husband since Christmas morning. They've been playing the Uncharted series right through - each taking turns with the other and watching the whole time. We waited and saved a long time to get this console, and it has turned out to be totally worth it. The graphics are beautiful, and system performance is great - no long loading times.

reviews.title: Mature for Sure
reviews.text:
This is a Mom's review -

The M for mature is well deserved, but for a mature teenager, the dollar to fun/time spent ratio is excellent. My son is running this on an overclocked 5th gen Core i5 with a GTX 1050ti and 16gb ram and says it is snappy.

reviews.title: A typist's keyboard
reviews.text:
I recently bought the K70 for my son, and he and I both love it. When the K66, my first question was whether it was a better deal than the more expensive (by about 50% of the price of this one) K70. If that's what you are wondering, too, my answer is yes. Everything, from the cable to the material of the keyboard itself, is of better, more durable qualiity on the K70. It's metal where the 66 is plastic. The cable on the 70 is nearly twice as thick and wrapped in braided fabric, rather than plastic. The K70 also comes with special gaming keys and a tool to swap them in or out. My son is thrilled with the K70, and if what you want is primarily a gaming keyboard, I strongly suggest that one over this one.

However, that's far from the whole story on the K66. If you want to game sometimes, but also use your computer for working and/or writing, I like the K66 better. Its action is lighter and quieter. It's also faster. And, yes, it's plastic, but it is still super nice. I get tired trying to type on a laptop, especially if I have to enter numbers. The K66 is a dream for typing - much like the old Mac keyboards: fast, precise, with no ghosting. It doesn't come with a wrist rest, so you will need to buy one separately if you use one. Recommend for typing/light gaming. For heavy gaming, check out the K70.

reviews.title: Great for Older/Mobility-Challenged People
reviews.text:
My son's XBox 360 has a new lease on life. Basically, I am the landlord, though. He has moved on to a gaming PC, and this old console sits neglected in the living room. I thought about selling it, but I checked it out, and they're not selling for much. Neither are the games. I have lupus and recently experienced an uptick in my blood pressure. I can't go to the gym or walk very far. So, with the buyer's market, I decided to get a Kinect and some exercise. The game that comes with it is perfect for an older, mobility-challenged person. It got me moving just enough without feeling like I was going to fall or have to stop. There are breaks between levels (this is especially good if you are older - sustained cardio is not as good for us as it is for younger people - at least according to the emails I get from various web-info-mercials I have clicked on).

You don't need a lot of room to do the game, and much of it can be done in a chair. The only thing I want to do is figure out how to keep it from taking my picture. Yikes.

reviews.title: Recommend for Entry Level Console Gaming
reviews.text:
The Cloud Stinger Core is a fine entry level headset for console gaming. We also have a Cloud Core headset in the family. It's another entry level set with a slightly greater frequency range and slightly larger driver, but on a console, I cannot hear the difference, and the Stinger is more comfortable for me (smaller head). It's also more convenient to use the in-line volume control and mute.

Basically, the question is going to be whether you want pc-gaming and, if not, whether you want to pay an extra thirty bucks for slightly better sound and a removable mic. Really, if you are looking to spend more money, you can do a lot better by spending more than just the thirty bucks to get up to the Cloud Core.

I recommend this headset if you're looking for something inexpensive.

reviews.title: Very Nice
reviews.text:
This is a three to four star keyboard, depending on your price range. I love a solid mechanical keyboard for most applications. Even with arthritis and mobility issues in my hands, when I need accuracy, I need tactile feedback and no ghost presses ever. I have been using two corsairs. One is a k70 with cherry MX speed switches. I ended up giving it to my son, who plays a lot of PC games with it and loves it. The other is a k66 with cherry mx red switches. It's slower and louder than the k70, but it's also a lot less expensive and great for touch typing.

This G513 has a lot of features that make it nicer in some ways than the K70 - the memory foam wrist rest is really comfortable. The GX blue switches are faster and lighter (or it seems that way) than the mx cherry speed switches. They do not lack for tactile feedback, though, so I don't lose accuracy when I need it most. I let my son try gaming on it, and he liked it better than the k70. However, when I asked which he thought was the better value, he said the k70.

So, bottom line is that if you're a gaming enthusiast whose budget is limited, you may not need to go with this. I don't have experience with the really really expensive keyboards to tell you whether those are worth the money to, like, competitive gamers. But for someone who plays for fun, I think this one is worth the money if you have it. Otherwise, go for the k70.

reviews.title: Works with STEAM
reviews.text:
My son's previous adapter developed an issue that wouldn't let it work with Steam. VJoy was doing something that did not make his controller usable but that did "blow up" his mouse.

This controller adapter does not have that issue, or any other issue, and it works as intended and expected. Would buy again.

reviews.title: Not Really a Gaming Mouse?
reviews.text:
The form factor of this mouse is standard desktop mouse-type. While it is highly customizable, it doesn't give you the hand position of a good gaming mouse. In fact, the ergonomics are about the same as those of any mouse you get off the shelf.

The price point is higher than that of a good mid-range gaming mouse. I just don't really see this as a good choice for gaming.

However, it is excellent as a desktop mouse. The precision and customization make it really good for, of all things, financial software. I recommend it for that.

reviews.title: Depends on What You Like

reviews.title: A few issues but otherwise I like it

The Turtle Beach Ear Force ZLa Gaming Headset was a little too small for my son but it fit perfectly for me. The microphone picks up too much extraneous sounds so that was a little annoying.

But aside from those two issues, we liked the headset. Good cushion for the ears and good sound as well.

reviews.title: Ordered to be a back up but now is primary
reviews.text: Not long before I selected this item, I had gotten my son another wireless headset that is the recommended headset for his PS4. He really liked that one so the idea was to try this one out as a back up. Turns out the previously purchased headset is now the backup as he really likes this PDP one. The microphone is detached. The fit is just a bit tight but as he said, "I have a big head" but it is otherwise comfortable that he's gotten used to it. He likes the sound that comes through as well. Overall, he rates it as a 4.5 and definitely a brand he'll keep in mind.

reviews.title: Worth a look at a good price
reviews.text: I selected this item since my son has a PS4. He really liked another headset from Amazon so I thought I'd give this one a try. He does like this item. Sound is good; functionality is easy; and mic works as expected. For the price, it isn't a bad starter item, he said. Overall, it is worth a look especially for the price.

reviews.title: Pretty good product
reviews.text: I selected this item with my son in mind since he plays games. He liked the earphones just fine. They were comfortable and the sound was good. He is picky about mics in general and that was the case here. The mic isn't bad but it was a little iffy now and again. Overall though, he thought it was a pretty good product and rounded the stars up to 4.

reviews.title: Fun and entertaining
reviews.text: I feel a little goofy (in a good way) playing any Rock Band game, but this Rock Band Rivals Wireless Fender Jaguar Bundle is a fun way to stay away from twitter and such and reacquaint with music again. It was an easy set up (courtesy of my son) and while my son found the song list a little short, I though it was fine. The main thing is that it is fun and entertaining.

reviews.title: Fun activity for the young in the family
reviews.text: I decided to try this out because I need other ways to exercise but while it was a fun activity for me, I wasn't as into the songs available (old school gal here). That said, the young kids in the family enjoyed it a lot.

reviews.title: Kept the kids entertained
reviews.text: I had the version with just the guitar and I liked it okay but little did I know how much fun the young kids in the family would have with the drum set. I'm not sure how good the drum set actually works. It seems to be working as far as the kids are concerned and it is keeping them entertained and concentrated. That was my main interest in selecting this item so I'm happy with that. It does take up space in my small town-home so the guitar only version is my preferred version in the long run but this set does pack up well for storage. It is a nice variation of an indoor activity for the kids so I'm pretty happy with it.

reviews.title: Solid headset
reviews.text: The "Mad Catz Tritton ARK 100 Amplified Stereo Headset for Playstation 4" is working well so far. The sound is good; the cans are comfortable; and the mic is effective. About the only disappointment was that it needs AAA batteries but that can be worked with. Overall, it is a solid headset for use on the PS4.

reviews.title: Fun overall
reviews.text: There were aspects of Ubisoft's "For Honor" that was a lot of fun. The story is serviceable and the single-player game is short, but the online multi-player has its moment. It can get grindy and the store being so close to the menu makes it tempting to get around that grindiness so that was a little distracting, but overall, it was a fun game. It is not quite a 4 star but not really a 3 star either.

reviews.title: Solid good fun
reviews.text: UBI Soft's "Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands" has some flaws but overall, the game play and construct scratches the itch that has been missed since the days of playing Socom. At least to this one player. So it was easy to overlook the flaws and enjoy the aspects that worked. The mechanics were comfortable; the game play was solid; and overall, the experience was more than what was hoped. All in all, a great surprise of a game.

reviews.title: Worth it
reviews.text: I forgot how I got the first Playstation wireless headset but I remember my son being very impressed. So impressed, he ended up using it until it couldn't be used anymore. He eeked out the use of that headset until we could get another one. It took awhile to get this since every time I tried to order it, it was on backorder but patience is a virtue and once ordered, it came in good time. It works as expected which is a pretty high expectation. It isn't just the sound that is good; it is the fit. He's particular about the fit of headsets and this one is the most comfortable. A little outside the budget but definitely a worthwhile buy.

reviews.title: Mixed
reviews.text: Turtle Beach Stealth 700 Premium Wireless Surround Sound Gaming Headset for PlayStation 4 Pro and PlayStation 4 is a mixed bag. On the one hand, it is wireless, easy to connect/set up, and comfortable. On the other hand, the sound has a weird echo that is distracting. We've had other Turtle Beach items that we've liked so we'll continue to keep this brand in mind, but for this particular item, it didn't quite work as expected. It is okay but not up to expectations.

reviews.title: Now that it has been in use for awhile, we like it
reviews.text: I'm glad that I waited on reviewing the "Razer Cynosa Chroma - Multi-color RGB Gaming keyboard - Individually Backlit Keys - Spill-Resistant Durable Design" because when it was first put in, we nitpicked it. "Yeah, it is a keyboard and I needed a new keyboard and a keyboard is a keyboard is a keyboard" and "Why do I have to log into an account to adjust the backlights" and nitpicknitpicknitpick. Now that we've had it awhile, we really like it. We like the lights and being able to adjust. It is a nicer keyboard than the one that was replaced. It works well for gaming or for regular PC work. Overall, we like it now that we've had it in use.

reviews.title: I like it
reviews.text: I am on the 'wireless' train these days, but I do like this ROSEWILL Gaming Keyboard. It is a hybrid mechanical keyboard but while that's something that my son appreciates, I don't always notice the difference. However, I do like that the keys are removable. I like being able to remove keys to clean the keyboard. I had one keyboard that I could not remove the keys to clean. The wrist rest is a nice add too. This keyboard definitely has some points to it that make me enjoy using it.

reviews.title: Good fun for awhile
reviews.text: I selected "NBA 2K19 - PlayStation 4" by Take 2 Interactive for my son and his friends to try out. They found that it was good fun for awhile. They noted that it is pretty much the same game as prior edition so there aren't many surprises. That aspect gives a certain comfort level but also can lead to getting tired of it sooner rather than later if one likes challenges. So it depends on what the game player wants out of the game. Otherwise, it is a steady product and most who are familiar with the brand know what to expect.

reviews.title: Comfortable with good sound
reviews.text: This Picun Wireless Headphones 25 Hours Playtime Romantic LED Bluetooth Headphones has good sound and it is comfortable to wear. I like the rose gold color as it makes it easy to find. It also charges fairly quick and holds well too. It paired easily to the device that I wanted to use it with. It works exactly as I had hoped.

reviews.title: Consistent and comfortable
reviews.text: Avantree Bluetooth 5.0 Headset is a consistent and comfortable to use headset. As with most headsets, there is some finagling on settings that are needed to get the 'right' fit per user, but it was easy to get to that sweet spot. It is usually with the mic more than anything but we got that working where we like it. The fit is comfortable and it is easy to clean. The stand is also nice. Overall, it was worth the look and it is pleasant to use.

reviews.title: Works great
reviews.text: The ABKONCORE True 100% Anti-Ghosting Mechanical Keyboard K660 was selected for my son. He does gaming as well as work from home. He prefers mechanical keyboards because they just seem to work better for him. He likes this keyboard as it works a lot like his favorite keyboard from years ago. It feels good to use. The reaction time is solid. All in all, a great working keyboard.

reviews.title: Works quite well
reviews.text: I selected this HyperX Cloud II Wireless - Gaming Headset for my son to try out. He gave it a solid 4-star. It was easy to install and adjust to his liking. The microphone work greats. The sound quality is good. It is comfortable to wear. He's been using mostly for his PS4 but sometimes switches to his PC. He has a few quibbles but overall, he likes this headset as a good all-around performer.

reviews.title: Works great
reviews.text: I selected this wireless gaming headset at my son's request. He wanted to try it out because he changed out to a new PC. It worked right away. It connected via bluetooth without incident. It is comfortable. The sound is decent as is the mic. There are a few minor critiques but not enough to detract from the overall positive performance. For him, it works great.

reviews.title: Very Nice but Hard to Install
reviews.text:
I usually keep my 3DS in a plastic shell, but found out that removing the gadget out of the shell left a scratch or two, I was just horrified. I didn't want its beautiful purple exterior scratched more so I decided to buy this skin.

This was the first time I ever tried ordering this sort of gadget protection. After ogling at the prettiness of the box it came in, I buckled down and started aligning pieces. The instruction videos made it look so easy, I swear! The hardest part of the installation were the flat surfaces that angle down a bit at the edges. All I remembered was a lot of frustration, a lot of pressing slippery pieces into place and a lot of application fluid. Proly just a noob thing, but eventually I got the hang of it, how much fluid to spray on and all then, and the rest of the installation went smoothly. Not a perfect job on my end, but GOOD ENOUGH.

Proly took a few hours to do all this.

I still have a few pieces left as I only needed the exterior of my 3DS covered. I kinda futzed around with the pieces on the hinges, but what they said about imperfections was true, you can hardly notice bubbles, and residue when it's fully dried.

I love the feel of the plastic film, I can really say that my 3DS is fully protected now thanks to Skinomi :D

reviews.title: You get what you pay for!
reviews.text: It snaps neatly onto my 3ds, however after a few months of use, the hinges snapped off. I use my 3ds everyday so it could be from heavy abuse on the casing!

reviews.title: Cute artbook!

Although it IS small (just slightly bigger/longer than the CD), it is a great investment for those who couldnt afford the full collector's ed! And the artwork is gooorgeous!

Overall, it feels nice on my Switch and it's a fantastic purchase! Love the extras its comes with.

reviews.title: 6 months in.. an issue
reviews.text:
Edit to original review below

I've been using this keyboard for 6 months now and my letter M key will only show red. It will not show any other color. I realize this is minor and they keyboard still works fine, however, it's only been 6 months and things are already starting to not work. Makes me wonder how many of the lights won't work in another 6 months.

So - I'm not sure my gaming experience is any better, but I do really like this keyboard. I find the clacking of the switches really satisfying. The RGB colors are nice. Can't really tell any difference though in game performance vs a membrane keyboard.

reviews.title: This game isn't so much fun
reviews.text:
I've been playing the Fable series since it first came out. I still have yet to see what was hyped from the beginning. I found this game glitchy and the emote system is a huge leap backwards. I have to interact with each person 1 on 1 and can't do group emotes to win over crowds anymore. Each interaction is the same repetitive thing. I can either Dance or call them a Chicken!
