It’s a bit frustrating in our house and I could see this being even more disappointing for others (especially if they too didn’t know beforehand). Such as families with more than one kid wanting to play (we just have one child). For example, I was the first person to play the game and set up the island. I remembered seeing something about multiplayers so I later started to play with my daughter and looked up how to do so. We soon figured out that she could have a seperate profile and character but her character has to live on my island and share resources for collecting items and all. This means that certain functions, like naming the island and being in charge of certain things, won’t work for her. Also, we can play at the same time but this can potentially get frustrating since you have to take turns to do certain functions and requires switching back-and-forth between players to do the activity. The assigned leader can do things like sell or craft items, and the follower can only “stand” there and wait until they’re done. The follower can collect items at the same time as the leader but it won’t go into their inventory- instead it goes to a bin at a certain part of the island. They can go and get the items to add to their inventory but it requires going to that part of the island and toggling to become the leader to add the items. It all just makes things a little more time consuming, though it is still a bit fun to play together. For some people this may not even be an issue. For us, we have played Minecraft on Playstation together and assumed it would be set up like that-- you can play in one world at the same time but the screen is split which allows each player/character to go to different parts of the world, do different tasks and get different items...or even build something together. I personally would really like it if they would allow that to happen on Animal Crossing! Though, compared to Pocket Camp, it is cool to at least be on the same screen together instead of only being able to visit each other’s camps at seperate times.

TIME SPENT AND CHARACTER SETUP-
Note that this game is very time consuming! It goes by real-life time (at setup you’ll choose your time zone), so if it’s night time for you- it will be night time on your game. Being that it’s so time consuming, It may not be for everyone- understandably! It’s certainly getting me through this time, in real-life, with the pandemic going on and staying at home. You of course can stop playing at any point but to level-up and do different activities, it does take a good bit of time...and patience! While I did purchase this game for me, I occasionally let my 9 year old play and give her a certain amount of time to do so. She gets a bit impatient with it since there’s so many things to do and can take time to do so. Also, as mentioned above, she gets bummed that she can’t do certain functions since she was not the one that set-up the island. The set-up process is probably the longest. You start off with basically nothing and are to build up the island by collecting items and crafting. It can take a while to gather certain items. Also, you’re basically in tutorial mode for a long time (and likely throughout most levels). It takes a good bit of time listening/reading directions from the characters and learning the different buttons, how to move around and the various functions of items.

EXPENSES/EARNING: I'm about 8 days into New Horizons and so far I haven't come across any extra real-life expenses required, as Pocket Camp requires. Instead you earn/buy things by spending time playing the game doing various activities. You can also collect bells by selling items and finding bells in various locations.

NOOK PHONE: You get an in-game smartphone that tracks earnings, information, map, recipes...and allows you to call other characters/friends, etc. You get one right at the beginning/start-up process.

CRAFTING/BUYING ITEMS: There are different ways to obtain various items. There are DIY (do it yourself) recipes that you can earn, buy and receive from characters. They are cards that will list the materials that you will need to gather in order to craft the item. Then you will craft it at the “community” crafting table (or eventually make your own table). Unlike on Pocket Camp where you had to order something to be crafted (and sometimes wait up to days before it is ready), you get the item you craft right away. Though, sometimes when purchasing items you might have to wait for them. There are a few different ways to buy items. One way allows you to purchase, with bells, items like tools and get them instantly. Or you can order rotating items like clothing or furniture and get them in your mailbox the next day (in human real-life time). Also, as you advance in the game, other ways of purchasing become available- like vendors coming to the island to sell.

FORTUNE COOKIES- Unless they end up appearing on New Horizons at a later level than I’m at, so far there have been no signs of fortune cookies like those on Pocket Camp.There are prizes that come wrapped as a gift and floating through the sky on a balloon. You use a slingshot to pop the balloon and open your present. Sometimes it’s a material for crafting or a piece of furniture or clothing item. Those are fun! Plus, until April 12 they have a “Bunny Day” event that allows you to collect about 6 different types of eggs that are used to craft Bunny Day recipes (for furniture, outfits, housing materials,etc)

OVERALL: My only reason for not rating 5-stars is due to what I wrote above regarding issues with multiple players on one console. There are TONS more features to the game that I didn’t even cover. I love all the details of the game. As mentioned, I can only compare New Horizons to Pocket Camp but I personally love this one a lot more (though, I loved Pocket Camp too!). Be prepared to put a lot of time into it (especially to get your $ worth!) but if it’s your thing, it is worth it and a lot of fun.

reviews.title: Cute theme and coloring
reviews.text: Really cute for AC fans. Working as expected. Good quality

reviews.title: Works with the 2.0 update & DLC
reviews.text:
[[VIDEOID:32df6c3003a43a69812c1b54feec721e]] ⭐ 11/8/21 Update ⭐

Below is my original review but I want to update that she's still working and she can also be used in the 2.0 update to invite her to The Roost cafe. She comes to the cafe alone - some NPCs bring along family/other characters. I don't have her new Amiibo card, or any other Isabelle amiibos, so I'm not sure if she brings any other characters with those Amiibos.

DLC/ Happy Home Paradise: When I scan her to try to design a paradise home for her it recognizes that's it's Isabelle but it says "You cant connect with this VIP client yet" so I'm assuming I just haven't unlocked that level yet to design a home for her. ⭐ HOWEVER, when I've completed designing other animals homes and ask to take pictures in their home- it allows for scanning some amiibos into the house to take pictures- it works to scan Isabelle for this feature. I have a Lottie Amiibo so I took a picture of them in Cally's home and posted it on this review to see. It's a lot of fun 😊🥳

If and when I get to the point of being able to design Isabelle's home- using this Amiibo figure- I'll come back to update again!

----------------------------------------
5/2021 Original review:

This is my first time using an Amiibo figurine. I've used the cards for some villager characters but not for special characters, like Isabelle.

I especially wanted the figurine to keep on display and figured if it happened to work on for Harv's on ACNH (Animal Crossing New Horizons) then it would be a bonus. It does work to use at Harv's. 🔴 Note that you can't invite the special characters to the campsite 🔴 We have both Nintendo Switch and the Switch Lite and this Amiibo works on both consoles.

Easy to use, just like with the cards. You place it near the joystick when the Amiibo symbol is on the screen and she pops right on the screen. 🔴 Also note that you can't change her clothes at Photopia/Harv's, you can only change her reactions and move her to different spots.

Once she appears there at Harv's, her poster is automatically ready to order on the Nook Shopping app- either from your Nook phone or at the ABD back at Resident Services. Like the other posters, it's 1,000 bells to buy it and it will arrive in your mailbox the next day.

The figurine is super cute and in great condition. The box was in great shape, as well!

reviews.title: Cute! 😍 Though, a couple issues...
reviews.text:
Reese, Cyrus and K.K. all came in great condition. Blathers and Tom came out of a box, which I knew before hand that they would, but they each have minor scuff marks so that's a little disappointing but I knew I was taking a bit of a risk with ordering these...and it's honestly not bad scuffing.

I wanted them to display as figures and to be able to scan at Harv's Island/Photopia on ACNH (Animal Crossing New Horizons). Each one scanned...nearly all scan quickly except for Reese, which first said there was no Amiibo found but every other time it has worked...though, I have to hold it longer than the others and in the same exact spot on the right joystick...the others aren't like that.

As long as Reese still at least scans, I'll keep my rating at 4-stars- if any further mess-ups happen, I'll update to make the rating lower.

Also, in case you were wondering, all of these characters, and the other special character Amiibos, are not able to be dressed-up/changed at Harv's. You can change their reactions and take pictures and then once they're scanned, it automatically becomes available to order the character's poster through Nook shopping. Also, K.K. doesn't have his guitar when scanned, so I personally feel he looks very different without it lol

All-in-all, other than the issues mentioned above, I love these. They're really cute and fun for AC fans 😍🙌🏼

reviews.title: Work great for 2.0 ACNH update
reviews.text:
Each work well.

As far as special characters: C.J. is the one that I got. When playing Happy Home Paradise (the new ACNH DLC), I'm not yet at a level where I can design his Paradise home but I can make him appear in other animal's paradise dream homes to take pictures once I've finished designing it- which is a lot of fun. It also works to call him into The Roost cafe and to take pictures at Harv's photography studio. This works with other special character amiibos that I've tried, as well.

The rest of the animal amiibos in this pack also work with all of the functions that C.J. is able to do- as mentioned above- plus they can also be called to your own island's campsite to become one of your villagers.

Loving this pack and the new characters! If you're interested in who I got in his pack, I posted pictures but also will list the names below:

C.J.
Chabwick
Cephalobot
Ace
Cyd
Roswell

reviews.title: Pretty and functional 😍
reviews.text: We're loving this controller, so far! It looks really pretty plus it has the fun and pretty lights on it 😍 It will need to be charged for a bit before using...our first use, we charged it until it had enough power to be used while charging. I want to say it was under 10 minutes to do so. It feels of good quality - sturdy, durable, functions well and looks nice!

reviews.title: hours of playing
reviews.text: i did fish tycoon a year ago on my pc and spent hours and hours doing it.  i was thrilled to see it for my ds.  if you like games like this, you will love it.  you have to find the 7 magic fish and in the meantime, breed, heal, sell fish and also buy equipment for your aquariums.  you can stop time if you go away a long time or you can speed up time so everything goes faster.  once you find a breed of fish that sells for some bucks, just keep breeding it over and over and you will get money to buy the special eggs, the potions and equipment.  then it makes it easier to find the magic fish.  i just finished plant tycoon on my pc and hope ds comes out with the game for it.  fish tycoon is a game where you need to spend some time breeding and making your sick fish well and upgrading your equipment.  once you get the hang of it, you will not be able to put it down.  a great game for everyone but especially older folks (over the age of 12 lol).  some fish are very very pretty and  unusual looking and it is fun to breed different ones just to see what you get.  sometimes, you will get one of the magic fish !  good luck

reviews.title: i am not smarter than a fifth grader
reviews.text: this game is just like the tv show, without the commercials.  i am surprised at how much i DON'T know !  my hubby thought for sure the tv show was fixed because he said "who couldn't answer 5th grade questions?!"  well, he has only made it to the 1 million dollar question one time and that was using his 3 cheats.  it is a great game to play just to see how much you remember.  it is also great if you have those know-it-all friends, you can test them.  great game

reviews.title: crazy fun !
reviews.text: this game will give you crazy fun !  it's siimple and passes the time.  i especially love alley ball, and the milk bottle toss.  if you are looking for a game to pick up and play for a few minutes this would be it.  i don't think this will keep you occupied for hours because there are just so many games on there and once you have played them all like 100 times, you will get bored.  i have unlocked all but one item and i discovered all the little secret things walking around the park but i find myself picking this up when i have a few minutes to pass time.  i am an adult gamer and shorter attention span than most, i get bored VERY easily.  get this game if you loved those carnival games as a kid...it might just bring back some memories.  overall this is a great game and in fact, i have ordered 2 more for friends for christmas.  have a great time at the carnival !

reviews.title: will keep you busy for a while
reviews.text: i am still playing this game.  i just play the mini games now.  i went through the whole game in a matter of hours and it was fun.  although it is repetitive, it is fine for those of you (and me) that just want a quick game.  my favorite is the jigsaw puzzles and you can play about 10 games in 5 minutes.  it's hard to keep my attention on something, so i play a few minutes a day and i am satisfied.  if you want a long game, this is not the one for you.  this is very easy and entertaining.

reviews.title: surprisingly fun
reviews.text:
I got this game based on the other review and I am glad I did. At first, I thought it was going to be real simple, you know, like the childs toy. Boy, was I wrong. It gets pretty advanced and is very challenging. I am up to a level now that I can't even get through the beginning of it but I take it as a challenge and I like it.
It is like the childs toy, where you fit the shaped blocks through the holes but in this game, they come flying at you and you have to fit them pretty fast by turning the base. It's pretty straightforward. I am having a problem with one thing in the game and I can't seem to find out anything in the book so I am going to look on the internet but besides that, everything is self explainatory. If you like a straight forward game, that is challenging, this is it.

reviews.title: great game
reviews.text:
i really love this game. it's interesting and i already played it two times.
the mini games are alot of fun.
the hidden object scenes are not too hard, but not too easy.
there are hints also.
you can actually skip the minigames too.

i really like this game and i have ordered a bunch lately. this one is a keeper and it does have the replay factor.

reviews.title: need help
reviews.text:
I love this game but i have a problem and was wondering if any of you experts out there can help me.
i got through the game and when i get to the coffin at the end, it says the spirit is free and then the game ends. i cannot get to the final puzzle. so i played it AGAIN and just about 10 minutes ago, i got to the same point and as soon as it says the spirit is free, it ends.

i think there is another puzzle. i have read there is an elaborate puzzle but i can't seem to find it.
can someone please tell me what i am doing wrong? i am starting it AGAIN and hoping by the time i get to the end, one of you will answer me.

as for a review, it's a great game except for the above in my case.
it's easy enough but challenging. the minigames are fun too.

please help !!!

reviews.title: love it
reviews.text:
I love these types of games, more than just pointing and clicking. There are actual tasks that need to be done. This reminds me of Mortimer Beckett and the Lost King. That is another great game you can download from Amazon.
This game is longer than usual, the graphics are great and I really enjoyed it. It is well worth the price and I am getting ready to play it again.

If you like this game, Mortimer is great, Flux Family Secrets and Magic Encyclopedia are wonderful games too. I got all mine from Amazon and they are more than the boring just point and click hidden object games. I think I own most of them or tried most of them and there are only a few that I am really crazy about. I also loved Murder She Wrote and Mushroom Age. Give them a try. You can always do teh free trial. I love Amazon because you can delete them from the computer and they will keep your bought games in their library. Perfect !

reviews.title: will do as an extra
reviews.text: My son is the perfect one to review this since I don't play games on this type of platform.  He said the big drawback is it's not wireless but it will do as an extra.  Compared to his other control pads, this one feels cheap and light and he said when he was using it, it was so light that it just felt strange.  The buttons are very very sensitive.  My son likes to slam the buttons (his words) and this only requires a very light touch and he just can't get used to it.  He played with it about an hour and one of the buttons stuck down.  He said this wouldn't be his first or second choice but it will do in a pinch if his other controllers break.  He said he wouldn't pay alot of money for ths and he would not recommend for gamers that are really into the games.

reviews.title: Beautiful scenery, fun game
reviews.text: I am a fan of hidden object games generally, and I love this one.  This was the first hidden object game to give the player a 360 view, which means that you can spin around within the scene and see all parts of it, from the ground to the sky.  The storyline for the game is a Paris vacation, and in the game you get to travel around to all sorts of famous and beautiful locations, from various level of the Eiffel Tower to parks, churches, and a country mansion.  The objects are actually hidden in remastered photos of real Paris locations, so the scenery is beautiful. Do watch out when you're moving around a scene, as the picture scrolls, and if I look at it head on when moving it can produce motion sickness.  But honestly, that's not such a big deal: just look down or to the side when you scroll.  This game is lots of fun, and it's fun to replay.  This is a good game for all ages, from elementary school up to adults.

reviews.title: Where it all started
reviews.text: Mystery Case Files Huntsville- it's the first game in the Mystery Case Files series, and the one that created the popular Hidden Object genre.  The storyline for this game places you as a detective, trying to solve the case of the missing diamond from the Huntsville museum.  You investigate a variety of locations by looking for hidden objects.  Each location reveals a new troublemaker, and all of them seem to belong to the same crime ring.  At the end of the game you uncover the mastermind, and discover who's really behind the diamond theft.  There are many good points to this game- the storyline is a good one, and the game definitely makes you want to get to the end so that you can solve the whodunnit.  Huntsville is full of a variety of entertaining criminals who, you'll discover through the levels, seem to engage is some bizarre crimes.  Perhaps most importantly, the pictures in this game are VERY well done.  They're complex, they're funny, and the objects are well integrated into the picture- they're not just plonked on top of a background scene.  As this was the first Mystery Case files game, it's also the easiest.  If you're new to the hidden object genre or looking for a good kid's game, this is a great place to start, but it's also engaging and difficult enough that it should please everyone.  Highly recommended.

reviews.title: Okay, not fantastic
reviews.text: The title of this review pretty much says it all.  This is a perfectly acceptable computer game- fun enough to play, but certainly not addictive.  This is the Clue board game put on screen- you move your piece around the board, role dice, make accusations, etc.  The drawings in the game (of the characters, rooms, etc.) are excellent, but there's really not much more excitement than the board game offers.  Actually, I find it less exciting than the board game because with the board game, you have other people to add to the atmosphere.  This is just you and the computer.

reviews.title: Great Farm Game
reviews.text: For those who enjoy time management games, especially those on a farm setting, this game has great things to offer.  It offers a variety of tasks to manage (feeding animals, harvesting crops, keeping out pests, among others), and offers enough variety in those tasks that it never gets boring.  You're not just doing the same thing on each level.  Interspersed are a few hidden object levels.  With high-quality graphics, cute animals, lush farm scenery, this is a great time management game- it has lots of levels and I highly recommend it.

reviews.title: Something Different
reviews.text: With the variety of hidden object games on the market, many of which are copycats, I'm looking for something a bit different in hidden object games these days.  And Pure Hidden provies that something different.  Through a series of hidden object and puzzle levels, players interact with scenes that are works of art.  With a clear Asian influence, many of the scenes contain Asian objects, or works of Asian art.  It's hard to adequately describe the scenes and objects presented, but I strongly recommend everyone who enjoys hidden object games try at least the free trial.  This really is not your stock hidden object game.

reviews.title: The Bad with the Good
reviews.text:
This is one of the newer Nancy Drew games, and there's both good and bad to it. I'll start with the good: the atmosphere of this game is great- very creepy. An old Irish castle after dark is bound to be spooky, and indeed it is. The graphics when inside the castle are also fantastic- high resolution, lots of detail. You really feel like you're in the castle. Part of the castle has been blown up, and it was never really clear why someone was staying in a room with half the roof missing, but we'll hold that thought until we get to the plot. Other pluses of this game- it's a fairly long game to get through, and some of the puzzles were quite challenging.

On to the negatives: the most important one is the plot. Quite simply, there isn't much plot- Nancy is searching for her friend's missing fiance, but beyond that, we get little plot development. On the same note, I found the ending to be quite unsatisfactory. I don't want to give anything away, so I won't go into to detail, and will just say that the ending severely interfered with my enjoyment of the castle's atmosphere. Also, I was unhappy with the outdoor navigation in this game. Outside the castle the player controls Nancy from above, meaning that the graphics are quite simplistic, and it's more like an arcade game than a mystery. I much prefer to see the game through Nancy's eyes. In sum, Nancy Drew addicts will definitely want to play this game, and there are certainly things to recommend here, but it's not one of the better Nancy Drew games. The first third of the game is decidedly the best part, and then it starts to go downhill.

reviews.title: Not a long game, but fun
reviews.text: The first in the Mortimer Beckett series, this hidden object game has Mortimer, a delightfully bespectacled young man, searching through his family's creepy old house, looking for pieces of the ghost machine.  Along the way he encounters a variety of amusing spirits.  Gameplay consists of finding the pieces of hidden objects (which have been broken up) until one has a complete object that then must be either put back in its place, or used to complete a task.  Artwork on this game is fantastic, and finding pieces of objects, rather than the objects themselves, adds to the challenge, and makes the game a bit more unusual.  My one complaint is the length of the game, which is rather short- I finished in less than two hours.

reviews.title: This is a tough one!
reviews.text: The second in the series, Magician's Handbook II proves to offer a significant challenge to hidden object lovers.  The objects are tough to find- this is a game that takes some time and some skill.  Hidden object lovers who find other games too easy will likely not be disappointed by this one- those who find other games too difficult will likely want to choose something else.  This game offers amazing artwork, very detailed scenes, lots of gameplay and lots of challenge.  Well worth it.

reviews.title: Longer gameplay and harder puzzles
reviews.text: I enjoyed the first Mortimer Beckett, and was definitely looking forward to the new one.  I was not at all disappointed.  This MB has the player travelling through time, seeking out the pieces of objects that will complete puzzles necessary to advance to the next level.  The graphics on this game are truly fantastic.  We go with Mortimer throughout time- to ancient Egypt, Camelot, a robot lab in the future, and many more.  The puzzles are harder than those in the first game, and the game was longer than the first.  Those who loved the first MB, or those who enjoy hidden object games generally should definitely try out this game.

reviews.title: Cute
reviews.text: Really, the best way I can describe this game is cute.  The planes are adorable.  They make cute noises, and they have cute facial expressions.  Gameplay is pretty typical Diner-Dash style- you need to land the planes, get them unloaded, loaded, and add gas and repairs if needed.  Colormatching and repetition of tasks give you bonus points.  What really sets this game apart is the fact that it's so ridiculously cute.  This was a rather long game, but it did get a bit repetitive.

reviews.title: Great Mix of Humor and Hidden Objects
reviews.text: The MCF games are always high-quality, and this one is no exception.  It has excellent artwork, and objects are well-integrated into the scenes without being completely obscure.  In this game you act as an investigator trying to figure out who stole the diamond.  You investigate 20-odd suspects- and here's where we get to see some humor.  These suspects are all rather shady characters, humorously drawn, who fit into some amusing stereotypes without being offensive (think the stage diva who can't sing, the kind of shady carnival worker, the stay-at-home mom who has a side job as a bank robber).  As you investigate each character you'll find out if they have an alibi or not.  At the end of the game, you solve a final puzzle to determine which of the five is guilty.  This changes each time you play, preserving replay value.  This game is now several years old, but I remember when it came out it was leaps and bounds ahead of its time.

reviews.title: Stepping Up the Difficulty
reviews.text: This is the fourth installment in the Mystery Case Files Series, and with it, the developers have definitely stepped up the difficulty too.  I've always found these games to be trememous value for money- they have lots of levels of play, great artwork, and the story usually keeps me engaged until the end.  Certainly the length and the fantastic artwork hold true here.  Added to the standard hidden object levels are several twists: there are secret shape-shifting objects to be found in each location, and each level ends with a fairly complicated puzzle (again, with tremendous production values).  These puzzles can be quite difficult, and I would definitely have appreciated a skip puzzle button at times, but help can be found online for those having trouble.  The one place where I found this game to not live up to earlier editions was in the storyline- it's suitably scary, but unlike, say, Prime Suspects in which you build up a list of suspects as you go, in this game you just seem to eliminate them (quite literally!) one by one.  That said, the ending is surprising, and with the more difficult hidden object scenes I still give this one a "5" even with the issues mentioned.

reviews.title: Repetitive
reviews.text: This hidden object game has a promising concept: you're called in to investigate the apparant haunting of a spooky old house, Majesty Manor.  So, you set about exploring the house to investigate each suspect by finding hidden objects.  The suspects are quite a group: family and friends, employees of the manor, neighbors, both alive and dead might be responsible.  Definitely a good concept, but this game gets repetitive quickly.  With 15 levels exploring the same rooms and doing nothing but finding objects, one can tire of the game quickly (which I did).  This was one of those "fun for the first hour, but after that it's questionable" sort of games.

reviews.title: One of the Easier Nancy Drew Games
reviews.text: I'm a big fan of Nancy Drew games, and The Secret of the Old Clock is a bit different from some of others.  This is the only Nancy Drew game that takes place in the past- in the 1930s.  It's also probably the easiest of the Nancy Drew games I've played.  Nancy undertakes to help her orphaned friend Emily, who has inherited her mother's inn, and fallen into a deep state of melancholy.  The inn has been experiencing strange accidents, and it's up to Nancy to figure them out.  The puzzles in this game were a bit easier than the standard Nancy Drew fare.  Also, there weren't as many locations to investigate as some other ND games.  In particular, there's very little to do in the inn, and one of the things ND games do so well is to set up spooky, old, searchable houses.  That said, the game is still fun, and this is a great ND game to start with, if one is new to the genre.

reviews.title: Much Like the First, but Still Fun
reviews.text: I really enjoyed the first Lost Cases of Sherlock Holmes, so I bought the second one as soon as it was released.  I was not disappointed, and I enjoyed this game just as much as the first.  The gameplay and style are exactly the same as the first game, but the sequel offers new cases.  For those unfamiliar with the series, this is primarily a hidden object game, punctuated by logic-style puzzles at the end of each chapter.  The game features a series of Sherlock Holmes cases, and you must search a variety of locations to find clues to solve the mystery.  Each location reveals a number of potential suspects, and the conclusion involves solving a logic and memory puzzle to determine which party is guilty.  The cases are well-written, and the hidden object scenes are appropriate to the time and place in question (late-19th c. London).  The suspects are believable, and the objects one must find to discover suspects are appropriate to the story (perfume bottles for the mistress of a prominent politician, for example).  Those who enjoyed the first game will certainly want to play the second.  Don't expect innovation, just more of what made the first game fun.  This is definitely one of the more fulfilling hidden object games I've played recently.

reviews.title: A Good Addition to the Nancy Drew Lineup
reviews.text: This is definitely one of the better Nancy Drew games.  It's not my overall favorite, but it was definitely a good one.  This installment involves Nancy going undercover at an elite girls' school to determine who is sabotaging the top students.  Nancy lives as a student in the dorm, and investigates her suspects, who are in the running for valedictorian.  This game has its good points and its bad points.  There are lots of people to talk to, and quite a bit to do in this game, that's certainly a plus.  I did find the locations somewhat limiting- Nancy is restricted to the dorm building and library during her time at Waverly.  There are the sort of puzzles and tasks one expects in a Nancy Drew game.  Some of the characters in the game are a bit overdone, but overall, the story was engaging, and kept me interested to delineate the culprit.

reviews.title: Originality in a Crowded Genre
reviews.text: There's lots of hidden object games on the market, but this one actually does manage to do something different from the rest.  Following the plot of Fitzgerald's novel, players follow the story of Jay Gatsby and Daisy Buchanan through hidden object scenes and cut scenes.  The drawings are beautiful, and the story is faithfully rendered.  Where this game manages to be original is in the introduction of moving hidden object scenes.  Not only are there objects hidden in the cut scenes, there are also hidden object puzzles that move- players must find the objects while on the screen.  This is one of the best hidden object games I've played lately- well worth it for those who love beautifully rendered scenes and deep plots.

reviews.title: A Fun Hidden Object Adventure
reviews.text: I've played loads of hidden object games, and I enjoy them.  It's hard to be original in hidden object games these days, and I'm pleased to say that this one had enough originality that I was quite taken with it, and have played it several times.  The story line for this game involves entering dreamland to end the nightmares of a variety of individuals.  Each dreamer has a phobia that needs cleaning up.  What makes this game interesting is that each level involves traveling through several different dream worlds.  Each scene has several different portals, and once the scene is clear, you get to pick which portal you enter.  This means that at the beginning of the game you really don't know where you'll end up.  At the end, when you've more or less figured out where some of the portals go, you have some control of what scenes you play.  The scenes are nicely drawn, and there are lots of levels to complete, offering lots of gameplay for the money.  Well worth the price for hidden object fans!

reviews.title: Disappointing
reviews.text: I was disappointed in this game.  I was expecting a seriously scary game and this, well, wasn't.  The first half of the game finds babysitter and children alone in the house.  Instead of fending off spooky things, you'll be spending your time cleaning up after mischievous children.  The second half finds you in a much spookier part of the house, but it was really more disgusting than spooky.  Basically, I didn't enjoy this game all that much.  That may just be a matter of taste.  The graphics were well-executed, and the objects were well-hidden.

reviews.title: Not worth it
reviews.text: I didn't think this game was worth the money.  I love point and click adventure games, but this one was not very well executed.  The haunted castle in France setting is promising, but there's not all that much to explore in the castle.  The other characters are not all that interesting, and their dialogue seemed stilted to me.  This is also a very easy game, as these adventure games go.  Normally I find myself completely puzzled, but this game never really did that.  It's also a very linear game, mostly because there's not enough gameplay to allow for non-linear play.  In sum, if you already know you like adventure games, stick to the others- Nancy Drew, Syberia, Sherlock Holmes- all are better choices.

reviews.title: Suitably creepy mystery
reviews.text: For fans of the Nancy Drew games, this is one of the better ones.  This game features Nancy in New Orleans trying to unlock the secrets of a creepy old mansion possibly haunted by a legendary crystal skull.  Nancy investigates the mansion, and her friend Bess handles the neighborhood around their hotel, including a voodoo supply shop.  This game has many of the elements that make Nancy Drew games great.  The setting is *really* creepy- think spooky mansion and graveyard on a rainy night.  The story is involved and gameplay is long.  This is one of the more difficult Nancy Drew games- I found some of the puzzles to be really tricky, even on the Junior Detective level.  Fans of Nancy Drew won't want to miss this one.

reviews.title: Outstanding!
reviews.text: In my humble opinion this is probably the best Nancy Drew game of the series.  This game finds Nancy in a creepy mansion in England attempting to find out why an old friend appears to be under a curse.  Her adventures take her all over the mansion, which is clearly hiding some secrets.  The mansion is delightfully spooky, and there are plenty of spooky happenings to add to the atmosphere.  This game has some of the most challenging puzzles of all the Nancy Drew games.  It's also quite long.  All in all, good fun, and good value for money.

reviews.title: My Favorite
reviews.text: I think this is quite possibly my very favorite Nancy Drew game.  Nancy is sent to Venice to track a thief who has been targeting wealthy homeowners and society events.  The thief dresses up as a phantom (hence, the phantom of Venice).  This game is long, offers fun and interesting puzzles, and has genuinely scary moments.  The scenery is also beautiful.  As far as the plot goes, it's excellent.  There are some changes from the Nancy Drew book of the same name.  All in all, this is a game well-worth playing.

reviews.title: Loads of Gameplay
reviews.text: This is one of the longest and most varied hidden object games I've played lately.  The storyline involves restoring the garden of an old house along with the help of Austin, the faithful butler, and the dog (you'll get to name him/her).  To raise money for garden restorations you hold yard sales, selling stuff in various rooms of a very overstuffed mansion.  People show up and indicate what they want, you have to find it as quickly as possible.  There are also hidden coins to earn more money, and a very interesting hint system, that really adds to the gameplay.  This is a game with many, many levels, and you get to make decisions about how you want the final garden to look.  Loads of fun, well worth the price.

reviews.title: Lots of Gameplay
reviews.text: This is a really fun game.  It's a building game- basically you have to rebuild a certain number of structures within a given timeframe.  You'll have to employ a number of different strategies to get through all the levels, and there are LOTS of levels.  One of the biggest strengths of this game is that there are loads of levels, giving hours of gameplay.  I definitely recommend this game as a great value.

reviews.title: Great Value
reviews.text: This game bundle is a great value.  I've enjoyed all three of these games.  They are pretty standard hidden objects games, but they are well drawn, and because the storylines come from real books, they are complex and well-developed.  Overall, these are exciting mysteries with fairly long gameplay.  Well worth the money.

reviews.title: Thought it would be better
reviews.text: At first this game seemed to be better than it actually is.  The premise is that you are a detective hunting down criminals.  You have to search hidden object scenes for clues, and use those clues to determine who the suspect is.  You'll get clues along the way as to the suspect's gender, height, hair color, etc., and you'll use those to determine who you're seeking.  The hidden object scenes are located around the world, and you'll need to determine where you need to search.  So far, this all sounds good.  The main problem with this game is that there aren't very many locations or scenes, so it gets repetitive VERY quickly.  It's good for approximately two games, then it starts to get boring.  Not worth the money, in my opinion.

reviews.title: Short, but fun for Drew fans
reviews.text:
This is the game that started the Nancy Drew series. I just bought and played this remastered edition, and I was pleasantly surprised. It's important to recognize that the Nancy Drew games have definitely evolved over time, so don't expect a game as flashy and complete as Crystal Skull or similar. But this game did give the basics that fans of the series expect: a good mystery, and suspects to investigate.

The storyline places Nancy in a high school, where an unpopular student has just died. There are several possible suspects, and Nancy has to figure out what happened to him. The main issues with this game are that there aren't very many locations to search, and it's a rather short game, compared to later Nancy Drews. I wouldn't recommend this as an introduction to the series, as there are undoubtedly much better Nancy Drew games, but fans of the series won't want to miss this one.

reviews.title: A good Nancy Drew game!
reviews.text:
I quite enjoyed this installment in the Nancy Drew series. This episode finds Nancy at a winter resort in Canada, trying to track down a dangerous prankster who has been damaging the resort's property and harming guests. There are several suspects, all staying at the resort, and Nancy poses as the new maid to try and figure out who is responsible.

Generally this is a solid game- there's lots to do, and plenty of interesting scenery. The resort is not as inherently scary as some of the other places Nancy finds herself (like old mansions and dark graveyards), but there are lots of places to explore. My two main complaints were with mini-games. The first is a snowball fight you have to complete every time you want to go outside. The second is a board game called "Fox and Geese" which took forever to finish and lost its appeal long before that.

Still, I'd recommend this game, to experienced Drew players and new ones.

reviews.title: Beautiful and Fun
reviews.text: This game takes the player into the land of storybooks, to help well-known book and fairy-tale characters restore order to their world.  Gameplay involves a series of puzzles and tasks in which the player will jump among several famous stories (including The Three Little Pigs, Treasure Island, and similar).  This is a rather hard game to describe- it is really one that needs to be experienced, and I would highly recommend it for anyone who likes puzzle games.

reviews.title: Loud and bright
reviews.text: This hidden object game is based on the standard look for objects in a room formula, but it includes elements that make it stand out from others.  The basic storyline involves searching through a mansion looking for evidence of spirits that haunt it. The scenes are quite bright and busy, and they are drawn in vivid colors.  You have to move through multiple parts of the room to find everything you seek.  Sometimes spirits escape and they fly around the room, which can be hard on the eyes.  And really, that's my main complaint about this game.  It has a good concept, but it was sometimes too loud and visually intense for me.  I couldn't play it for very long periods of time, which is a shame, because it is otherwise a good game.

reviews.title: Completely Addictive
reviews.text: This is a great game, and one that's completely addictive.  The object is to clear paths from your castle as you move onward through the kingdom.  You'll travel through different sorts of environments, such as deserts, swamps, and polar villages.  Along the way you have to erect buildings to produce necessary resources, and finish in the time allotted.  By all means play the trial, you may very well find yourself addicted too.

reviews.title: Wonderful!
reviews.text: This is a wonderful game, one I have fully enjoyed playing.  This is a deep and complicated mystery set in the Louisiana bayou. The graphics are complicated and well-done, the game is certainly atmospheric.  You will have to solve a series of hidden object scenes and puzzles in order to solve the mystery.  This is a long game, it offers tremendous gameplay.  The Mystery Case Files games are always a cut above, and this one is no exception.  My only complaint is that this game uses live actors, and the acting is sometimes stilted, but overall, fabulous game.

reviews.title: Loved it!
reviews.text:
I loved this game- I thought it was one of the better Nancy Drew games. In this game Nancy finds herself in Germany investigating monster sightings at a remote castle. The castle has a long history of legends surrounding the monster, and the monster has an appetite for young women, just like Nancy.

This game has the elements that make a Nancy Drew game fun. There's a large, beautiful castle to explore. There are people to talk to, and you have to talk to them repeatedly. The mini-games are complex, but not difficult, and they fit with the context of the story. There's no irritating mini-game that's nearly impossible to pass. I got many hours of gameplay from this game. I'd compare it to Blackmoor Manor and Crystal Skull. I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game. The mini-games were so much better than previous ND games, and the artwork was absolutely amazing.

reviews.title: Some Good, Some Bad
reviews.text:
There are some really good things about this game, but there are things that I didn't like as well. This episode finds Nancy in Japan teaching English during the day and solving mysteries at night. Nancy is staying at a traditional Japanese inn, a ryokan, and it appears that there are secrets and mysteries lurking throughout. Guests have been leaving because they've been seeing ghosts, the image of a drowned woman. Nancy decides that it's up to her to determine what's going on. Her investigations reveal that every member of the family that runs the ryokan has deep, dark secrets.

The positives: I loved that Nancy went to Japan. The setting was beautiful, and it was exciting to have Nancy visit a new place. Many of the mini games focused on Japanese culture and traditions. This was a long game and I got plenty of gameplay.

The negatives: It was hard for me to find the ryokan scary. It simply wasn't all that scary, even though the action happened at night. I also found the characters fairly uninteresting. Usually these ND mysteries have some seriously bizarre characters, but these characters were, well, normal. I guess normal just isn't interesting. Because this mystery centers on a family's past, it often seems like Nancy's investigating is more intrusive than helpful. I also didn't like the way the days were set up- because of teaching Nancy is only free after 7pm.

In sum, this is a quality ND game, but by no means my favorite.

reviews.title: Fun Farm Game
reviews.text: I seem to be in the minority, but I think this is the best of the Farm Frenzy games.  The game involves buying animals, upgrading buildings, and producing products to sell.  You'll have to keep the farm stocked with grass and water for the animals, collect raw materials, and produce finished goods in craft buildings.  You'll also need to earn money to finance all these things, and keep predators (bears) away from your animals.  I enjoyed this game.  It's long, and you'll get plenty of gameplay for your money.  My main complaint about the game is that you have to repay to upgrade your buildings at each level.  I wish that upgrades were permanent.  There are many subsequent games in this series, but I've found those to be basically copies of this first one.

reviews.title: Long Game, Lots of Value
reviews.text: This is quite a long hidden object game.  Thought it's not tremendously hard, it kept me busy for hours.  The artwork is good, and the puzzles aren't too hard.  The game has a spooky amusement park theme, which I thought worked well.  The last third of the game takes place in an odd surreal world that you travel through a porthole to reach.  It was never entirely clear to me why this world existed, and I preferred the parts in the amusement park.  Still, if you're looking for a good value hidden object game, you could do much worse than Weird Park.

reviews.title: Dark Fairy Tales
reviews.text: I love the Dark Parables series, and this is a quality addition to the line-up.  This is an adventure-hidden object game with beautiful graphics.  The story involves you, as the detective, searching a mysterious forest for a girl who vanished.  The hidden object scenes require you to find pieces that combine to form objects.  This is a nice change from the traditional hidden object game.  The game is lengthy, the story is complex, and you will visit a broad range of beautiful locations.  I have never been disappointed by a game in this series, and I enjoyed this one just as much as Briar Rose and Snow Queen (and if you like this game, check out those too).

reviews.title: One of the Weaker Nancy Drew Games
reviews.text:
I've played all of the Nancy Drew games, and this is one of the weaker ones. This case has Nancy travelling to Hawaii along with the Hardy Boys, who will help her solve the case. Nancy is on assignment helping a bug scientist in the jungle (no joke- not quite my idea of a Hawaiian vacation). The Hardy Boys, meanwhile, are staying at a resort where people are required to complete ridiculous tasks to "earn" privileges. Expect to string plenty of necklaces. Again, who goes to that kind of resort?

In any case, the graphics in this game are beautiful- expect some gorgeous paradise beaches. The game's story is weak, however, and the game is very short. Much shorter, I thought, than the other Nancy Drew games. The game is still worth playing, but don't expect the amount or quality of gameplay as in the others.

reviews.title: Simply Beautiful
reviews.text: This game immerses the player in the theater of the Phantom of the Opera.  Gameplay involves investigating the sumptuous 19th century Parisian theater trying to uncover the malevolent phantom.  The graphics are absolutely gorgeous, and the game is long and complex, in action and in story.  It kept me occupied for a number of hours.  The Gothic ambiance makes the game suitably scary.  This is a very well-done game, and one I fully enjoyed playing.

reviews.title: Lots of fun
reviews.text: This second installment in the Ranch Rush series is even more fun than the first.  Ranch Rush 2 has a tropical theme, and has the player growing and making tropical crops and crafts on the beach.  Some added elements include a monkey friend who helps you collect coconuts, and a farm that bridges two sides of a water inlet.  The numerous crops, machines, and orders remain from Ranch Rush 1.  Those who enjoyed the first will definitely like the second, and anyone who enjoys time management games should definitely give this one a try.

reviews.title: Amazing amount of gameplay
reviews.text: It's amazing just how much gameplay you get with this game.  This is an interactive hidden object game- the kind that immerses you in a world and you interact with objects as well as hidden object scenes.  This is the longest game I have played in a very long time.  You definitely get your money's worth on that front.  There are numerous locations to explore in a spooky, old, enchanted mansion.  The artwork is attractive, and the storyine kept me interested.  If you go through games quickly, I'd absolutely encourage you to try this one.

reviews.title: easy
reviews.text: easy to buy and fast to use

reviews.title: easy
reviews.text: easy to use and operate, my 15 year old brother uses it for his minecraft files

reviews.title: good headphones but bad for gaming
reviews.text:
I had high expectations when ordering this headset, especially since they were backed by Sony. I was looking for wireless that had the controls on the side. These seemed perfect, however, after just a few uses, I had issues with them disconnecting during game play, from there they would not connect at all. When they were working, I would have to unplug it every time I wanted to use the PS4 for streaming or to play multiplayer with my son. Even with the headphones off, the system still attempted to play through them, so that became annoying.
I stopped using them for gaming and started using them to play music on my work computer. For that, they work great. They are loud and comfortable. The sound is great, but I do not use the mic anymore. Wish Song would have tested that portion of things out before, as that seems like an important piece.
All in all, good headphones, bad gaming headset.

reviews.title: works great!
reviews.text: PlayStation 4 controller thumb grips and precision pack are nice and easy to put on. They fit perfectly on your controller. They feel amazing on your fingers and thumbs. These fit on the controllers great and the grips make it easy to use and play. No problem with sweating and slipping on the controllers.

reviews.title: works great!
reviews.text: Amazon basic pro gaming headset has good sound quality. The microphone is clear and people say they can hear you on the other end.  It fits comfortably on your head and ears. The audio coming into the headset is clear and loud.  All the buttons work perfectly fine.  Definitely a good value for the price.

reviews.title: Level up your gaming!
reviews.text: Easy to put on and doesn't effect any of the buttons. Handles are grouped and vented so it's easier and less sweaty. And you gotta live the thumb grips! Comfortable camo headset with wheel for the volume and on/ off switch for the mic.

reviews.title: Well designed big mouse pad
reviews.text: This is a really nice mouse pad for gaming. The look and feel of the mouse pad gives it a top of the line feel. I would definitely recommend checking the dimensions of the mouse pad to make sure that it will fit your desk, because it is HUGE. While the large size takes up quite a bit of room, your mouse movements are smooth and precise for optimal gaming. The anti-fray stiching looks very nice, and hopefully it will stay in good shape over time. The one thing that bothered me was the factory smell when I took it out of the box. It was overwhelming and hard to use for awhile, but it seems to have started to go away. I would definitely get this mouse pad if you are looking for a top of the line, quality product that gives you an advantage when gaming.

reviews.title: works great!
reviews.text: The sades gaming headset is great. It is very comfortable to wear and fits great. The LEDs look amazing on the sides and really brings out the color, but are definitely just for show. They look great while streaming. The sound quality is great but my only complaint is the MIC. I have people say they have a hard time hearing me and the only way I can get it to really work is to almost eat it.

reviews.title: works great!
reviews.text: I love the way these feel. They sound nice and are comfortable for long use. The mic sounds great and all the buttons work as expected.

reviews.title: LOVE!
reviews.text: The sound on these are amazing. They sound great for PC use, and they are so comfortable for long term wear. If you are going to be using it for any kind of music, it does not have the best bass. The program is super easy to set up and use. Great for gaming and streaming.

reviews.title: waste
reviews.text: The headphones sound great and fit comfortably, however the mic quality is trash. This makes them a waste for gaming as no one can hear you talk.

reviews.title: Works as well as Nintendo brand
reviews.text: I love these charging grips for my Joycons. They charge well but not fast. It feels just like the Nintendo brand ones. Save some money and get these!

reviews.title: Easy to replace joy-con joysticks
reviews.text:
I had some older joy-cons that had drift issues and worn down joysticks. I figured that I didn't have anything to lose by replacing them myself. I had already replaced the joy-cons with newer ones. I will say that it isn't the easiest thing to replace the joysticks, but with minimal knowledge and patience, you can do it. The kit comes with 4 joysticks along with all of the tools in the picture. I used every piece of the kit except for the extra screws and two joysticks.

To start, you need to use the star screwdriver to open up the joy-con casing. Once all four screws are out, you need to get the pieces of casing separated using the guitar pick. Be careful to not disconnect anything and set aside pieces as you get into the insides of the controller. Once you have the casing separated, you need to get under the battery. There is one to three phillips head screws (depending on left or right joycon) holding a plastic piece that holds the battery for the controller. Once you have the plastic piece holding the battery off, you will see the circuit board for the controller. Carefully remove the joystick using the screwdriver and tweezers. You will need to disconnect the cord coming off of it. Once you pop the joystick out, you just need to put the new one in the same was and connect the cord to the controller! After that, you just need to reassemble your controller and test it out!

The joysticks work perfectly, and I have had no issues with them so far. I still have two back-up ones to replace my current main controllers if needed! I highly recommend this kit.

reviews.title: Great protection for Switch Lite!
reviews.text: We bought a new Nintendo Switch Lite for a relative and used these on the screen. Super easy to apply and feel very durable. They last for a bit, as long as nothing hits them. Worth it for the protection they provide to a $200 video game system!

reviews.title: HyperX Alloy Elite RGB Mechanical Gaming Keyboard
reviews.text:
I’m something of an odd gamer, in that I play one game (World of Warcraft) and use a MacBook Pro with an external monitor, mouse, and keyboard when I’m gaming. I know, I make absolutely no sense, but that’s how I roll.

So! I’ve tried a few mechanical keyboards since adopting my current setup. If a keyboard has fun backlighting, I’m drawn to it like a bird to a shiny object. I adore the lighting on the HyperX Alloy Elite RGB keyboard! The default is a scrolling rainbow of colors, but the onboard memory profiles include a blue mode and a red mode. Unlike Windows users, I can’t download their software to get the full customization available, but I’m satisfied with the built-in options. And I know that if someday the apocalypse happens and I switch to Windows, I will have even more options in that area.

The volume control is another one of those cool features that I really like. The scroll wheel is amazing for adjusting on the fly, such as if I can’t hear my raid leader in Discord, or my game sound is suddenly booming in my ears. I don’t have to look to adjust, which is a plus.

The keys feel amazing. The keyboard is very clicky; the first time I used it, my mom thought I was murdering the poor keyboard. But I like the noise and feel of it. If you haven’t used a mechanical keyboard before, there’s a slight adjustment period. I like the feel of the keys and the keyboard’s quick responsiveness so much that I use it for writing and other work every day, not just gaming.

HyperX included extra keys, for 1-4 and WASD. The WASD have a slight texture to them. There’s also a plastic wrist rest you can attach to the keyboard.

The only thing I’m confused about -- the keyboard has two USB connectors. Because I use a laptop, I’m limited on ports. I learned the keyboard still works with only one of the USB connectors plugged in. So I’m not sure why there are two? There is a back USB port on the keyboard, if you have the running-out-of-ports problem like me. Lastly, the USB cord is super heavy duty, very thick and braided. It’s almost 6 feet long.

reviews.title: iMW Glass Protector Pack for Nintendo Switch, 2-Pack
reviews.text:
These screen protectors are shipped in a cardboard box to prevent bending.

I’m glad this was a 2 pack of screen protectors, because I have big bubbles in the first one I applied.

I followed every step for installation. The guide stickers aren’t pre-installed, you have to put them on the screen protector. I triple-checked my alignment; the holes line up properly. But no matter how careful I was in applying the screen protector, I ended up with several bubbles that I couldn’t press out.

Functionality wise, the screen protector seems to work well. Other than the unsightly bubbles.

reviews.title: DELTA Essentials Nintendo Switch Controller
reviews.text:
The instructions are obviously translated from Chinese, but the translation is decent. Pairing the controller was suspiciously easy. I honestly expected it to be a harder process, but nope. The instructions include screenshots of the appropriate Switch screens, which helped.

I didn’t need to calibrate the controller at all. The vibrations are strong. The controller feels comfortable in my hands. The color is darker than the photograph, more of a dark grey. I don’t mind because I’d rather have dark colors on a controller.

I’ve tried it with Lego Harry Potter and Overcooked 2 and have been pleased. I wasn’t able to get it to work with Let’s Go, Eevee.

My controller didn’t come charged. The box does include a charging cable but you’ll need a USB AC adaptor to plug into the wall.

reviews.title: Logitech G935 Wireless Gaming Headset
reviews.text:
I tried the Logitech G935 Wireless Gaming Headset for about two months before writing this review. I wish I liked the headset better, but after testing it, I’m still on the hunt for the perfect headset.

Currently I do most of my gaming with multiplayer Switch games, such as Splatoon 2. I have to use Discord on my computer or phone to talk with friends while we play. But I also want to hear game sounds, so the option to have dual sound inputs is what really drew me to the G935. I connected the headphones wirelessly to my computer and used the 3.5 mm cable to connect to my Switch. A bit messy, but I was willing to accept that if it worked well.

But it didn’t. No matter how many sound settings I adjusted, my voice was muffled when talking. I had better results using a normal pair of headphones and the built-in microphone on my computer!

Not to mention, finding the proper button I want to use when wearing the headset is difficult. I have to feel and count the buttons, which takes my attention out of the game and performance suffers. I suppose I’d develop some muscle memory if I used the headset for longer, but I still feel like there are too many buttons. And the volume rocker is at the bottom of the earcup, so if you take the headphones on or off, it’s really easy to change the volume and not be able to hear or get a screech in your ear.

Comfort wise, I tend to get headaches if a headset is too heavy and/or tight. About an hour was my limit for wearing the G935, or I’d have a headache from the weight of it. The earcups are actually pretty comfy and well padded, the headset is just big and I wouldn’t recommend if you have a small head.

Sound quality is good, one of the better parts of the headset. But I couldn’t find a way to adjust the volume on one source and not the other via the headset if I did dual inputs.

I just wasn’t thrilled with the G935 headset. At the level it’s designed for, I would have expected Bluetooth connectivity instead of a wireless dongle, better button design/layout, and better comfort overall, not to mention clear voice quality.

reviews.title: Corsair Glaive Pro, 18,000 DPI
reviews.text:
I’ve been using the Corsair Glaive Pro (18,000 DPI) for about a month. For comparison, I also have a Razer Basilisk and a Logitech G502 Proteus Spectrum. The Logitech was my preferred mouse for a long time, but I’ve been using the Corsair almost daily instead of switching. It’s good for general use as well as gaming.

One of the biggest pluses for me is that Corsair’s software, iCUE, runs on Macs. I can customize everything, including the lighting, make macros, change the DPI, and probably other things I haven’t found yet. There’s a lot of options to explore in iCUE, but I think it’s pretty intuitive.

I like the hand feel of the mouse. I have small hands; this mouse is comfortable to use for hours at a time. Obviously, everyone has different preferences, and I’m quite picky myself. Hand feel is impossible to test when buying a mouse online. But Corsair has designed this mouse to have three different thumb grips. My Logitech mouse has adjustable weights, which requires a little fiddling. Changing the grips on the Corsair is super easy: they snap into place. Magnets keep the grips on and make a quick switch out easy, if I think I might want a different one when playing.

I also like how the scroll wheel feels. It reminds me of a little tire, with its tread.

The mouse is lacking buttons for serious gamers. Aside from the usual left/right click, there’s only forward, backward, and DPI up and DPI down. I also have to say I don’t notice any difference between the Corsair’s 18,000 DPI versus the Razer’s 16,000 DPI or even the Logitech’s 12,000 DPI.

reviews.title: E-YOOSO Mechanical Keyboard, Outemu Blue Switches
reviews.text:
I’m not an expert on mechanical keyboards (that’s a rabbithole I don’t want to go down, or I’ll be building my own in a week), but I do love them now that I’ve switched to using one on a daily basis. My daily driver is a HyperX Alloy Elite with Cherry MX Blue switches.

I’ve put this E-YOOSO mechanical keyboard to the test for about three weeks. The switches are Outemu Blue Switches, which is a knock-off of Cherry MX Blue switches. I definitely noticed a difference between the Outemu and the Cherry. The Outemu are a little noisier and don’t feel as smooth. I feel more resistance when I type on the E-YOOSO keyboard versus the HyperX one. Over a few hours, the resistance adds up.

Of course, the HyperX keyboard is more than double the price of this one, but the E-YOOSO is lacking in some basic features that I’ve become used to. There’s no attached wrist rest, and I really feel the lack of it. Muscle memory keeps my wrists up as if there was a rest under them, which gets tiring. There are no multimedia or sound controls on the keyboard; I really miss that easy adjustment when I’m mid game. The keycaps are basic plastic, without any texture. What you’d find on a normal cheap keyboard, and again, this is a matter of preference, but the keys are slippery. Not great for gaming.

The silver screws on the keyboard continually catch my eye. This is a minor thing, but I wish the screws were flush with the plastic case rather than sitting above it. I’ve snagged my fingers on the screws a few times. The USB cable is plastic instead of braided.

The lighting options are preset, you can cycle through them via the FN and INS keys. I do like that the keyboard includes options without needing to download additional software, but for most people, the first mode (steady rainbow) will be the default. If I’m gaming in the dark, marquee or snake are useless. Another minor quibble, but I really don’t like the orange row of the keyboard, I wish another color had been chosen. The orange just doesn’t fit with the other colors, in my opinion. It’s too similar to the red row right above it.

I do like the dust resistance; I’ve had the keyboard sitting out for three weeks and haven’t noticed any dust building up on it.

reviews.title: Razer Base Station Chroma Headset Stand
reviews.text:
This Razer Base Station Chroma Headset Stand is one of those things I don’t really need. But I’ve been thinking about getting a headphone stand for my desk for a while, just to make it look a little neater. And I love RGB lighting; everything on my desk lights up. I even have light strips attached underneath my desk and on the backs of my monitors.

The stand arrives in two pieces that sturdily click together, so it would be easier than it seems to transport this if needed, in the future. The matte black looks nice in person; I was worried the stand would pick up dust, but it’s actually a smooth plastic texture that is easy to clean.

But no matter what I try, Synapse will not recognize the stand. I’ve looked up and tried every fix I can find, with no dice. So when everything else on my desk is glowing blue or purple, this stand is doing its default rainbow thing. And look, I love rainbows, but sometimes I want everything to match!

So the stand does half of its job: it holds my headphones. But I’m really disappointed that I can’t customize its effects with Synapse. My other Razer devices connect to Synapse with no problems.

reviews.title: iMW Joy-Con Caps
reviews.text:
I’ve tried a few different grips and caps to make playing my Switch more comfortable in handheld mode. Currently I’m using a Skull & Co. GripCase, which I like, but I still have fatigue and hand cramps if I play for too many hours.

I didn’t like these iMW Joy-Con Caps. They raise the joystick too much, so my thumbs are almost in a 90 degree angle. It was so uncomfortable I yanked them off mid-match.

I tried again without the case, to see if that made a difference for me. It did not -- I felt immediate irritation in my hands, and again yanked off the caps.

They come off very easily, so I feel like they’d pop off at the worst moment during an intense play session.

reviews.title: Razer Basilisk X Hyperspeed Wireless Mouse
reviews.text:
[[VIDEOID:4c2e9d2f7b0e6a0691a91cb5e893b6c]] This is a review for the Razer Basilisk X Hyperspeed Wireless Mouse.

For comparison purposes, I also use a Razer Basilisk 16,000 DPI Optical Sensor (wired) and a Logitech G502 Proteus Spectrum (wired) on a daily basis. I don’t love the wired Razer, as I’m not a fan of the scroll wheel or the design of buttons 4 and 5.

Right off, I noticed that I liked the scroll wheel on the Razer Basilisk X. It doesn’t have as much resistance as the wired version does. It’s a little clicky and has some resistance, but not so much that I revert to using my laptop’s trackpad, as I do with the wired Basilisk.

The left and right buttons are nice and clicky. The side buttons stick out a bit more on the Basilisk X than on the wired Basilisk, which I prefer.

I have small hands and found the Basilisk X comfortable to use for hours at a time.

Synapse 2 on my Mac could not find this mouse. Synapse 3 on my Windows computer did find the mouse. This mouse is only compatible with Synapse 3. On Windows, I was able to customize the different buttons.

There’s no RGB customization, as the Basilisk X is the less expensive model. I was sad to see the Razer logo doesn’t light up; yes I’m a dork who likes glowing peripherals.

The mouse can be used either wirelessly or with Bluetooth. There’s a switch on the bottom to switch between connectivity types. The Basilisk X uses one AA battery; to help with battery life, I put the switch on BT to keep from accidentally waking the mouse if I don’t have the dongle plugged in. The USB dongle can be stored inside the battery compartment. It’s very small and difficult to remove from a USB port once inserted.

In contrast to other battery powered mice I’ve used in the past, the Basilisk X’s battery compartment is on the top of the mouse. The top pops off so easily I’m worried that it will pop off while I’m using the mouse, especially during an intense moment in a game. All it takes is a little pressure in the right spot, and bam, off the battery lid goes. I really don’t like this.

I don’t have a scale, but there’s a noticeable weight difference between the wired Basilisk and the wireless Basilisk X. The Basilisk X feels very lightweight in the hand. It’s almost a bit too light for me; I notice the difference every time I switch between the mice.

reviews.title: HyperX Alloy Origins Core Tenkeyless, HyperX Red Linear Switch
reviews.text:
I’ve been using the HyperX Alloy Origins Core Tenkeyless Keyboard for a few weeks and I love it!

I have the Linear Switch (HyperX Red) version. This is my first time trying linear switches. The first few days, I felt like I was typing on the softest keyboard ever. I personally like how buttery and responsive it feels, but finding the right switch option is really one of those things you have to try yourself. I did notice that it’s easier to “bottom out” the linear switch versus say, a Cherry MX Blue switch.

I have a light hand and don’t do a ton of button mashing with the games I currently play (Warcraft, Paladins, SDV), so the Origins Core has replaced my daily driver, the HyperX Alloy Elite RGB (with Cherry MX Blue switches). I do miss the volume rocker on the Elite RGB, but that’s all I miss.

The Origins Core does have function keys (FN + F#) for volume, media control, and light profiles.

Getting back some of my desk with the Tenkeyless version is another plus, too. The keyboard is small enough that I actually would travel with it, if I were going somewhere for a few days. The USB cable is detachable, which makes it easier to transport.

I use this keyboard for both writing (at least 2-3 hours of typing a day) plus gaming. I like that HyperX has built angles of adjustability into the keyboard feet. I can have a 3°, 7°, or 11° angle. The keycaps are a little slippery during extended gaming sessions, but this hasn’t bothered me enough to replace them.

The keyboard itself has a good build feeling to it, and it doesn’t slide on my desk, even during intense moments.

I did try HyperX’s NGENUITY software to make my own custom lighting profiles. The software is only available on Windows, but the keyboard can save 3 profiles to its onboard memory. I switch between Windows and Mac, so I was excited that I could customize the keyboard on my Windows machine, and be able to use those light profiles on my Mac without needing the software. NGENUITY allows a LOT of customization; I spent a few hours playing with the different lighting options. I like NGENUITY more than Synapse.

I have one little quibble. I wish the lighting for the caps lock key was on the key itself, instead of above the arrows. But that’s a tiny little complaint, it doesn’t interfere with my use at all.

I recommend going with the RGB version; you can always set a solid color. The RGB lighting is so much fun, and I dare I say -- it’s pretty!

reviews.title: Razer Kraken Kitty Headset
reviews.text:
Okay, so, I’m a total dork and love things that glow. I couldn’t put the Razer Kraken Kitty Headset on my head quickly enough -- glowing cat ears? I almost wish I was a streamer, so I could show them off!

The headphones are very comfortable. They’re heavier than other pairs I own, but I don’t notice that when wearing them. The headband is padded. The ear cups are too, fitting comfortably over the ear. The headphones stay in place without squeezing my head too tight, which is important for me, as I get headaches when headphones are too tight. The headset has measurements on each side, so you can keep track of what is the perfect fit for you.

These days I generally prefer wireless headphones for the convenience, but I’ve been reaching for the Kraken Kitty pair instead, so that should tell you how much I like the comfort/style.

The mic is retractable, so when I’m not using it, I don’t even notice it. Sound quality with Discord and the mic has been good. The sound quality of the headphones is good too, though they don’t do noise cancelling. Just the mic does noise cancelling.

While I love the kitty ears, there are a few downsides to this headset.

One: changing the color from the default Razer green requires Synapse 3. Synapse 3 is still in beta, and only runs on Windows machines. I only have Synapse 2 on my Mac, which is my main computer for using Discord while I game.

Two: the cable is not removable. I had hoped to get an adapter and make the Kraken Kitty a Bluetooth headset, but then I’d have a 4 foot cord hanging off my ear. The cable is a strong braided one (like all Razer devices), but I do worry that it will wear out, or I might run it over with my chair. Then I’ll be stuck with a headset I can’t use anymore.

reviews.title: Avankin Headphone Stand and Hanger
reviews.text:
I have a headphone stand already, but it takes up valuable space on my desk, so I thought I would try the Avankin Headphone Stand and Hanger instead.

I’ve only used it in hanging mode, as that allows me to reclaim some of my desk. The clamp fits securely on my desk; it does take some strength to pull the clamp apart. Each side of the clamp has a thin layer of foam padding to protect the surface.

The clamp needs about 2” of space to get a grip, so if you have a desk with a narrow lip, you’ll probably knock it off.

The stand portion can rotate, which is nifty. I can put my headphones on it, then rotate the stand so the headphones are even more out of the way.

reviews.title: Afterglow Wireless Deluxe Controller
reviews.text:
I wanted a glowing controller for my Nintendo Switch from the moment I bought it. But the options haven’t been great, not until the Afterglow Wireless Deluxe Controller was released.

I like this controller a lot. I’ve tried quite a few, including Nintendo’s Pro Controller, but the Afterglow is my favorite. Not just because it glows, but because it feels nice in my hands. I have small hands, so I want a lightweight, easy to hold controller. The Nintendo Pro Controller felt nice, but I didn’t like the matte finish on it, nor how that finish felt against my hands after playing for a while.

The Afterglow controller is compact and lightweight. It has a plasticy finish that I like. The A/B/X/Y buttons are quite clicky, with some resistance behind them. The joysticks are taller than the ones on the joycons, so that takes a bit of adjustment. The big button on the back of the controller is a bit weird, but it can be disabled.

Lastly, the Home button is really close to the X (and the + is really close to the Y). I’ve accidentally hit the Home button more than once in the middle of a FPS match, which isn’t ideal. And I have small fingers!

But now, let’s talk about the glowing, because that’s one of the best parts for me. The controller is transparent, so it looks cool even when it’s not being used. There are different glow modes: set color, fade in and out to set color, cycle through all colors, and react to movement of joysticks. So there’s a lot of customization and color options. The controller looks the best in the dark, but it’s not too shabby in the middle of the day, either.

So, even though I have a few small quibbles with the button placement, the lighting is honestly enough to make up for that.

reviews.title: My new favorite HyperX keyboard!
reviews.text:
I like HyperX keyboards a lot. For the last several months, my daily driver has been their Alloy Origins Core Tenkeyless, with their HyperX Red switches. I usually write several thousand words a day, so I liked the switches for comfort, the RGB lighting for fun, and the keyboard as a whole for being able to switch seamlessly between work and gaming.

Enter in the new HyperX Alloy Elite 2. I haven’t touched my Origins Core since unboxing the Elite 2! The Elite 2 is full-size, with num pad and media keys, so it takes up a bit more space on my desk. It’s heavier too, weighing in at 3.3 pounds (1530 grams) compared to 1.98 pounds (900 grams) for the Origins Core.

But I’m fine with all of that, because the Elite 2 looks SO COOL.
