The ABS Pudding Keycaps are hands down the coolest part of this keyboard. The sides of the keycaps are translucent, which allows a ton more light to shine through. The top of the keycaps are black, and actually look like they are floating on a sea of LED light. If you like your keyboard to light up, it doesn’t get brighter or cooler than this.

At certain angles, you can see the red of the switches.

I’m already used to and like the company’s HyperX Red switches. Switch preference is a personal and tactile preference, but I will say that for me, these switches feel like typing on air. Performance feels good, though I do think it’s easier to bottom out linear switches compared to clicky switches. I play Paladins and have a light hand; this keyboard works well for me in that game.

I use the keyboard with Windows and Mac computers. Another thing I like is that the keyboard has 3 onboard memory profiles, so I can use HyperX’s NGENUITY software on my Windows machine to customize profiles, plug the keyboard into my Mac, and be able to use those customized lighting profiles.

I’ve also tried HyperX’s first Alloy Elite keyboard, and like the Elite 2 much better. My first Elite had Cherry MX Blues, and I definitely prefer the HyperX Red switches on the Elite 2. I do want to point out that the Elite 2 does NOT include a wrist rest or different WASD keycaps.

reviews.title: LED is great, but smells strongly of rubber
reviews.text:
If you’re like me and like things that light up, an LED mouse pad is really fun to have on your desk. I also like big mouse pads that can fit my laptop, mouse, and drink, so this mouse pad from Zpose does double duty.

The mouse pad has several lighting modes. My preference is for the static colors (red, blue, green, purple, cyan, yellow, and white) since they are less distracting when I’m working. But some of the dynamic modes are fun; there are a few that slowly change color and don’t flash in and out.

The mouse pad remembers the last selected light mode, which is nice. The two different brightness options (tap the button twice quickly to change) are almost identical. It is powered by an included micro USB cable. The cable is about 70 inches long.

The LED stripe around the edge of the mouse pad is flexible, so the mouse pad can be rolled up for easy storage.

I’ve taken off a star because the mouse pad has a *very* strong rubber scent. The smell is strong enough to turn my stomach and give me a headache. I let the mouse pad air out for over a week but it still has the rubber smell.

reviews.title: Cannot see lighting effects when using
reviews.text:
I have to admit, I’m somewhat of a magpie for things that light up. Especially when said things have rainbow color options. I have LED light strips on my desk and external monitor, a LED mousepad, a rainbow backlit external keyboard, and various lamps. At night, my office looks like a space ship.

All of this is to say I was drawn to the Tilted Nation Gaming Laptop Stand because of the “visually striking aesthetics” of the lighting options.

But when my laptop is on the stand, I can’t see the lighting effects! The sides of my laptop block any view of the lighting.

And I have a 13” Macbook Pro, so a larger laptop will block even more. The only way I can see the lighting effects is if I look underneath my laptop.

When I took the stand out of the box, one of the foam blocks meant to hold the laptop in place fell off. I stuck it back on, but naturally, that makes me worry about it falling off again and my laptop sliding off.

The stand does have an extra piece that can be put in the front slot, for use with bigger laptops. It does impede using a touchpad but provides extra stability.

The USB ports are really high on the back of the stand. If your laptop has a thick lid, the lid might cover or come very close to the ports. The stand is powered by USB-C, the box includes a USB-C to USB-C cable and a USB-C to USB-A cable to accommodate all laptops.

Depending on where your laptop’s vents are, the top portion of the stand might block them. The top support is 2 inches wide.

reviews.title: Lights up, doubles as desk protector
reviews.text:
I was never a fan of mouse pads until I started using big mats like this one from Itopfox. No more being annoyed when my mouse runs off the edge. And for me, the huge mouse pad doubles as a coaster for beverages, a non-slip surface for my mechanical keyboard, and of course plenty of space for my mouse.

But the even bigger draw for me is the LED strip that goes around the whole mouse pad. I like everything on my desk to light up, and this mouse mat looks super cool in the dark. The light is powered by micro USB, cable included.

The light is bright but I did notice it’s slightly dimmer on the lower right-hand corner and right side of the mouse pad, the farthest spots from where the USB cable plugs into the mouse pad. The dimness isn’t something I tend to notice when sitting at my desk, so it doesn’t bother me.

The light options and brightness are controlled by one button. Adjusting the brightness takes a little getting used to, as you have to double click the button to change the brightness and not switch to another light color.

The mouse pad had a slight rubbery scent when removed from the box. After letting it air out for a few days, the smell has disappeared.

reviews.title: Sturdy, can fit 2 pairs of headphones
reviews.text:
The instructions don’t make it obvious, but this headset stand from TROND can be used without the RGB lighting at the base. There is a touch sensor button on the right side of the base that controls the lighting.

Lighting options: rainbow scrolling, red breathing, green breathing, blue breathing, pinky purple breathing, and no light.

I could not figure out how to set a static color. The rainbow lighting is more pastel-hued than pictured, but I think it looks nicer than the normal bright rainbow.

The headset stand can fit two pairs of headphones. The raised edges keep the headphones from falling off. I put one pair of headphones at their longest length, the cups don’t touch the base.

While I will be using the headset stand, I like that the stand bit can come off the base. This makes for easier storage than a fixed headset stand.

The base has non-skid feet to keep the headset stand in place.

The base offers 3 AC outlets and 3 USB ports. The maximum power consumption is 1250W. The USB ports don’t support Quick Charge. The power cable for the headset stand has an angled flat plug that makes it possible to plug the unit into tight spaces.

reviews.title: Useful way to store headphones
reviews.text:
An under the desk clamp is a great way to store headphones without adding to the clutter on top of my desk.

I like that this particular clamp has two arms, so I can hang two pairs of headphones. Each arm has a clip to hold a cable, so I can easily charge my headphones while they’re hanging up (and not lose track of the necessary cable).

The sides of the clamp have a layer of foam to protect surfaces.

What I don’t like about this clamp is the relatively small space between the clamp and the hanging arms. The space is only 2 inches, which sounds like more than enough room to hang a pair of headphones.

But my desk has a metal support frame underneath the top, so I have to kind of wriggle my headphones onto the arm. Yes, I could rotate the arms so they aren’t underneath my desk, hang my headphones, and rotate back. But I know a lot of desks have those big metal rectangles underneath, so I wanted to mention it.

reviews.title: Pudding keycaps are the best
reviews.text:
I have the White version of this keyboard from Nacodex, with Blue Switches. I have to admit, I was mainly drawn to the keyboard for the PBT Pudding Keycaps. I love pudding keycaps because the translucent sidewalls really show the RGB backlighting. If I have a backlit keyboard, I want to *see* the lighting, y’know?

The white tops of the keycaps makes the rainbow backlighting pop even more. Visually, this keyboard looks great. The backlighting turns off after 1 minute of inactivity.

The default lighting mode is a solid rainbow: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, purple. Pressing FN \| switches between the other modes available. To me, most of the other lighting options were gimmicky. One is no backlighting, and the keys light up as they are pressed. Another is rapid breathing. One more is no backlighting and the row lighting up when a key is pressed. And so on. For me, those options are more distracting than having a solid rainbow, or the other sorts of effects I can create with keyboards that have software.

The instructions say there is a Mac mode. As far as I can tell, the Mac mode turns the Alt key into the Command (⌘) key, which is very strange for muscle memory. After a few minutes I switched back to Windows mode, which uses the Windows key for the Command key, like most keyboards do when used with a Mac.

The top row looks to be the F1-F12 row … but it’s not. It’s actually default to be 1, 2, 3 etc. -- but the printing on the keycaps shows F1, F2, F3, etc. This tripped me up the first time I used the keyboard.

My daily keyboard is a TKL, so when I first tried this one, I greatly missed the arrow keys. I wish the printing on the keycaps showed the alternate key options, like a left arrow on the ALT key, or a number on the corresponding F1 key.

The Blue switches are loud and clicky. If this is your first mechanical keyboard, everyone in the house will know you’re typing. I wouldn’t recommend this keyboard for an office environment due to the noise. I’m not complaining about the noise, just mentioning it in case this is your first mechanical keyboard.

Connecting the keyboard via Bluetooth was very easy, I simply turned it on and held down FN + P for pairing mode. When using the backlighting, the keyboard battery lasts for about 5-6 hours. The space bar flashes to indicate when the battery is getting low. The included USB cable is USB A (computer) to USB-C (keyboard).

I am not currently gaming, so I used this keyboard for a lot of writing. I didn’t notice any lag connected via Bluetooth. The standout parts of this keyboard are the rainbow backlighting and the pudding caps.

reviews.title: Nice pudding caps
reviews.text:
I’m currently using the PIIFOXER Pudding Keycaps on my Razer BlackWidow V3 Mini HyperSpeed. This is a 65% keyboard with Razer yellow mechanical switches. Some of the stock keycaps have extra printing for different functions, so I didn’t replace all of the keycaps, but that just makes the PIIFOXER Pudding Keycaps even more noticeable.

Other than the visual effect, I can’t really tell a difference between the PIIFOXER keycaps and the Razer keycaps. By that I mean the PIIFOXER aren’t cheap feeling or slippery or anything like that. They feel nice for long typing sessions.

I’ve had the PIIFOXER keycaps on my keyboard for 3 weeks now and I like them. Pudding caps are my preferred style because they really show off keyboard lighting.

Overall I’m pleased, but I have had problems with one keycap so far. It was sticky. I don’t mean dirty, but that it stuck to the keyboard and was mushy feeling when typing. At first I thought it was the switch, but when I swapped back to the stock keycap, the problem went away.

reviews.title: Abysmal battery life, high form factor
reviews.text:
This is a review for the BlackWidow V3 Mini - Phantom Edition with Yellow Switches (Linear & Silent).

My current daily driver keyboard is a HyperX Alloy Origins Core with HyperX Red Linear Switches. I really like that keyboard and the linear switches, but it takes up a little too much room on my desk. So I like the smaller form factor of the V3 Mini, and the Bluetooth/wireless connectivity options.

The V3 Mini is 65%, which is another plus for me. I tried to go down to a 60% but I can’t live without arrow keys. It does take a few days to get used to the placement of the arrow keys on the V3 Mini, but I use them constantly and like that the keyboard has them.

I’m currently not gaming, so my main use for the V3 Mini has been writing and work. I usually write 1k a day if not more, and I’ve noticed my wrists ache after a long writing session. The keyboard is high profile even at the lowest height setting.

Battery life is abysmal. “Up to 200 hours” is only achievable without using Chroma backlighting and HyperSpeed. The battery indicator is on the back of the keyboard, so I was shocked the first time I ran the battery down. That was after 2-3 days of use. I get about 15-20 hours per charge (and charging takes about 5 hours) with backlighting and connected via Bluetooth.

The switches aren’t silent, but they aren’t as loud as many mechanical keyboards. I think “Silent” is something of a misnomer here. Going on semantics, I expected a silent or nearly silent keyboard. As I said, the switches aren’t as clicky as others, but I can hear myself type with over-ear headphones and music playing. They do feel nice to type with, very responsive and quick.

The steal pudding keycaps are cool but not quite pudding caps in my eyes. The stealth bit means nothing shows on top of the keycaps when the keyboard lighting is off. The letters are printed in a smoky color that blends into the black top. When the Chroma lighting is on, the letters light up. The bottom half of each keycap is also smoky-transparent, so it gives the illusion of a pudding cap, but does not allow as much of the lighting to show as a true pudding cap does. I swapped some of the stealth keycaps for regular pudding keycaps and the difference is very noticeable. I mention this because I cranked the Chroma lighting to its highest brightness when I had all stealth caps, which contributes to lower battery life. Maybe it’s just me, but if I have backlighting on a keyboard, I want to see it.

reviews.title: Lightweight, average sound
reviews.text:
I was drawn to the Logitech G435’s because of the design for smaller heads and how lightweight they are. Headphones that are too heavy or tight give me a headache, and many of the headsets designed for male gamers are just too big for me.

The G435’s are VERY light, weighing in at 5.8oz. That’s light enough to dangle off my pinky finger. Some comfort is sacrificed to reduce the weight -- the headband has no padding. A tightly woven mesh sleeve covers the top portion of the headphones, I can easily feel the frame. I can see the mesh getting snagged if you put these in a backpack or bag, it’s not super durable. The earcups are also some sort of mesh, which I found comfortable for a few hours, but not a super long gaming session.

The earcups do not “lock” or click into position. So every time you put them on or take them off, the earcups slide up and down, and you have to readjust the fit. The earcups are on the smaller side; these headphones are best for kids, teens, or adults with small heads. The description says, “fits a wide range of people but designed for younger players with memory foam ear cushions and sizing for smaller head sizes.” Definitely younger and smaller head sizes, not a wide range of people.

Sound quality is on the lower end of average. Not quite tin can, but “hollow” is the best way for me to describe it. Quite frankly, I expect better from Logitech. I don’t use a gaming headset for just gaming -- I use a headset for everything, including listening to music and watching tv/movies. When I was trying the G435’s and listening to music or watching a show, I found myself reaching for my usual headphones because the sound was just not great.

The headphones do not have any play controls on the earcups, only power, volume up/down, and a mute button.

The headphones have no noise cancelling, and in fact, I thought they magnified background noise. My mom watches videos in the next room and I could still hear her videos over whatever I had playing when using the G435’s. I have other headphones that don’t have noise cancelling but they still block out the background noise. Not so with the G435’s.

Battery life is really good. I did get about 15 hours right out of the box. The headphones charge via USB-C. They are only wireless via the Lightspeed adapter or Bluetooth.

Overall, these headphones are a mixed bag for me. I like how lightweight they are, but the sound quality is not what I expect from Logitech.

reviews.title: A stable headphone stand
reviews.text:
The NACODEX RGB Headphone Stand is exactly what it says: a headphone stand with RGB lighting.

One big plus for me is the lighting works even when the stand is plugged into a USB outlet on a power strip. I have some other headphone stands that will only light up when plugged into a computer USB port.

There are 3 breathing modes and 7 single color modes. The stand doesn’t remember the last set color. Changing the colors is handled by a touch-sensitive button on the top of the base. I don’t love that the company’s logo is lit up, and for some reason the logo is “AJAZZ.” That text is what I see the most when I’m sitting at my desk, not the circle cutouts.

The stand has two USB ports and a 3.5mm aux port, all are located on the back of the stand. I personally don’t use them because I power the stand through my power strip, and my headphones are all wireless.

The stand has a 4½ inch by 4½ inch base. The footprint is small, it doesn’t take up a lot of space on my desk. The bottom has grippy rubber feet to help keep it from sliding about. The stand is pretty stable. I’ve bumped it and tried to knock it over, and it stays upright.

The stand can hold up to two pairs of over-ear headphones. Two pairs looks a bit silly, but it works. The usable height is 10 inches, so there’s plenty of room for big headphones.

reviews.title: Hot-swappable, but installed switches are difficult to remove
reviews.text:
When I use an external keyboard with my laptop, my keyboard of choice is a HyperX Alloy Origins Core with HyperX Red Linear Switches. So of course I can’t help but compare the CIDOO Keyboard and Red Switches to my daily driver.

And I’m pretty impressed!

I’m not currently gaming, so I’m reviewing this keyboard from the perspective of someone who types a lot. I usually write 1-3k words a day and just prefer mechanical keyboards. I like having the option of different switches, and yeah, I’ll admit I like the lighting effects. Typing in the dark is so much easier when I have a rainbow of light scrolling across my keyboard.

The Outemu red switches on this keyboard feel pretty nice to me. They are not silent, but are far quieter than blue switches. I do like that you get a blue, brown, and red switch in the box, so you can actually feel the difference between the switches.

The keyboard is hot-swappable, which is probably my favorite feature. I’ve wanted a hot-swappable keyboard for a while, so that I can try out different switch types without needing a bunch of extra keyboards. The switches are MX-style, so you can swap any MX-style switch onto the board. The box includes a keycap puller and a switch puller.

Unfortunately, the switches are VERY hard to remove. I ended up scratching the keyboard frame when I tried to remove them, and I bent some of the switch pins so badly I couldn’t fix them.

The included cable is braided, USB-C to USB-A. The cable is detachable and measures over 5 feet long.

The RGB backlighting is controlled on the keyboard, you can pick the mode, brightness, and speed. There are 6 different effects: static, wave, star, fireworks, breathing, and rain. The static options are: purple, white, rainbow, red, orange, yellow, green, teal, and blue.

reviews.title: AK351, Blue-White Hot Swappable Brown Switch
reviews.text:
There are different options in this keyboard, so I’ll specify I have the AK351 model, the “Blue-White Hot Swappable Brown Switch” option.

This configuration has white backlighting, blue and white key caps, and brown switches. The white USB-A cable is not detachable.

The keyboard comes with a keycap puller and a switch puller, and 6 extra switches (2 blue, 2 red, 2 brown) so you can try the different types. The keyboard is hot swappable (3 pin switches), so you can swap the brown switches for different ones. The installed switches are difficult to remove; I scratched the frame when trying to change some of them. The keyboard frame is shiny silver with a slight texture, so thankfully the scratches aren’t super obvious.

The instructions are in Chinese and English, the English side is … not very clear. For example, the instructions indicate I can change the backlighting color, but this keyboard only has white backlighting. And so on.

The brown switches are okay. Switches are really a matter of personal preference, and trial and error to find the best ones for you. Browns are tactile, basically between red (linear) and blue (clicky).

reviews.title: Burst Pro Air
reviews.text:
This is a review for the Roccat Burst Pro Air, the new wireless version of the Burst Pro.

“Lightweight” is a bit of a misnomer, the mouse weighs 81 grams. That’s a little heavier than some other wireless gaming mice, but to be honest, once I started using the mouse, I didn’t notice the weight. It’s balanced really well, and the mouse skates are buttery smooth.

The mouse is comfortable in the hand, and this is coming from someone with small hands. I am really picky about mouse feel and shape, this one just feels good. I use a palm grip, so the bump at the base of the mouse gives a lot of space for my palm to rest.

The RBG lighting looks so cool! I have the white version, so the lighting is very obvious. I like how the colors shine through the honeycomb design. Roccat’s software allows you to customize the lighting and other functional things, like remapping buttons, creating macros, DPI switcher, etc. The software is Windows only. The mouse can store five onboard profiles, which is nice. If I use the mouse on a different computer, I don’t have to download Swarm and re-customize everything.

I’m not a big fan of the M1 and M2 buttons. This is my first time using Titan optical switches so maybe that’s why, but the buttons have a bit too much resistance for me. It takes effort to click. Not mushy, but there’s some resistance. I haven’t gotten used to the M1 and M2 buttons after using the mouse for a month. The other buttons feel better, including the scroll wheel.

reviews.title: Comfortable for small ears, decent sound quality
reviews.text:
The Bloody M70 Wireless Earbuds are a comfortable pair of earbuds with decent sound quality.

I have the Red color option, and I have to say, I feel like a Cylon when I turn them on. The earbuds have a red light on the stem that glows when they’re turned on. The case also has red lights on the outside, the lights flash when the earbuds are charging inside the case.

The earbuds last 6+ hours on a charge, I’ve been using them for the last month and haven’t ever heard a low battery warning. The case doesn’t support wireless charging, it charges via USB-C.

The earbuds come with 3 sizes of silicone tips to help get the perfect fit. I’ve tried a lot of earbuds; I have inner ear piercings so many earbuds are not comfortable to wear for hours at a time. These earbuds are super comfortable and fit with my piercings (daith, rook, tragus). The earbuds can also be used independently, so you could use just the left or right earbud if desired.

The earbuds have touch controls, I’m not a big fan of them. It’s very easy to activate a control without meaning to do so. I kept triggering the controls when inserting the earbuds, and then couldn’t figure out why one was off.

reviews.title: Looks great and is functional
reviews.text:
The PhoeniXeries Universal Dual Controller Holder looks great and is functional! It’s sturdy with one controller or two sitting in it.

Assembly is very easy: the clear acrylic holder sits in the base. If you want to take it apart to store it, it’s easy to separate the two pieces.

The base has “PhoeniXeries” printed on one side, but you can hide the logo on the bottom. Either side of the base can be used. The package includes 4 clear rubber grippy feet to put on the base, if desired.

The clear acrylic holder and base do pick up fingerprints and dust like crazy. That’s the only downside I can see. I cleaned it and within 5 minutes, it was already fingerprinted again.

reviews.title: Works great, eliminates need for big Nintendo dock
reviews.text:
I usually play my Switch in handheld mode, it’s more convenient for me. If I want a bigger screen, I might use one of my external monitors, but then I have to rearrange my desk to fit the dock. It’s a hassle, so I was eager to try out the Mumba TV Dock.

The Mumba works great! No more rearranging my desk to fit the Nintendo dock. The Mumba is 6 inches long including the cable, and 1 inch at its widest point. It’s tiny! Small enough to take on the go, if desired.

The Mumba has an HDMI port, a USB-C power port, and a USB-A port. I tried it with my Switch and my phone, a Note 20 Ultra. Samsung Dex popped right up as soon as I plugged the Mumba into my phone.

The USB-C port on the Mumba isn’t too bulky, I was able to keep my case on my phone and my case on my Switch. My Switch case is a Satisfye ZenGrip Pro Gen 3. It doesn’t cover the ports on my Switch, but I do need to remove it to use with the Nintendo dock. So that’s another plus for the Mumba.

The Mumba is made in China. I used it for about an hour to do a Hades run, it was barely warm after that time.

reviews.title: Buttons take force to click
reviews.text:
The Uciefy U26 Wireless RGB Gaming Mouse is … okay. Would I consider it a gaming mouse? No. It lights up, but lights do not make a gaming mouse. The right and left buttons take force to press. If I’m rapid clicking in a game, my fingers are going to get tired very quickly. Other than M1 and M2, the mouse only has forward, backward, and DPI adjustment buttons.

Here’s the biggest strike against this mouse: it doesn’t track on dark mousepads. I was using a light blue desk mat and the mouse worked fine. I switched to a black mat, with a dark green and gray design, and the mouse suddenly stopped working. I flipped the mat out of the way, the mouse worked again. Most gamers I know have dark mouse mats or mouse pads, so that’s a big minus.

The mouse connects via wireless dongle, Bluetooth, or wired. The included cable for wired/charging is USB-C, and it’s actually quite nice. The cable is braided, so it lays flat on the desk and isn’t too stiff.

I connected the mouse via Bluetooth to my Mac. Connecting is easy, but the LED indicator for the mode is on the front of the mouse while the button is on the bottom. So if you’re switching modes, you have to hit the button and turn the mouse over quickly. And there’s no label on the front to tell you the different modes, you have to remember the order or check the instructions.

As for lighting, the light mode can be adjusted, but only the light stripe around the bottom half of the mouse is customizable. The other spots light up green when using the mouse. I do like that the mouse doesn’t have any branding on it, the logo on the base of the mouse is a fierce cat.

reviews.title: Fits original Switch
reviews.text:
The Bheddi Switch Carrying Case is a great value! I have the Black Dex version, and it’s a great match for my Pikachu and Eevee Edition Switch. That’s an original Switch model.

The zipper pulls on the Black Dex case are Pokeballs, very cute. The flap for games has printed characters on each slot, some are Pokemon and some aren’t.

There are two screen protectors included, one for an original Switch and one for an OLED model.

The case is slim, it has a mesh pocket on the upper half but there’s not a lot of room to pack anything bulky in with your Switch. The case itself is a hardshell. It’s not hard plastic, nor is it flimsy cardboard, it’s somewhere in between. It should be protective enough to take on the go.

reviews.title: Comfortable headset, subpar performance
reviews.text:
This review is for the Logitech G735 Wireless Gaming Headset. The headset is part of the Aurora collection, which combines aesthetics and comfort, especially with “fit for all gamers inclusive of smaller head sizes.”

That IS the biggest plus for me: these headphones are insanely comfortable. The ear cups are well padded and so is the headband. This is a headset I can wear for 7 or 8 hours and not get a headache. I rotate between headsets and earbuds because most headsets give me a headache from pressure and weight after a few hours. Not the G735s.

The comfort is the only reason I keep using them, because nearly everything else is subpar. I expect better from Logitech, and I definitely expect better performance for the high price.

I’ve used the headphones for over a month, so I’ve spent plenty of time with them. One of the biggest annoyances is they seem to amplify ambient sound. Part of the reason I use over ear headphones is to block out the annoying noises in my house. Right now, I have the headphones on and music playing. A family member is on the phone in the next room, I can hear every single word of their conversation and the TV show they’re watching. If I take the headphones off, the ambient volume actually drops. It’s like the headset is a mini echo chamber for outside noise.

They shut off randomly and without warning. That is not ideal, especially when gaming! If I’m playing a console game and using Discord on my phone or computer, I don’t always realize the headphones shut off until I get messages asking why I’m not responding to chat.

The headphones also have volume inconsistencies. This happens when audio pauses, due to buffering or if I pause playblack of music or streaming. After the pause, the audio will jump up in volume. Ear blasting volume. I jump every time it happens.

The firmware is up to date, so I know that’s not contributing to the random shutoffs and volume jumping.

Logitech G HUB is required for all customization. The headset connects via Bluetooth or wireless dongle (LIGHTSPEED USB receiver). G HUB can’t find the headset unless connected via wireless dongle, which is a pain.

Once G HUB finds the headset, you can customize the sound and lighting effects. I was disappointed there weren’t more presets for lighting built into the headphones, it would be fun to change that on the fly, rather than needing G HUB.

Battery life isn’t great. I get about 10-12 hours with lighting, and maybe 20 with the lighting off. Turning off the lighting is supposed to get up to 56 hours, I did not have that experience.

Overall, while the headphones are extremely comfortable, I can’t get past the poor performance.

reviews.title: Functional and cute, great for Splatoon fans
reviews.text:
The KeepRolin Squid Joycon Grips are SO CUTE!!! I wish my Switch had 4 joysticks so I could use all the grips at the same time.

The grips fit perfectly on my original Nintendo Switch, Pikachu and Eevee edition to be specific. Putting them on was easy: roll up the slight edges, put the squid over the joystick, and let the sides go. I’ve used some grips that were very hard to put on, in comparison these were a breeze.

The grips can be positioned however you want: up, down, or sideways. I did not notice any impact in play performance from the irregular shape of the squids.

I played a few rounds of Splatoon 3 to see how well the grips would stay in place. I don’t use motion controls, so I use the joysticks for all movement and aiming. The grips stayed in place through every match.

The grips are neon pink and green, like the colors on Splatoon 2 box art. The eyes are raised from the squid head, so there is a bump when your thumb moves over the eyes.

reviews.title: Non-slip, well padded
reviews.text:
I use the DEVASO Wrist Pads for playing my Switch at my desk and also sometimes as wrist rests in front of my keyboard. I have a split keyboard so normal wrist rests don’t work for me, so this 2 pack is great for me.

They are a little higher than other keyboard wrist rests, so they are nice for high profile keyboards. They are big too, measuring 6½ inches at the widest point and 5½ inches at the tallest point.

The wrist rests had a very strong rubbery smell, I had to let them air out for 2-3 days before I could put them anywhere near my desk. The rubbery smell is still there, but now it’s tolerable.

Most of the time, I use them as elbow pads when I play my Switch at a desk or table. The bottom of the pads are nonslip rubber, it’s not sticky adhesive and holds them in place on a smooth surface.

reviews.title: Meh, but still going to use it.
reviews.text: Has a small defect on one, and adhesive not present in one corner. Going to use anyway because its kiddos Switch and he is 6 and doesn't care. If this were on my phone it would have driven me batty.

reviews.title: No more green screen!
reviews.text: Made my 30 yr old NES work like new. No more green screen! You do not need the included tool for installation but you do need it to open the games and thoroughly clean them. A must if trying to get an old system back up and working well.

reviews.title: Quality sound and an impressive Mic
reviews.text:
I used my Sennheiser Game One's as a comparison. In their heyday they were in the $250 range (although they are half that price now, oh technology why do you hate my wallet so much). Anyway, I figured they would be the best set on hand I could test against. Both sets were tested on my system with a dedicated sound card (soundblaster Z) and on my hubby's system without a dedicated sound card. I tested for PC use only, so if these are for an xbox keep that in mind.

Need for dedicated soundcard: First off, while the Senn's require the soundcard to pull enough power and not crash my computer, the Astros proAmp thing either compensated enough to not need one, or this headset is fine without a sound card. Either way, I did NOT need a dedicated soundcard for the Astro's.

Overall sound quality: ok the Senn's sound slightly richer. Not above and beyond but the sound seems "warmer" and more immersive. I'm not saying the Astro's were bad, they passed all the sound tests I ran with flying colors, pulling in a wide range of super low bass and super annoying high frequency. I'm just partial to the Senn's, but the Astros were excellent in their own right.

Microphone: Ok this is where the Astros shined. They isolated the noise better, voice was much clearer, and they triggered Discords auto-enable flawlessly. My Senn's often clip the start of my words even on the highest sensitivity.

Muting: Going with the Senn's on this one, flip mic to mute is just awesome. Astros have an inline mute, that you slide. When muted the LED lights on the proAmp turns red which is a nice visual to know you are muted. Flip up mic is more of a preference, but I’ve heard enough drama in discord from people forgetting to mute than it’s a life choice more than a preference :P

Fifth, comfort: Senn's win this one with a caveat, they are a lot warmer. All that super cush comes at a price, they make your head hot after a bit. The Astros weren't as squishy soft, but they are better ventilated and lighter.

Conclusion: Compared to my Senn’s I say they average out to being equals. Sound is great, the mic is amazing, and all the replaceable parts on the Astros incase they wear out make these a really great set. The only real negative is the instruction sheet. IT IS AWFUL. Seriously they wrote it in like 3pt font in light grey. They have a diagram on one side that is rather pointless and HUGE, then the actual instructions on the back are super tiny. If I were writing a review for instructions alone this would be 2 star review. Thankfully its for the headset, so I’m only dinging them one star for the terrible instructions, lack of cush on the padding, and the price point. For $250 gaming headset you gotta hit all the categories out of the park. These did well, but my Senn’s are now half that price and comparable in performance.

reviews.title: Finally I don't have to nab the one off the dock
reviews.text:
This is a great time saver for when kiddo's Switch travels with him. He can easily charge his Switch without me having to take the one from the dock, which is a pain. Works great so far, I have had zero issues and it seems to charge as quickly as the one that came with the Switch.

If it has any issues in the near future I will update this review accordingly.

reviews.title: Good set, clear sound a little light in base
reviews.text:
These are a great solution if you do not have a separate internal sound card. It comes with a an external usb sound card superior to most onboard soundcards, that you just plug into your pc inline with the headset.

I was hoping these would replace my Sennhesier Game Ones as they are getting old and not what they use to be. However, since I already have an internal sound card and no need for the external usb one the Logitechs just couldn't compete. They are crystal clear and and voices are crisp, more so than my Senn's. But the base isn't as rich and the sound not as enveloping. So they are going to be handed off to hubby.

I would say that if you already have a good sound card, get something better than these within the price range. If you do not, the external USB included on the Logitech is great and these are a great buy within this price range.

reviews.title: Tactile are mushy, but the keyboard itself is great
reviews.text:
Wow this thing solid, I mean it feels durable and sturdy and all around well made. I could probably take out an intruder with this thing, THWACK.

I wish the tactile keys had a little bit more feel to them. They are pure mush, even for tactile. The volume wheel is nice but maybe not the best use of real estate. And the G keys add some width on an already wide keyboard. However, I love the low profile, I have small hands and full size mechanical keyboards can cause a bit of hand strain. It was minimized with this keyboard. Very comfortable typing experience.

I dinged a star for the mushy keys and the price point at $200 is a bit obscene. Otherwise a great keyboard.

reviews.title: Great set, good bass clear mic
reviews.text:
This is a great headset, and the sound (even the bass) was spot on. I ran a sound check and these picked up bass at the very limits of human hearing, which is quite impressive for an $80 pair of headphones. The mic was crystal clear and did a better job of picking up my voice and blocking background noise than my Sennheisers. Playback of my voice was true, which means if you are looking for a mic that adds a richness and depth that isn't actually present in your voice, this isn't gonna do that. Your voice will sound like... you.

The only time I got any static was adjusting the volume when testing for bass, so the drivers were being stressed. Otherwise the volume wheel didn't produce any static.

If you want full noise cancellation these aren't going to get you there. I was still able to hear external noise if it was loud, like someone calling for me. But they are much better than open backed headsets, and muffled out sounds like my computer fan and traffic. They also didn't create that weird negative pressure that some noise cancelling headsets create, which was a huge relief. Personally I found these to be the perfect amount of noise cancelling, I like to know that if someone needs my attention they don't have to tap me on the shoulder to do so. Just shout above a normal speaking voice.

These are very comfortable to wear, not too heavy but not flimsy light. The ear cups are a standard size, if you have large ears and struggle with headsets in general, you may struggle with these. But I would not call them smaller than average. They were a bit warm though. So if heat is something you are looking to avoid, I would say switch to an open set instead, those are better ventilated although they don't do anything to block outside noises.

Overall this is a great headset that performs well above it's pricepoint. Which is surprising since Alienware anything is notorious for being super overpriced, lol.

reviews.title: Responsive and not overly huge
reviews.text:
Responsive and has a ton of buttons, although I wish it was a bit more customizable. Kiddo loves it, although it is a bit big for his kid hands. But not so much so that he cant use it. I would say it is a medium size mouse, good for claw/finger tip grip or even palm if you have small to medium sized hands.

If you have ginormous hands this might feel a bit small if you palm grip.

reviews.title: Fits with PlayStation VR helmet, Amazing sound!
reviews.text:
Connected to iPhone, playstation 4, and blue tooth transmitter for TV effortlessly.

Very comfortable, and the sound is AMAZING. Crystal clear, good range from lower bass up through the higher trebles. No feedback, no rattling, and the best part they fit with the Playstation 4 VR helmet, yay!

Price tag hurts a bit, but they are a great headset so I can't ding them on price. That just seems to be the crazy cost of these things now, sigh.

reviews.title: Decent, springy, good for the price
reviews.text:
This is an all around decent keyboard, although nothing really stands out, but anything under the $100 mark for a mechanical keyboards that doesn't have major issues is a good value.

The keys are loud, clicky and super springy. All things usually like, but oh my goodness the travel on these is forever. If you have larger hands this may not be an issue, but mine are small and I felt like my fingers were sinking into my desk just to trigger the key. My typing was much slower as a result, although the keys themselves were super responsive, no miskeys or ghosting.

I will be sticking with my Razer Ornata, (runs about the same $$$) that unfortunately is not aging well but it has a nice combo of clicky with a shorter travel distance.

reviews.title: One of the best gaming mice for small hands
reviews.text:
It would be great if more companies caught on that not all gamers have giant man-hands or want to palm grip the mouse. For those of use with smaller hands I can't recommend this mouse enough. Now if only they would come out with one this size but with more programmable buttons.

Seriously though, every time one of my female friends or someone looking for a mouse for their younger gamer ask about mice this is my go to recommendation. Particularly if you are a claw or fingertip grip.

reviews.title: Performance depends on your system
reviews.text:
When I got this I was a bit disappointed. Kiddo has an entry level gaming laptop (he's almost 8, entry is about all I trust him with right now) that gets full rather easy and the biggest space hog is his Steam library. I was hoping this would be a quick fix to moving the games off his laptop without a loss of performance. But moving the games took FOREVER and he kept knocking the external SSD around on his small desk. It also gets a bit warm when taxing it, so I called it a fail, and just ended up upgrading his internal M.2 SSD instead.

Since I was stuck with this thing, I decided I would use it as a temporary drive for my desktop. I needed to replace my rather old internal HDD and I didn't want to crowd my second smaller drive. My system is quite a bit better than the kids, with a newer i-7 Intel processor and a freshly installed vid card (GeForce RTX 2080 Super). This made all the difference, the file transfers zipped along including my Steam library. I was able to play games directly from the drive without a noticeable drop in performance, although I play things like Rimworld and Terraria, so I may not tax it as much as some of the more graphic heavy games out there. I was scared to test Ark, that poorly optimized game likes to crash my entire system... @#$%.

I did eventually put everything back onto an internal drive, I like having this though as a nice back up and quick way to transfer items. Some things like tax and other important documents I left a copy on the drive. Just in case my system blows up or has a major melt down.

TL;DR
This SSD Drive's performance is very dependent on your system. Which is going to be true of all similar products.

reviews.title: Not bad considering the price
reviews.text: These are all around not bad for wireless headphones. The sound is where I would expect at this price, actually a bit better since they are under $100. I did ding a star though because they only fit well on my husband. Kiddo and I find them loose and cumbersome. They really are made for an adult male head.

reviews.title: Good set for budget-minded or for kiddos that want an actual headset
reviews.text: Great low price set of headphones for the kid. If he breaks them, as he has so many others, it won't be a huge loss. However, they are still a decent set. On par with his similarly priced Turtle beach set. The noise cancelling isn't the best, but honestly I'm glad for that. I need him to hear me when I'm hollering for him, lol.

reviews.title: Great Portable Swing
reviews.text: This is great for moving from room to room when you need to get things done. Especially if you have a wee one that is only happy when slightly upright. Also works for little trips to visit relatives, fits easily in the trunk.  It's pretty low to the ground, lower than a typical baby swing.

reviews.title: Would have been 4 stars, but ubisoft account requirement is lame
reviews.text:
Decent game but being forced to create a separate ubisoft account to continue playing is ridiculous. Had I known I would have never bothered with the game. That aside the game is pretty and kiddo and I had fun with it. It's not super involved, even the character creation screen is streamlined, which isn't necessarily a bad thing.

I can't in good conscience though recommend a game that forces you to create an account to push micro-transactions on you.

reviews.title: Faulty dongle, alright sound.
reviews.text:
I really wanted to like these. I have a high end pair of the a50s that I love. Kiddo is not ready for something that pricey, but he would be better off with a wireless headset for distance learning. He has to get up and get papers and such that the wire has become an issue. When these popped up for review I jumped on the opportunity.

Fit and Feel:
My first concern was unnecessary, they fit my 8 year old on the smallest size just fine and are light weight so he isn't bothered by them. My husband was able to adjust them out to fit his head as well, so I would say these fit a wide range of head sizes. They really do make you look like a Transformer as another reviewer stated, but at kiddo's age that was a plus not a minus. If they weren't bright white it probably wouldn't be so noticeable. He liked the soft ear cuffs, I found them to be okay. Not super plush but not super cheap feeling either. While being light for him was a plus, I found the headset to feel a bit plasticky and flimsy for the price range. He and I agree to disagree on that one.

Sound:
I like that he can still hear me when he has them on. These are more of a muffled "open" headset than a noise blocking "closed" headset. If you want to block out the world around you, these are not for you. If you want to still hear people talking and what's going on around you, these are good for that.

Sound was just okay. A bit tinny but in this price range most are going to be. At least they aren't over done with artificial bass to make up for it. If you like a rich bass check out Sennheiser, but expect to pay a bit more for it too. The mic was okay sound wise. It didn't pick up much background noise, but it did oddly clip off your last word in both Zoom and Discord. That might be a sensitivity issue on those programs end more than the headset, but it was odd that it did it with both. Our other headsets didn't. I love the flip up mic, I've heard enough people eating while not on mute to wish that it was a mandatory feature :)

Connectivity:
Here is where much of our issues stem from. I was willing to go 4 stars up until this point. But, the dongle is a train wreck. First of all there are no included instructions on how to use it and most of the online instructions are for the transmitter version not the dongle. So you will have to dig a bit to find instructions how to set it up. That is unacceptable in my opinion. It is not just pop it in and use your headset, there is a process...

Also, the dongle plug is too loose to stay in the usb port securely. It jiggles in his laptop, my computer, both of our usb hubs. I popped it into the PS4 and while slightly tighter still looser than I'd like. It also sticks out a bit over 2 inches when plugged in and easily gets knocked out. It also constantly loses its settings and is a royal pain in the behind. Most likely we got a dud, perhaps trying to get a replacement dongle would fix the connectivity issues, but in all honesty it's just too big to have poking out the side of a kid's laptop.

TL;DR
Faulty dongle and flimsy plastic feel make this mid-range wireless headset a bit of a dud. Sound is tinny but okay, mic is fine and flip to mute is amazing, battery life was as expected. Fits an 8 year old all the way up to a full grown man. Bulky but light weight. If it weren't for the faulty dongle, 4 stars considering the price range.... as it came... 2 stars.

reviews.title: Great for Games like Sonic
reviews.text:
Kiddo loves sonic, but trying to play it with a keyboard was impossible (plus I afraid he was going to break it with all the pounding). This controller has been great. He's found many of his games are compatible that he didn't realize would be easier with a controller.

It has TONS of buttons, seriously. Almost too much of a good thing. So far it's been very responsive and no lag.

reviews.title: Some initial issues, but great keyboard now
reviews.text:
This keyboard or more likely the SWARM software, disabled my Astro headset. I tried loading and reloading drivers, changing my sound settings, etc. Finally what worked was trying about 5 different combinations of USB ports on the back of my PC. No clue why it worked but it did.

Now that it is all set up I love the keyboard. I'm still adjusting to the additional key travel over my last keyboard, but I have tiny hands and that is really more the issue than the keys. I love the lighting effects that comes with the swarm software, its mesmerizing to watch. You can also turn off the lighting if you aren't into the lightshow.

I did ding a star because the wrist rest is a joke, it's nearly flat and has hard as my desk, kinda pointless.

reviews.title: Long braided cord, long narrow body style
reviews.text:
Great mouse with some extra buttons but not so many as to be confusing. Body style is narrow but long rather than the super wide style that seems be taking over. I have small hands and used it just fine although if you truly want a mouse designed for smaller adult hands I highly recommend giving the Roccat Kona Pure or Tyon line a try.

The Acer Predator is a nice medium sized mouse and would fit a wide range of hands. It has a high arch, so if you finger touch rather than claw or palm it might not be the best fit.

Responsive and worked as expected. The cord is braided and surprisingly long.

reviews.title: Need two mini battlers for it to work
reviews.text:
The punch guys are actually pretty decent fighters (avoid the ones with ball and chain type attacks, they are useless). I did ding a star because only one mini battler is going to get you no where. You need two for a match.

On that note, I highly recommend getting the battle arena, it allows you to play actual matches and has fun sound effects. Current price for the battle arena on Amazon at the time of this review is crazy, but elsewhere they retail for $30 and is well worth it if your kids like it as much as my 9 year old does.

reviews.title: Super cute
reviews.text: Adorable slim little case for just the essentials. Perfect for slipping into a bag and not feeling like your kid is dragging everything that could possibly get lost to grandma's.

reviews.title: Much better in black
reviews.text: Super easy way to have our PS5 blend in rather than stick out with its glaring white. It was easier to put on than the originals were to take off, but with some patience it was doable. Seems to keep it cooler too.

reviews.title: This game makes studying addicting
reviews.text:
I like most of the mini games quite well. I have a few minor nits. I wish the word search wasn't timed. I don't do those quickly in English, so I lose points when I know the word but can't find it fast enough. I don't see the point of the whack-a-mole game. The concentration game is addicting. I could play it all day long, and it's basically flash cards. The fade out writing is perfect for learning kana and kanji. So is the word card for learning to write words.

There are a few minor bugs (lesson 20 conjugates "Tabemasu" to the negative form as "Nomimasu"). Overall, it's rock solid.

Don't use this alone. It's not enough. As a supplement, however, you'd be hard pressed to find better. Any Japanese student should have this for the way it gets you to drill words and have fun doing it.

reviews.title: Perfectly useful case
reviews.text:
First, I detected no funny smell from this. It smells like nylon or vinyl. Nothing offensive.

I use the straps sometimes, and just ignore them other times. Depends on how much I think the thing will be bounces around in my bag. If you just put the device on top of the straps, they hide out of the way. The case holds the device snugly, and is very well padded.

The zipper is stable, closes easily, and doesn't jam or open on its own. I think that's important for a case like this.

I highly reccomend keeping the little baggie the clasp comes in. It's perfect for storing the super-tiny Sony storage cards. Then you can stuff that in the webbed area and have them together with your system and not easily lost in the case. I find no use for the clasp, but as clasps go, it's a nice, sturdy one.

It's large enough for the AR cards to sit in the top compartment, though a slot for them might have been nice. They don't fit in the webbed area--not quite.

It's a good, basic case.

reviews.title: More of a decoration than a case
reviews.text:
To me a case fully surrounds the unit. This is two separate peices that clip onto the top and bottom, but do not cover the sides, so the protection is minimal. It's not something you slip the device in and out of, it's something you skin the device with. So effectively, it's decorationn. Very nice decoration, but decoration.

I cast this aside in my desk and picked up [[ASIN:B007770QRQ Neon Wallet Case for Nintendo DS- Neon Orange]] as an actual case. I'll pick this back up when I want to turn my blue 3DS red.

reviews.title: Good chat headset
reviews.text:
For chatting, it's a nice headset. It's not going to let you listen to the game via headset (thus not inflicting it on the rest of the room). It's just for chat.

Given that purpose, it's a nice headset. It's lightweight. The cable, while enourmous, doesn't tangle. The on-wire controls are well-placed and responsive. The sound quality, and the mike, are excellent.

It plugs into the USB port on the front of the device, rather than use the XBox trick of plugging into the controller, thus the reason for the 100' cable. That will mean a wire running across the room from the device to the couch (or however you have your system arranged).

If you find it doesn't work when you first plug it in, reboot the system. For some reason, mine doesn't detect the headset if it's pluged in after the system has been turned on. I've taken to just leaving it plugged in and tucked away next to the console.

Overall, it does what it's supposed to do, and does it well.

reviews.title: tricky but good
reviews.text:
As has been mentioned, it is hard to connect the Kinect to this. The latch has to go all the way in to catch properly. I turned mine upside down and then sort of rocked it until it clicked. Make sure you hear that click. It took about twenty minutes. I'm dinging a star for that.

It doesn't clamp to the TV. There is no chance of it scratching the screen. It has a hinged part of the back that forms a triangle with the kinect and the tv providing other two sides. The front loops over the front of the tv for the final support. It is very easy to take on and off.

It blocks the image slightly, but only slightly. It doesn't interfere with game play but would be an itsy bit distracting when watching a movie.

I have my Tv in the corner at an angle and could not find a good place to put the Kinect on the too small TV stand. This solved the problem and gave me a little more play space as opposed to putting it in front of the TV.

Overall I am quite pleased.

reviews.title: Well thought-out
reviews.text:
It takes a little doing to get everything to sit properly. Figure twenty minutes from opening the box to having everything plugged in and charging. It uses the simple, small polarized plug, so it won't interfere with other outlets. It holds the controllers firmly, without scratching them. It does an excellent job swiftly charging the controllers and keeping them charged and ready.

There are convenient slits in the back for the strap from the Move controller.

The indicator lights are bright--bright enough that this thing does double duty as a sci-fi style night light. It's beautiful. I have it tucked in the corner, and am looking for a way to display it better.

reviews.title: Great for kids
reviews.text:
This is a fun, silly sort of platformer where you need to leap over dangers, pick up Smurfberries, and quest to find and rescue Smurfette. It features voices from the movie, and has some very cute cut scenes with Gargamel. You bounce on tomatoes like trampolines for extra height. You have to hop on a frog to defeat it. It's not the easiest game -- I'm a moderately experienced gamer and I had to fight that frog three times -- but it's not all that hard once you get the hang of it. It features a co-operative mode with Clockwork Smurf, so the kids can work together to beat the game. It's a lot of fun, with nothing to worry a parent.

The game, at least in single-player mode, can be played entirely on the GamePad, freeing up the TV. That makes the Wii U the best platform for this game, as all other elements are the same.

It's a fabulous game for children, and a guilty pleasure for those of us who grew up with the first incarnation of these little blue fellows, back in the 80s. I had a great time playing it.

reviews.title: A fabulous game that never forgets it's supposed to be fun
reviews.text:
There is way too much to love in this game.

It records you as you are dancing (or not -- you choose) and, if you have a good sense of humor, you can post it to Facebook, Twitter, or XBox Live (or not -- you choose). You can play with friends. You can play alone. You can play online. You want flexibility? This game trains it and this game has it. You want to just use it to work out? Can do.

There are beloved oldies, like YMCA. There are new hits like Roar. The oldest song I found was from 1956 -- Just a Gigolo. Flashdance, from 1984 is there is well.

You want to sing along? Great! You get extra points for that.

It's all about the fun. Yeah, it'll tell you if you mess up, but it'll cheer you on. It won't boo you off stage like Rock Band can. If won't stop and say "let's try that again" like [[ASIN:B0057PERWU Country Dance Kinect]] will. It won't poke fun. I suspect the design team never forgot that this is a game and never let it take itself too seriously. The result is that it is just fun.

If you've had trouble with other dance games before, you won't with this one. If you love dance games, you'll love this one. If you want a fun, heart-pounding work out game, here it is. If you just want a crazy party game, this is perfect.

I just love it.

reviews.title: Great for when noise cancelling headphones would be a problem.
reviews.text:
This headset is very lightweight and comfortable. It adjusts to a huge variety of sizes.

It's not noise cancelling. In fact, it makes a point of being certain you can hear the world around you. I guess that has its perks, particularly for those planning to use this out of doors -- and for that application this is a perfect headset -- but it means that the volume comes across as pretty low on the PS4, and it can be hard to hear other players, or even in game sounds. I tried it with Assassin's Creed IV, and sometimes I couldn't make out what the characters were saying.

It does a much better job with the WIi U and the 3DS. For those, it hits the sweet spot between being loud enough to clearly hear the game, but not so loud as to keep you from hearing everything else. This is fast becoming my favorite headset for the 3DS.

If you want that great surround sound, where the games closes out the world, look elsewhere. If you want to keep one ear on the game and the other on reality, you're going to have a hard time finding a better headset.

reviews.title: Fantastic headset!
reviews.text:
These are amazing.

There is a separate control for chat volume and game volume. That feature only works on PS3, XBox One and PC. Because they can also use a standard audio jack, they are also compatible with the PS4, Wii U, Vita, and 3DS. There is an additional attachment to use them for your cell phone.

The mouthpiece is detachable, which makes them great (albeit large) for regular headphones.

These are powerfully noise cancelling, immersing you fully in the game experience. The sound quality is outstanding. They have tremendous range and seem to have some sort of built in leveling feature. If your teammate says something just as there is an explosion, the game volume reduces, the chat volume increases, and you can hear both no problem. If two players are talking, one softly, one loudly, it adjusts so that one doesn't drown out the other.

They are far more comfortable than they look, given their size. They are fully adjustable, and sit well on the head. I could wear them for hours. In fact, I may see if I can use them in place of my headset at work, because they are that comfortable and that high quality.

They have switchable side plates, either a montage of marvel characters, or Thor. The montage is very subdued, and isn't all that noticeable at a distance. The Thor plates are yummy.

reviews.title: Amazing sound quality
reviews.text:
It comes with the Xbox One Stereo Headset Adapter, which lets you control the volume and mute the microphone, right on the controller. It clips in on the bottom, right where the XBox One headset would go. You then plug this, or any other headset, into that. You will need to run a software update on your controller, but that's true of any headset that uses the stereo adapter.

The microphone is excellent. I'm told I sound very clear on it when using it for Skype.

The sound quality is fantastic. It is a good enough approximation of 5.1 that I can tell if something is supposed to be in front of me and to the right, or behind me and to the right. Or just flat to the right. It also sounds open. There is space in the sound, which is hard to achieve with headsets. You get that even if you are using them in an mp3 player, a tablet, a phone, whatever. I'm very impressed with these.

I find them comfortable, and I'm fussy about headsets. Many of them feel too tight and give me a headache. These feel nice.

reviews.title: Perfect replacement for a chewed up sensor bar.
reviews.text: My cat chewed through the original (she'll eat pretty much everything, sometimes even cat food). This replacement works perfectly for the Wii and Wii U both.

reviews.title: Great for the PS4, okay for the PS3, not so good for the Vita.
reviews.text:
It has good audio prompts, like "Charging Battery", "Powering On" and "Powering Off", so you are clear on what it is doing, which is cool.

It can pair to the PS4 two ways. You can plug the Optical cable into the USB dongle, plug that into the USB port, and go fully wireless. Or you can use the enclosed audio cable plugged into the PS4 controller. Both are easy to set up. Both work.

For the PS3, you need to plug the Optical cable into the USB dongle, plug that into the USB port, and then go monkey around with the settings until it finally works. That one will work, but it is more of a pain.

For the Vita, or any other media device, it should be simple. You just plug the enclosed audio cable into the headphone jack, turn on the headphones, and you're good to go. Only after a little while it says "Automatic shutdown enabled. Press the power button to cancel." If you press the power button, it says "Automatic shutdown disabled". What it does after that is up to a coin toss. It will either tell you it's powering off and then proceed to do so, or it will stay on. I've yet to figure out the pattern. I would have assumed that I did not press the button, or that it did not register, were it not for the audio prompt that automatic shutdown was disabled. I might have blamed it on the battery if it didn't happen less than an hour after a full charge, and right before staying on for an additional 45 minutes.

It has little blue Turtle Beach logos on either side that glow red while the device is charging, blue when it is charged, and flashes blue when it is in use. I would have preferred a stable light to the flashing, or even no light to the flashing. If I can hear noise, I know it's on. The flashing is just annoying. It has separate volume controls for each earphones and microphone, and audio presets such as "bass boost", "bass and treble boost", "vocal boost" and "natural sound". I favor "vocal boost" for most games and videos, though some games sound better with "natural sound".

They are good for noise cancelling, and the sound quality is excellent. In "vocal boost" mode, videos level (the voices are not drowned out by the special effects) which I very much appreciate. Turtle Beach is known for excellent audio equipment, and the sound quality on this is flawless. Were I judging it by sound alone, it would be five stars.

The microphones attaches and detaches easily, for use as a gaming headset or just earphones. There is a mute button on the right ear, that is quite easy to get to. The buttons are spaced well enough, and distinctively enough, that they are easy to use while you wear the headset.

They are comfortable when worn on the head, but when I wear them around my neck they get grabby with my hair, which is, for me, the biggest negative.

reviews.title: Amazing!
reviews.text:
I am in love with this console.

The graphics are amazing. I love the look of the games on this system. The sound is impeccable. We run it off a 7.1 surround system, and I've had moments where a twig will snap behind me, or a beast will roar off to the left. It is a bit more precise that I'm used to in how it handles locating sound between speakers, by firing both off but not at the same volume. I really love that.

The controller is so comfortable. I had some problems early on with the rubber coming off, but each time Sony was great about quickly replacing the controller. The audio jack on the controller means even the most basic headset can be effectively wireless for gaming. I did not think I would like the touchpad, but now I love it. It has an accelerometer, so for Infamous: Second Son, when you are using the controller like a can of spray paint, you have to turn it sideways and shake it. And the embedded speakers are such, it sounds like a can of spray paint being shaken. The PS3 controller always bothered me a little that it is too easy to inadvertently push down the left thumbpad (so it thinks you hit L3) when you are trying to run around. I've yet to encounter that problem with this one, not even doing the various rundown sections of Assassin's Creed: Black Flag.

Sharing in-game video is quick and easy. It works so well, and so fast. I didn't think I would use that, but it turns out I kind of like sharing awesome moments on Facebook. I'm very much a solo gamer, and the library for that is still very impressive.

If you have PlayStation Plus, your games are backed up online. When I upgraded the hard drive, which is ridiculously simple, I just redownloaded my games, already in progress. It picked up where it left out without a hitch.

For stability, for elegance, for performance, and most importantly, for incredible game play, I give the PS4 five stars.

reviews.title: Fun, flawless, a little harder than I'd expected
reviews.text:
The game is technically flawless. I have not encountered the slightest bug or issue. The graphics are amazing, the story is interesting, and the game play is varied and fun. Sneak around, shoot an invading army, climb a tower... There is a lot to do and a lot of variety. It is a bit harder than, say Assassin's Creed, and it is definitely a sequel, so it would probably be better to play the previous games first but if you want to jump into this one you can. This is the first game I'm playing in the franchise, and it took a bit to get my bearing in it. I think it would be really hard for new players, or players who have never tried any Ubisoft stealth games before.

Fans of the franchise would probably enjoy it.
Fans of stealth games and shooters will find a lot to enjoy here.
Fans of Assassin's Creed will be delighted.
Casual or newbie gamers will be frustrated.

reviews.title: They wimpified my assassin.
reviews.text:
When you first start the game prepare for a long install. This game has been patched, re-patched, and patched again to knock out the bugs, and there are still bugs. In the first section, before even the welcome screen (which is granted something like an hour into the game) I managed to crouch behind something only to have a clipping error trap me there. I had to go in the world map then back out again to refresh the screen layout so that I can move. But that's not that bad. Most of the bugs are gone, and those clipping issues are a running part of the franchise.

There is a companion app with a whack of micropay transactions that is pretty much a required part of the experience. Many chests won't open until you solve a ridiculously easy puzzle in the app. Easy, because the things you're looking for don't move, so you can just remember where they are for the next try. That's a little worse, especially because not all mobile platforms are supported. At the time of this writing Windows Phone (tiny install base, granted) and the Kindle Fire (very large install base) are not supported. If the thing is mandatory, it should work on all platforms. The app also allows you to send out your assassin's on assignment, similar to what Ezio was doing in Brotherhood, except it made sense for Ezio to do that. He was pretty much leading the assassin's at that point. Arno isn't even an assassin when he starts. Also, the forgot the initiation rite from Ezio's time or else it changed past all recognition. The new one is really weird.

Also required is the multiplayer element built right into the single player story line. I mean, you can ignore these things but not if you want to fully complete the game to 100%.

The upgrades are tied to helix credits that you can buy, more microtransactions, which can get kind of annoying especially since they start at $20 and go up to $100, but are, at least, optional. Really optional. Like if you don't buy air assassination, you can still perform an air assassination, you just have to guess when it will and will not work as the option doesn't show up in the UI. It's as if they made the decision to implement the "you have to buy this" feature late in the development cycle, so the programmers just hid it from the interface. You can also do leap of faith before Arno learns it. In fact, you have to do it before Arno learns it.

If anyone was wondering if we lost the modern era stuff in this game, worry not. It's still there. Pretty interesting stuff too.

Arno is wanted, so much so that if he is seen in a restricted area, no matter how many other random people are loitering around, he'll be pursued. So with this in mind, he walks into a police station and randomly offers to help with the crime problem. The only cop on duty isn't all that concerned, neither with a most wanted fugitive standing in front of him, nor with such an odd request, but a bored prisoner sets him to solving murder mysteries. Why? Because they wanted murder mysteries in the game. They're not bad murder mysteries. They just don't fit in at all.

The worse part, is that Arno is the single wimpiest assassin in the entire brotherhood. Eagle vision wears off in a few moments, and needs to recharge. He can't escape battle and heal over time. Like Ezio, he needs healing bottles. Unlike Ezio, he can't find doctors all over the place. He can't counter and do an instant kill. He just gets some extra blows in and if he does it wrong he's off balance instead. His attacks do a lot less damage than any prior assassin. What he gets instead is...he can crouch. Yep, we're giving up unlimited eagle vision, healing over time, and a deadly counter-attack for crouching. Oh, and he can pick locks. So basically we're trading in an assassin for a cat burglar.

If you can, bypass this one and try Rogue instead. Rogue is the real A.C. game out this year, a true successor to Black Flag. This one...had potential for true greatness and gave in to mediocre gimmicks instead.

reviews.title: Study, secure, works well
reviews.text: It holds two controllers well and keeps them charged. It has an on switch on top, which I find odd, and a bright green light on the bottom. There is a clear indicator for when it is charging. It's pretty sturdy. If, say your cat throws it from a windowsill to a hardwood floor it will not be damaged. My cat really needed to test that.

reviews.title: Pickup is weak, sound field is amazing
reviews.text:
It comes with a USB cable to update the controller. I found that odd, but convenient. I can always use extra cables. The adapter has controls to increase game sounds, increase chat sounds, mute the microphone (it lights up if the mike is muted--a very convenient feature) and it can turn up and down the volume as a whole. The audio cable is standard, so you can use it in anything else that works with a headphone. The microphone retracts well enough to be invisible if you don't know to look for it. I used it for a bit with my 3DS and it worked fine for that. The audio cable is permanently attached, and I do not like that design choice. The cable is the single most likely part to break (worse for me because my cat chews these cables, but true in general). A port with a swappable cable would increase the lifespan of these headphones, and would offer choices in terms of swapping to a longer cable, a shorter cable. A more modular design is always a better choice.

It's a good size for a female. The microphone is well places (more on that in a bit) and the headset fits well and is comfortable. It's lightweight, comfortable, and easy to wear for long gaming sessions. The padding was soft without being annoying or sweaty. The ear cups don't annoy the ears the way some can after a long while.

As I said, the microphone sits well. It sits exactly where other headsets I have used sits. For me at least, position isn't a problem. The problem is that the pickup is lacking. If I speak at a normal level--and here I admit to being fairly soft spoken-- it doesn't fully pick up my voice. It echoes in the headset, and does that very well. It reminds me of the studio setup I had back when I was podcasting It's that kind of quality echo back. That's my largest issue with these, and the reason they lose a star. They might have gone to three stars but for the sound field.

The sound field is astounding. I had to keep taking the headset off to see if I was really hearing through the headset and not the speakers. The sounds are directional and adequately distant to give the audio illusion of space and positions in space. I have never heard audio this good from headsets in this price range. That's where this headset truly shines. The sound quality, the range of base and treble, and the sound clarity is impressive as well. In fact, if you're looking for a set so that you can watch shows or play without the noise bothering anyone else, and the mike isn't an issue (or if you naturally have a loud voice) you are going to be hard pressed to find anything better than these.

reviews.title: Keeps the New 3DS XL and three cartridges safe and secure
reviews.text: Holds everything secure.  Survives the cat trying to rip it up.  Slots for three games.  Works perfectly with the new 3DS XL.  Everything a case should be.

reviews.title: Gold is golden
reviews.text: You don't need it any more for video streaming, but for online gaming you do, and the Games with Gold has had some nice offerings lately.  It's pretty much a must have for XBox Owners.

reviews.title: Underrated, don't miss this fantastic game
reviews.text:
This is the true successor to Black Flag, the real Assassin's Creed of 2014.

It almost feels like Unity was where the pencil pushers focused to make sure it has everything the nex gen should, by the books, it follows all the templates, and they pretty much left the Rogue team to do what they wanted. That's how it comes off anyway.

This is perhaps the best Assassin's Creed game yet. From Black Flag, you retain sea battles, navel forts, and whaling. We see a return of building up districts by investing in renovating properties that we first encountered with Ezio. Game play is pretty much as you'd expect from this series, no major divergence from the franchise there.

The story is top rate. Shay starts as an assassin, disenfranchised perhaps, but loyal to the cause. He's a contemporary to Connor, and we see Adewale a few times in the game. Over the course of the story, he sees the unintended consequences of the assassins' actions. He sides with the Templars, not because he believes in their visions of world domination -- and the modern day storyline reminds us that they are the bad guys, this is not a good vs good scenario -- but because he wants to stop the destruction being unwittingly wrought by the assassins.

History is still the playground, and we meet some amazing historic figures, the primary one being Benjamin Franklin. We're running around the colonies during the American Revolution.

I can find no flaw with this game. I encountered no bugs. I loved the story, the characters, the gameplay, and the open world. This is a technically and artistically perfect game.

reviews.title: IGC, Powers, and online gaming.
reviews.text:
You need this to play online on the Sony network.

Members can watch the Powers tv series at no additional cost.

Members get bonus items like themes and such, which is kind of nice.

Members also get the Instant Game Collection. The Thursday before first Tuesday of the month, Sony announces the new IGC games for the following month. They are usually a combination of AAA titles that have been out at least a year and indi games. There are games for Vita, PS3, and PS4 every month and one membership covers them all. Then on the first Tuesday of the month, close to the end of the day, they all show up on the PlayStation store for the picking.

If I had to choose between this and XBox Live, for someone who has both platforms, I'd go with this because of Powers and because there are more, and better games in IGC than in Games with Gold. Membership is definitely worth it.

reviews.title: Quick, simple
reviews.text:
