During the height of the hacks last winter, I was nervous about giving Microsoft or Sony my credit card number. To be fair, the one time my XBox account was hacked, Microsoft issued a refund quickly and let me keep the games purchased fraudulently (nothing I'd ever want to play, so I wish they'd have taken them off my account, but I respect it was a nice gesture). Picking up a code at Amazon and registering it on the XBox was a fast, safer way to pick up digital content at the time.

I've continued to fund my XBox account this way ever since. It may be unfair, but I trust Amazon more. Delivery is nearly instant, and registering the code is fast and easy.

reviews.title: Fabulous headset.
reviews.text:
The sound quality is remarkable. It levels the volume a bit, which I like. I've played a few games (cough AC Unity cough) where the background noise can be loud and then the dialog drops inexplicably. This makes it all a bit more even. The tonal range, bass to treble, is quite good. I noticed no distortion. You can hear yourself in the headset, which I find important. It is very good at blocking out external sound, so don't expect to hear someone calling to you from the next room.

One thing to keep in mind, the microphone can sort of kind of go in backwards, and it's nasty uncomfortable if you do that. It should be set up such that the mike is on the left hand side. I have no idea if it works the other way. I didn't want to deal with that. I do know it seems to click in and it stays. I wouldn't think it should make a difference in terms of comfort, but it does. Even when using them without the microphone, having them not be backwards makes a big difference in comfort.

I found these to be snug, but comfortable. They adjust easily. The mute button is the only button on the right front, so it is easy to access. I would have liked a visual indicator if the mike is muted, but that's a small thing. Again, remember to shut off the chat feature on the Kinect if you want to be able to speak to someone privately (or to not annoy your teammates with the blare of an air raid siren, if you're in a neighborhood like mine that has one -- no air raids, just a peaceful siren to herald in the calm of the weekend).

These charge on USB and they charge fairly quickly. An indicator light on the earpiece tells you if they are charged, and if they are on. And of course the XBox will show you on screen to whom the device is paired.

I know it's not supposed to work with a hub, but I had a spare and I needed this and a keyboard to go into the same port, so I experimented. I used http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00H0PLQHO?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00 as the hub and http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003SVSJ1K?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage as the keyboard and mouse. I then went into Kinect and turned off the Use Kinect for Chat feature. I tried first a Skype call (call testing service) to keep things simple, and that worked. I then tried it in game, and that worked too. I put them in the port on the side towards the front, not the back port--no choice because the back ports are used for external drives but work mentioning as that has given my trouble in the past with the keyboard and I suspect the headset would fare no better. So if you aren't getting a good signal, try that port.

I tried one more thing it's not supposed to do, and it doesn't do it. It doesn't work with the PS4. Unusual, since normally any headset with a 3.5mm connection can work with that. It will function as headphones, but it cannot detect the microphone. If you want one headset for multiple systems, this isn't it. If you want a truly excellent headset for the XBox One, this most definitely qualifies.

reviews.title: No PS3, meh for PC, awesome for PS4.
reviews.text:
As has been pointed out, they do not work on the PS3 as advertised. They are for the PS4 only. There is a separate audio cable that goes into microphone in and headphones out of a PC. When I use that, I get sound in one ear only, so not recommended for that purpose. I'm dinging it one star for lack of PS3 support.

They are very comfortable, and both the headset and sound quality are excellent. Plug them in and the system immediately recognizes them. I needed to go into the accessories menu and lower the volume, because the mike pickup is very good, and I'm excessively soft spoken, The poor guy at the deli has to practically lean over the counter to hear me. These were popping into the red zone for me. They could easily pick up someone calling in from the next room.

The cable is very long, enough so that you can put the controller off to the side without taking off the headset. This would be useful for a game like Final Fantasy: A Realm Reborn. You could talk to your friends, while using a keyboard for emotes and the like (is mine the only group that likes dancing in the dungeon?) The microphone too is fairly long and easy to properly position.

They work well with portable electronics. I used them on an iPad Air and got stereo sound of respectable quality. Pretty much anything with a 3.5mm jack can use them as headphones.

The mute button is easily reached, and one of the main reasons I wanted these. I'm kind of tired of running co-op missions in Assassin's Creed Unity where the other player doesn't have a headset. So they can hear everything on my end, and I can hear nothing on theirs, and I figure I'm probably annoying them with the meow of a cat interfering with the in game sound. So the ability to rapidly mute and unmute depending on who I get paired with matters a lot. It's really easy with these, even without taking the headset off. Just slide the only button (and a fairly large one) on the left earpiece and you're either chatting or silent. Easy.

They take no adjustment, but they need none. They kind of adjust themselves. They don't get sweaty, even in July.

reviews.title: Great value
reviews.text: Very good sound, akin to 2.1 ssurround. You can audiolocate left and right with it. Good pickup on the microphone without an excess of background noise. The microphone is good about not popping the p sounds. The controls are conveniently placed. It is quite comfortable for a long session. It compares well with a few $100 headsets I've tried.

reviews.title: Awesome wheel
reviews.text:
This is pretty much the sweet spot between a basic wheel that lacks force feedback and a top of the line wheel that costs more than a console. It clamps to the table (and do clamp it, or it'll go bouncing around if you crash into something).

It is fully wired. You need to plug it in for power, and the cord is pretty short so you may want an extension cord, and you plug the wheel into the USB port on the PS3 or PS4, so you may need a USB extender if you're far from the TV. I'm playing at about 80 inches from the TV with no issue, but that's close to the limit.

The force feedback is adjustable, at least if you're playing Project Cars, and it's a good idea to flip through the options to find the one that's right for you. It emulates a semi-automatic car with gear shifting paddles behind the wheel. Project Cars at least responds to that. Since I've never driven anything but an automatic, I'm basically flapping them around trying to get a sense of what they do. The wheel is comfortable to hold and turns easily enough, but with a little more resistance than a real car. The pedals are big, close enough to the size of the pedals in a real car as to make it hard to notice the difference. If you are playing on a hardwood floor the pedals will slip around. Get a welcome mat to put under them when they are in use and they will stay put, this assuming you are attaching the wheel to the table and not going all the way with a frame setup. The pedals are responsive and adjustable. In the default configuration the break offers more resistance than the gas.

The PS3/PS4 switcher is fairly hidden in the front behind the wheel, as it should be given you will be using that switch least of all. You have full controls for both, including a dpad, options, share, and the triggers (but not the bumpers L1 and R1 that I've seen) right on the wheel. Project Cars (can you guess my favorite PS4 racing game?) recognized it with no configuration required.

Overall this is a lot easier and a lot more fun than racing with the controller. I'm having a blast. Now if only I could stop crashing into the walls.

reviews.title: Go buy Rock Band instead
reviews.text:
You need to pair the guitars to the USB dongles. Unlike say Rock Band where they are just Bluetooth. If you buy the two pack, good luck remembering which dongle goes to which guitar.

You can't buy songs, to play over and over, it's more a jute box situation where you buy plays. The good news is you can earn them in game. The bad news is you have to play whatever it throws at you to get them.

The controller disconnects repeatedly, so the game puts up an error message, but the notes keep coming. New batteries didn't help. Clear line to the dongle didn't help. The thing just doesn't work.

You can't calibrate the game manually. At best you can let it sort of figure it out on its own. At best, it suggests putting the TV in game mode. Calibration was a well-established technique back in Gen 7.

reviews.title: Mindblowing!
reviews.text:
I've always liked racing games. I can't say they were ever my favorite genre, but I enjoy them. I played Forza 4 on the 360 with an economy wheel and had a splendid time of it.

Playing Forza 6 with this was an entirely different experience. My hands were shaking; my heart was pounding. It has been a long time since a game did that to me. The wheel fights like a real wheel. You go into a skid and you need to struggle that wheel to go where you want. It's not so much strength as skills, and it's amazing. If you release the wheel slightly, like you might in a real car after a turn, it rights itself exactly as a real car will. It turns pretty much as much as a real car's wheel will in any direction.

You can, of course, attach it to a table or something like -- it connects with a small clamp tightened by two knobs on top that look like buttons (twist them if you're having trouble and the clamps with slowly descend or ascend) but if you're going to go with a wheel of this quality, you may want to go all the way with a wheel stand. It makes a difference in comfort and stability. On the folding table I tried the table tipped, the whole thing shifted around, and it was bad. With even an entry level stand, so long as it has a board to clamp this too, it is perfect.

If you want the most intense racing experience possible, you want this wheel. There are cheaper out there, but the quality difference is severe.

reviews.title: Great for PC and XBox
reviews.text:
My only complaint is that I could not find the mentioned App on the XBox One. Perhaps with the Windows 10 update.

You can change the color, and it goes through the entire spectrum, right from the controller. It has a very long (I think ten feet), very stable, not prone to tangle cable. It is responsive, has good rumble features and works well on both the XBox One and the PC. I've been using it to play Halo: Master Chief Collection and I've yet to find it lacking. On the PC side, I've played a little Splinter Cell: Blacklist and so far it is perfect. Definitely the best controller I've ever tried on PC. I'm running the game in Steam on Windows 10 if that matters.

reviews.title: Cute little Yoshi
reviews.text: These are so cute.  Completely knitted, stitch perfect, and absolutely adorable.  They have the rfid tag and so will work with some Amiibo compatible games, most notably Yoshi's Wooly World (for those who bought it digitally or not the bundled edition).

reviews.title: Lightweight and responsive
reviews.text:
It's hard not to compare this to the Elite.

On the plus side, it is lighter and feels better in my hands. It's easy to configure the buttons and the triggers are very responsive.

On the minus side, the components don't interchange, the buttons on the back are smaller, and might be a bit too small. The most important consideration is that this is strictly a wired controller. If you are using it on PC, great, and it does work nicely on Windows 10. If you are using it on the XBox One, the cord is on the short side. You will want a USB extension cable.

Overall, I love the feel of it, and I adore the responsiveness.

reviews.title: Not the best
reviews.text:
I had some problems getting the microphone to work on the XBox One. I might have a bad unit, but it gave me a bit of trouble before it was able to pick up my voice. The quality on listening is great, but the mike is mediocre at best. I have to raise my voice to have it picked up well, and I'm not used to that from any other headset I've used.

Normally a headset like this, with an audio jack, would be able to double as normal earphones, and this one only can with some devices. The Kindle Fire yes, my phone no, the audio equipment at the gym no, True, it says it's only for PC and XBox, so I'm giving it three stars. For the most part it does what it says it does, once it is set up properly, but that's the limit.

reviews.title: Clumsy interface and nothing seems to work
reviews.text:
I so wanted to like this system. It's a mess.

First off, the interface is clunky as all get up. I could not figure out how to get to what I was trying to click on. For the Crunchroll app (one of the few video streaming apps that is supported, more on that later) I had to use the arrow on the remote control (not included, and a useful accessory) to get to the search button. The arrow is a button that does not look like a button on that controller. You make the cursor go away by pushing any other button. The shift is like the shift on a keyboard, not a phone. You need to hold it down to get a capital letter. With a Lego Yoda game, I could find no way to click on the choice between dark and light side. Some of the games work, but it's hit or miss.

I set the system default language to English, so the games kept defaulting to French. For the farming game that comes with it, I could not see how to swap it before the tutorial began.

I am using an Ethernet connection so the system keeps saying it won't download until I connect to WiFi (clearly it checks for WiFi and then assumes I'm on a cellular plan). This gets annoying.

The main feature is its ability to stream GameFly games, but the game lists are paltry. The plans are by genre, so if you want say family games and action games, you need two subscriptions. Not that there is much to recommend any of the packages. Most have few games, and only one or two popular ones per subscription.

Forget streaming video. Crunchyroll, Crackle, and HBO Go were supported, and YouTube of course, but no Hulu, no Vudu, no Netflix, no Amazon Video. The pickings are sparse. Crunchyroll did not stream cleanly, but rather had an odd border around the video.

That leaves the ability to stream pc games to the device, in the odd situation that your PC does not have an HDMI port (a splitter will let you put out to TV and monitor both). I found that of dubious value since my PC already goes to the TV at need.

I love the idea of an Android gaming platform. I loved the Ouya. This is a sad entry.

reviews.title: Very good game
reviews.text:
I know this game has its detractors, but I am enjoying it quite a lot. Aside for the near constant presence of rats the size of cats (yes, we have them; no they don't run down the streets in anything like those numbers but rather haunt subway tracks) it's a perfect rendering of New York. There have been many times I don't need the overhead map to show where I am to go. I know the neighborhood. I've been there.

It is absolutely a tactical shooter, and you will find it much easier to defeat the opponents if you think in terms of the best tactical approach rather than charge in recklessly (indeed, it's nearly impossibly to finish any of the missions by charging in recklessly). You need to keep cover, keep a positional advantage, and not get surrounded. You need to use the terrain to your advantage.

It's good for single player and especially good if you can get online with a friend or friends and play together. The story is engaging, the gameplay is strong.

You can do hunter/gatherer missions, getting data and supplies to build up your base. You can do shoot the enemy missions (rescue hostages; drive off the bad guys). You can go head to head with other players in the dark zone. Whatever suits your whim of the moment. It's a rich and varied experience.

reviews.title: The best Rock Band 4 guitar
reviews.text:
To assemble this thing (crazy simple in case anyone was concerned).
Add the included AA batteries.
Unfold the guitar and use the latch in the back to hold it open.
Click on the head (easy snap on)
Add the strap (just put the hole in the strap around the disks on the guitar.

To pair it, on the PS4 go into settings and devices.
On the device, turn it on and then all the way on the bottom on the side that has the PS button there is a sync button. Press that.
Back to the PS4, this should have shown up as a device. Select it.

What I like:

It folds, and once you get the hang of it, it folds quickly and easily and does not unfold unless you want it to. There is a latch on the back that keeps it open or closed. It's a little stiff at first, but loosens up just a bit after a few uses. It's small, unobtrusive, and effective.

It's a tiny bit more responsive than the guitar that launched with the game, but keep in mind this game is all about responsiveness. Of course it has the double set of frets (top and bottom) that were introduced with Rock Band 4. It does everything the launch guitar does.

What I don't like:

Nothing. There is nothing here not to like.

reviews.title: (Here I'll say I actually liked Assassin's Creed and Watch Dogs
reviews.text:
Remember how everyone said Assassin's Creed 2 saved the Assassin's Creed franchise, and how they were hoping Watch Dogs 2 would do the same to redeem Watch Dogs? They got their wish. (Here I'll say I actually liked Assassin's Creed and Watch Dogs, but I cannot deny the sequel is far superior).

There is a twist of humor here. There are a lot of options to get through a mission. There are many side quests, and you can cause a lot of trouble.

For interface, it's by and large the same fare you're used to from Ubisoft. You have an indicator to follow. It tells you how far your destination is. All that. You can sneak up on guards and take them out. Or you can sneak past them. You can hack machines to lead them into traps. You can hack phones or traffic lights or whatever for distraction. There are a lot of options.

I found the story compelling enough for a game (or even a movie; it was really good) and the gameplay especially excellent.

I haven't had much experience with the multiplayer, but that's not really my thing anyway. As a single player experience, it makes up for the lack of an AC game this year.

Loved it.

Hack the planet.

reviews.title: Good sound, tricky setup, no way to make it wired.
reviews.text:
The main issue I have with this is updating the firmware.

To update the firmware, I need to first connect it to the app and have the app recognize it.
To have the app recognize it, I need to first update the firmware.

I've tried different computers, different ports, different cables. It's just a chicken and an egg. Fortunately, even without the update, it does sync to the XBox One, and the sound quality is excellent. The chat is about average, which is all you need from chat.

It is strictly what it says it it, for XBox wirelessly ONLY. It syncs the way a controller syncs. There is no port for an audio cable to connect it wired if the battery dies. There is no way to sync it to anything else, except maybe a PC with an adapter. Charges with a standard micro-usb cable and the charge time is pretty quick.

reviews.title: Convenient, small footprint
reviews.text:
This has a very small footprint, which is quite convenient. The controllers sit in it facing each other, which offers some protection on the more visible parts (this is a good feature if you have pets). Seating the controllers is easy. It seems sturdy and well-made.

I have only one issue with it, and that is, when the controller is seated, the light is completely covered. Now this is great, since this sits in my bedroom and the light won't bother me (of course it has its on remarkably bright green lights to contend with) but this isn't great because I depend on the light to be sure I've seated the controller properly and that it is charging.

reviews.title: and it's fairly easy for a small thing to slip into the case ...
reviews.text:
It's limited in how well it protects the JoyCons. Basically there are two flaps that fold out and you place the front of the joycon into the slots there. There is nothing on the back or the sides of the JoyCons. I would have preferred more protection for those. The speakers are exposed, and it's fairly easy for a small thing to slip into the case and scratch up the system. But then, I never liked tablet or ereader cases without sleeves, so maybe I'm just excessively protective of my stuff.

There isn't much in the way of padding. It's a hard case. I'm of two minds about that.

It does hold the Switch in three positions and seems stable in all three.

reviews.title: Sturdy and does a good job.
reviews.text:
This is a very sturdy stand. The cat has knocked it to the hardwood floor twice, and twice it was fine afterwards. I think something like this needs to be a bit on the sturdy side.

Beond that, it charges the joy con about as quickly as having the switch in the port. It holds them securely, even through a fall. It doesn't take up a lot of space. For its purpose, it's perfect.

reviews.title: High quality; good value
reviews.text:
There are two things I especially love about this headset. The first is the weight. It's extremely light, so it is a comfortable headset to wear for a long gaming session, or a long session of teleconferences, or maybe a bit of both.

The second thing is the sound quality. At the price point, I didn't expect much and I was pleasantly surprised. These stand on par with some of the more expensive headsets I've tried. I wouldn't say they're the best -- they aren't going to deliver the quality of a $200 Turtle Beach for example -- but they're good enough for most purposes, excellent for gaming, and a good balance of cost and quality.

The headset plugs into a PS4/XBox One Controller (or a Nintendo Switch or a cell phone or anything else with a single jack for headphone and mike) and it comes with an adapter to split the input and output so you can plug it into the PC, and the cord is suitably long for both purposes. The microphone control is on the wire. The headphones fold for easy storage.

reviews.title: Comfortable and good sound quality.
reviews.text: Excellent sound quality, both in picking up in game sounds and in chat with party members. The microphone pickup is excellent. It's quite adjustable both in terms of size and in terms of volume, and the volume control is, quite sensibly, on the wire where you can see it. I prefer that to on the earpiece, which is invisible to you when you're wearing the headset. It's a comfortable headset, even if you're wearing glasses.

reviews.title: Really good surround sound
reviews.text:
What I like best about these is I can wear them with my glasses without any problem. Some headphones are really unpleasant with glasses.

The sound quality is fantastic, especially for multiplayer. I can hear my party and hear my game at the same time, and it emulates surround sound perfectly, so I can use it to audio locate my enemy. Or an in game cat. Okay, I mostly use that to locate the in game cats. There's a trophy if you find them all. But I mean I switch from an actual 7.1 surround sound system with speakers spaced around the room to the headphones if I'm really struggling to find that cat because the headphones are a bit more precise.

Anyway, the mike pickup is good, or at least no one has complained. I have tried this with the XBox One and with the PS4 and no issue with either.

reviews.title: Great sound and quality mike
reviews.text:
I use this primarily on the PS4, so I can't say how it will work on other systems. For the PS4, it's great. The sound quality is fantastic, and the mike is great. It's very comfortable for semi-long gaming sessions. I don't get long gaming sessions. I have to adult. :( It does let you audiolocate in game, same as a classic 7.1 speaker setup.

I wear it with glasses no problem.

reviews.title: For better or worse, it's huge; not good screen protection
reviews.text:
It's a very large case. The good? You can fit your Switch, extra joy cons, extra pro controllers, cartridges, plugs, pretty much everything you need, and there are spacious internal pouches to hold it all.

The bad? It's huge, which means it's bulky to lug around. I only carry my Switch, ear buds, and maybe a cable. There is way more space here than I need.

So, depending on your use this is either a feature or a bug. I'm not going to ding it. It set out to be huge.

It has a good handle. No strap, which is a bummer. I am dinging it for that given the size.

The inside is a little discombobulated. The console straps in behind a pouch. It takes a bit to figure out where everything is supposed to go and nothing separates the Switch from the remaining contents of the pouch. I don't find that choice of design suitably protective. If I turn the Switch face in and try keeping, say a wall wort in there, the Switch could easily be scratched. If I turn it face out, that's bad for the joysticks. If I disassemble it and turn it face it, it slides too much. I'm dinging a second point for the lack of good protection.

reviews.title: Duck Hunter with Zombies
reviews.text: This puts me in mind of the old Duck Hunter game from way back when, with the plastic gun ("it's also good for hunting hedgehogs" ;) ).  It's not trying to set itself up as a serious, plot driven game in the vein of Last of Us. It's setting itself up to be some family fun, and I feel it succeeds. It's a modern game with old school charm. I'm loving it.

reviews.title: The headset I use every day
reviews.text:
I have the wired version. In the whole pandemic work from home situation it has been my go to headset for work and for foreign language class and for virtual hangouts with my friends. In other words, I wear this headset most of the day. It's comfortable enough for that. I wish I could do more gaming with it. It has excellent sound and audio location ability in games. I love this one.

Simple USB plug in. No other audio connections required. Simple on headset mute button and an indicator light on the mike tells you that you are muted.

reviews.title: No meaningful volume control
reviews.text:
I have tried everything to get the volume of this down. The on device controls do nothing. The PC is set to 1%. I still have to keep them off the ears somewhat because they are entirely too loud.

The microphone is good. The battery life is good. Setting it up is easy. I'd love to give this a perfect rating for all of these. Aside from the volume issue, they're quite comfortable.

Highly recommend for some who is hard of hearing. I can't think of a better headset on the market for that user group. For everyone else... Better to avoid.

reviews.title: Poor sound quality
reviews.text:
I'm using this on an iPad with nothing more challenging than Duolingo. The sound is distant, tinny, and off. I would not want to try to game with this headset, or listen to an audiobook, or watch any kind of video, or heaven forbid listen to music. I'm not a fan. It sounds about the way I'd expect a video tape from the 80s to sound today after forty years of decay.

At best, this is a headset I might use in a situation where I might lose or damage it and want one I won't care what happens to it.

reviews.title: Good sound quality; good mike; comfortable
reviews.text:
I use this primarily on the PS4 to play Destiny 2 with a friend. It's perfect for that. I can hear him and the game. He can hear me no issues. Background noise isn't much picked up by the mike, which is good. I can somewhat audiolocate with these--not as well as when I'm using regular surround sound, but not horrible. They are comfortable for long sessions.

I'm using them for our weekly sessions and I have no concerns so far. They're perfect.

reviews.title: A bit too large fo rme
reviews.text:
I found them a bit on the large size. For a man they would be perfect. Because of the loose fit, they didn't do much for noise cancelling, but that's fine for my purposes. Again, a man might have better luck.

I use them for some gaming, but mostly for work because of the fear of them slipping off. I have to admit, for that, they are really comfortable. They don't interfere with my glasses. They have excellent pickup and audio. I've done meeting marathons in them with no issues. So I'd say sound quality and mike quality as on point.

Overall, on a technical level, there is nothing to complain about any anyone who needs a really big headset will love these.

reviews.title: A little tricky to set up, but good
reviews.text:
For pairing with a Windows 10 PC, ignore the instructions. Turn the controller on and hold the pairing button for a few seconds. Go to Bluetooth and other devices. You see the option Everything else that references XBox controllers? Ignore it. Click the top option Bluetooth. Mine paired in less than a minute, then proceeded I not to work. I rebooted and that looks like it did the trick.

Tested with UPlay. It works.
Tested with XBox App for PC. It works.
Tested with Steam. For me it didn't work at first. I had to go into Settings -> Controller -> General Controller Settings and enable XBox Configuration Support. After that it worked with no issues.

I am a dedicated console player who wants to get into the PC gaming space, both because of UPlay plus and there are many excellent PC games I want to play, but I want the familiar interface of the controller. Yes, I know, dedicated PC gamers praise the keyboard and mouse as the ideal interface. I'm just not used to it and I'm not of a mind to change right now. Yes, I'm connecting my PC to the TV via USB. Please feel free to cringe. Given that, this controller gives me everything I'm lookig for. I think it's awesome. It requires no dongle. It uses common batteries. It feels identical to the XBox One/Series X controller (they aren't all that different). It's everyting I want in a PC controller.

reviews.title: Excellent controller
reviews.text:
I have this set up to my PC. Having set up a similar one, the second was much easier. This pairs no issue. It is very responsive. It feels great in my hands. It disappears. It does it's job so well you can immerse in the game and forget the details of the controller. That is the ideal.

The only thing I don't like -- not enough time to play.

reviews.title: Good for work or play
reviews.text:
Really good sound quality. Good pickup on the mike. I use this for work and gaming and it's comfortable enough for long gaming sessions and even 6 hour meetings (yes, we have six hour meetings -- I think I work for Mestapholes). USB connection. Decent cable length. On cord volume control and mute.

Great quality and a great value

reviews.title: Perfect if you never want to use controller accessory add ons
reviews.text:
I'm spitting the stars because what it does well, it does perfectly and what it does badly it does not at all.

I have the original Switch. It works on that no problem. The haptic feedback is more pronounced than in the default Joy Cons. It's easier to hold. It's comfortable. All things perfect.

It had an atypical shape and can't fit any of the accessories. The tennis racket. The golf club. Anything you'd want to putt a Joy Con in won't worth with these at all.

So if all you want is a standalone controller, this is beast of breed. If you want full features including compatibility with expansion units, look elsewhere.

reviews.title: Can't type. Gaming
reviews.text: This is great for keeping the batteries charged and ready to go. Since the XBox 1 and XBox Series X use cross-compatible chargers, this works for both. It charges fast.  It's small and out of the way. It keeps little things like battery life from getting in the way of your gaming. I found no issues worth mentioning. The cat has knocked it off the dresser a time or two and it didn't break, so points for sturdiness.

reviews.title: Fun
reviews.text: They're basically just plastic props for the JoyCon, but they're a lot of fun. They're sized for small children, naturally, but adults can play too. They have been abused a bit here, with no damage. They're sturdy and they clip onto and off of the JoyCon easily.

reviews.title: Cute and they work well
reviews.text: I used this for daylong Zoom calls during the pandemic, largely because they were cute and people found them amusing. They were surprisingly comfortable, given they look like they were made for kids. The sound quality is excellent. I still use them a lot for PC gaming and the less frequent (or at least no longer all day) Zoom calls.

reviews.title: Very sturdy
reviews.text: My Switch took a tumble down a flight of stairs in this thing. Nothing broke. The memory card didn't even pop out. I was glad it had this kind of protection. It's a cute case, and heaven knows Animal Crossing was a defining game of its era. I'm in love with this case.

reviews.title: Lots of room
reviews.text: This is roomy. I can keep the Switch in there, along with a cleaning cloth , cables, and a few other things. I even keep a few pages of game notes in there, and the occassional printout of a bit of walkthrough. It holds up well for travel. I use it for the orignal Switch. The OLED might have a little less room, but I don't doubt it will fit. It seems like that would be perfectly fine. It's well padded. I recommend it.

reviews.title: Noise cancelling is perfect
reviews.text: Very comfortable. Excellend sound quality, with excellent virtual surround sound. It's good for work and for gaming, though I prefer it for gaming. The best thing is when there is a lot of noise external, such as my roommate screaming at her mother on the phone (nothing bad -- her hearing is going) and I can hear my game over all of that. It's got great noise cancelling features. This might be my favorite for gaming.

reviews.title: Great given the price point
reviews.text: I used these mostly for pc gaming to be honest, and they're great for that. The mike has good enough pickup I can use it for podcasting. The sound quality in the headphones is perfect. I wouldn't say these are the best I've ever used, but at the price point, I'm far from disappointed. I will say they might be uncomforatable for a larger man. They ran a little small. As a rather small woman, I had no issues. They are well-padded and comfortable for long gaming sessions.

reviews.title: Really good noise cancelling
reviews.text: These are beautiful. I've used them on a few long Zoom calls because they are comfortable, and I've gotten some laughs because they look so serious. They are good at noise cancelling. For a while I had an air raid siren go off every Friday night and I could hear the call over that with these. That's serious noise cancelling right there. Without them, I'd have to tell the other participants to hang on a moment, our siren is going off (no, we don't get air raids here, it's just a Shabbos alarm). The microphone has good pickup (just had to mute during aforementioned sirens) and doesn't tend to pop a lot, which is great. They're very adjustable, size-wise, so I'd say they'd work for a larger guy just fine.

reviews.title: They hold the joycons well and they're fun
reviews.text: They're basically plastic add-ons for the joycon and don't do much on their own. That said, they fit the joycon perfectly. They're a lot of fun and I've dropped them a few times without breaking them. I like that the tennis rackets have a strap after the fiasco with people losing control of their wimotes back when.

reviews.title: good dev mouse
reviews.text: This mouse isn't just good for gaming (I mean it is good for gaming) but if you're using a visual IDE for software development, this is good for laying out your screen. You can get the kind of precisios you need for either purpose. I've used it a little with Photoshop for some light editing, and even there, an applicaiton for which mice are generally ill-suited, I liked the precision of this one.

reviews.title: A bit of a grind, but fun
reviews.text: Definitely play Far Cry 5 first. This is a direct successor to that game. There is a lot of grinding to be done here, or at least I had to grind a lot, which makes it a bit of a slog at points, but the world and the story are interesting enough to make up for it. The gameplay is excellent and it kept me well entertained.

reviews.title: Good for PC
reviews.text: I am using this as a PC gaming controller. I plugged it in and it was immediately recognized. It works with the Xbox app. It works with Steam. It works with the older Assassin’s Creed games, like Revelations, where I’ve had a problem with PC controllers (granted, wireless) in the past. The cord is a good length. Long enough I can sit back and game. No so long it is prone to tangling. Responsive. Comfortable. Absolutely no issues.

reviews.title: Boring
reviews.text: There isn't much to this game. It reminds me of some of the old homebrew games from the Commodore 64 era. It crashed a few times too for extra nostalgia. I'd give it a hard skip.

reviews.title: Great for fans of classic turn based rpgs
reviews.text: An RPG horror game with 9 different endings. I found the gameplay a little repetitive at times, but the story more than makes up for it. It's a nice blend of classic turn based rpg and modern gaming. You don't see as many turn based games these days and this is an excellent one.

reviews.title: FINALLY! iPad Running iOS 7? This is for YOU!
reviews.text:
Let's face it, Apple has been a bit late in the game (pun intended). But what can I say, I still love the iPad.
Touted as the only wireless controller given the Apple stamp of approval, and the third iOS controller ever made, this Danish designed item packs a lot of punch in a small device.

There are two easy-to-use joysticks that really move once you get used to them, a D-pad, X, Y, A, B, and a player readout.
But here is where this item stands out, and why Apple sanctioned it, in my opinion...on the top, Trigger buttons L1 and R1 with nubbies to prevent slipping, and behind them an L2 and R2. Micro USB port on the bottom, and Bluetooth on the side.
If you are buying this as a gift, know that the above-mentioned is important because it means a greater compatibility with more complex games coming 'round the bend.

How amazing to get so much on such a small controller! And that may be a negative for some. As a female, the size is perfect and easy to transition to, but a guy with large hands might have an issue with it. Your middle fingers grip an indentation on the back, I suspect it might get crowded back there for a someone with big paws. There is a snap on piece that might make it more comfortable for men.

The charge lasts between 8 to 10 hours.

So, like anything, it takes some getting used to. But it gives another functionality to your iPad, and certainly travels well. More options than the Moga.

reviews.title: Legends Speak of a Place Where WORLDS COLLIDE...
reviews.text:
...IN 20 MINUTES!
The hero/brawler Heroes of the Storm is no longer lurking in Starcraft.
This is a jump in, battle first, kind of game, and this gaming headset reflects that ideology 100%. When WoW or LoL is close, but not quite what you're looking for (or have time for), Heroes of the Storm might be a good fit, and this headset brings it all home.

Turtle Beach specializes in gaming audio, and make no mistake, these are for gaming first, all else is a distant second. Yes, you can listen to Bon Jovi or Taylor Swift. But why would you want to? With an ability to pick up the tiny crackle as well as the layered boom, you get the full gaming experience.
Super comfortable over-the-ear padding and an easy adjust mic that detects a whisper. Customize with skins and plates.
This world is yours.

reviews.title: Cool Headphones at a Value Price
reviews.text:
These headphones are lightweight, making them comfortable when it comes to long gaming sessions.
They cushion your ears, adding to the comfort level...and they adjust for a perfect fit.

But the biggest draw is how cool they look.
And under twenty five bucks? That's a steal! GREAT gift for teens.
Sound is fine for kids and teens.

DISCLOSURE : Product received to test with the option to review. No financial compensation is EVER accepted, and vendor may request that item be returned.

reviews.title: In it for the Long Haul
reviews.text:
Besides being comfortable, these have a great sound for gaming.
Had the best experience with Destiny, terrific immersion with sharp crashes and thunderous bass. Enough to scare ya, ha ha!
The mic is quite good as well. Easy access mute and it folds away if you don't want to use it.

Lets face it, most of us will have these on for long stretches at a time.
They are super light, so even all nighters are comfortable.

reviews.title: Your grandkids will be read this
reviews.text:
American Sniper had been on my wish list long enough. With the touted movie released it seemed high time to read it.

There's been a number of 'out of the sandbox' chronicles out of Iraq and Afghanistan and of varying quality. Among readers of first person experiences, Sniper reflects a keen similarity with [[ASIN:0891419063 With the Old Breed: At Peleliu and Okinawa]] by EB Sledge. If you're familiar with Sledge's "Old Breed", I can hardly say more to triumph the Sniper. The style makes Sniper the best of the modern first person narratives. Your grandkids will be reading this one.

reviews.title: As advertised, as expected.
reviews.text:
Why did I buy it? Fortnite.

Can I reduce action speed lag? Will this new wired controller keep me getting whacked less often? So far so good.

reviews.title: Increases targeting accuracy
reviews.text:
Game - Fortnite 24/7

These grips extend the thumb switch lever to effectively provide an instant improvement in precision and accuracy. That's the surprise here. The silicone tops will likely be comfortable once my thumb calluses fall off.

reviews.title: Light weight and cool
reviews.text:
I got these as an Xmas gift for my G-son. My G-son plays Fortnite in full chat mode … for hours. He's got a mid tier headset but ear sweat, weight and mic fidelity are handicaps.

Gaming headset's are a mixed bag. Price and "quality" don't necessarily correlate. So, I had to try them. My benchmark is my own Bose QC-35's. The first thing noticed is the cool gel pad, light weight and comfort.

The sound quality is excellent and software adjustable. I didn't take the time to mess with THX, 7.1 etc … just the sound fidelity. In Fortnite, sound fidelity and direction is very important for survival. This Razer Nari headset are significantly better than other gaming headsets.

After neatly repackaging the headset, it's good to go as an upgrade for him. Of course, that's 'my opinion' which rarely carries much weight.

reviews.title: Years after its release, still a worthy purchase
reviews.text:
I picked this game up for some variety after starting with DDR Max2 and DDR Extreme. While DDR Max 2 is still my all-time favorite (I own Flow, Pump It Up, Into the Groove, DDR Max 1 and 2, DDR Extreme 1 and 2), this game places second in my book.

It has good variety in the difficulty levels of the songs. Some I can pass on Heavy easily after a year, and some songs I still can't pass on Standard. There are some really slow songs with a hip-hop vibe and some really fast techno ones, and songs in a whole range of styles and speeds, so whatever mood I am in, I can usually get into a good flow with this music and want to keep working out.

There is a training mode just like with DDR Max 2, where you can slow the songs down and gradually speed them up as you get better at each sequence, which is invaluable for Rhythm and Police and Exotic Ethnic, two awesome but very fast songs!

The downside to this game is that it doesn't have nonstop mode like DDR Max 2, but the game mode is structured so that you don't have to keep flipping through a ton of menus if you pass each song, so it isn't as necessary as it is with DDR Max 2.

I am grateful that DDR Max excludes the dancers as I find them distracting.

The (nearly complete) song list (I've starred my favorites!):

22 Dunk - Slake
5.1.1. - DJ Nagureo
Abyss - dj Taka
*AM-3P - kTz
*Baby Baby Gimme Your Love - Divas
Brilliant 2U (Orchestra Groove) - Naoki
Broken My Heart - Naoki (feat. Paula Terry)
*Candy - Luv Unlimited
Celebrate (Beat Mania Version) - JJ Company
Cutie Chaser (Morning Mix) - Club Space
Dark Black Forest (Short Trip) - Steve Rhyner
Deep In You - DJ Nagureo
Do It Right (Harmonized 2 Step Mix) - SOTA (feat. Ebony Fay) Drop the Bomb (System S.F. Mix) - Scotty D.
Dynamite Rave (Down Bird Sota Mix) - Naoki
*Ecstasy - D-Complex
Electro Tuned (the SubS mix) - TaQ E
*Exotic Ethnic - RevenG
*Gambol - Slake
Gentle Stress (AMD Sensual Mix) - Mr. Dog (feat. DJ Swan)
Get Me In Your Sight (AMD Cancun Mix) - Symphonic Defoggers with 1479
Gradiusic Cyber (AMD G5 Mix) - Big-O (feat. Taka)
Groove 2001 - Sho-T (feat. Brenda)
Healing Vision - De-Sire
Healing Vision (Angelic Mix) - 2MB
Holic - TaQ
*I Like To Move It - Reel 2 Real
I'm For Real - Slake
Insertion - Naoki
Jam & Marmalade - Final Offset
Kind Lady - Okuyatos
*Let the Beat Hit Em! (Beat Mania IIDX Version) - Stone Bros.

reviews.title: Great songs, annoying "game" plot to unlock them initially
reviews.text:
This is a great game for exercising; nearly all the songs made me want to get up and move! I own DDR Max 1 and 2, Extreme 1 and 2, Flow (the rap DDR!), Pump It Up, and Into the Groove, and this is one of my most-played DDR games because of the awesome songlist.

I love how modern and danceable the songs are, and I love that so many of my old favorites are on here (Afronova here I come!). I embarassingly enough love the silly pop songs like Oops! I Did It Again, Crazy in Love, and Genie in a Bottle, and then there are others that have become favorites to dance to like Butterfly (a fast remix), Spin Spin Sugar (in which the arrows get you to turn around, which is fun!), Block Rockin' Beats, Get Busy (Shake That Thing), La Copa de la Vida (a great salsa-y track that gets me shimmying along), Pump Up the Volume, I Will Survive, Play that Funky Music, and Boom Boom Dollar.

There is a huge selection of background dancers to choose from (which I don't use, as the dancers don't really dance along with the music or keep to the beat - I prefer to just see the background animations on their own), and loads of videos.

The one thing I dislike about this game is that you have to play their rigidly-structured "game" in order to unlock songs, where you have to start dancing on a super-easy mode and pass lots of songs, while the songs you are given get harder and harder. There are some levels that have songs where the arrows come from the wrong direction or you have to hit the dance pad as many times as possible *without* hitting any arrows. This wasn't fun to me; I really wish I could have just unlocked all the songs and special additions by playing the normal old way - selecting my own level and passing new songs. It would have been fun as an additional option but I didn't care for being forced to play it to unlock all the songs.

Even with this complaint, this title is well worth adding to your DDR collection. The songs are varied and fun enough to keep you playing for a long time.

reviews.title: I like a lot of the songs, but hate the unlock process
reviews.text:
I have all the other DDR and DDR-type games for PS2, and am enjoying this one so far, though I really hate the Stellar Master Mode, which you are forced to play to unlock new songs. You can get points to purchase new songs from playing the normal way, but you unlock songs to purchase by playing the Stellar Master Mode, which features all sorts of odd challenges, like strange arrows or arrows that move in odd ways. I play DDR by freshening up my instinct and so retraining my instinct to follow odd arrows is not any fun for me.

Then a lot of the songs are a bit too easy for me. I am not a great player by any means, so when I can get an A on Heavy (or Expert as they call it now) Girls Just Wanna Have Fun on my first try it is a bit disappointing. I'd like to have something to work towards!

Still, if you are a fan of the series this will give you some fun new songs to play! But if you are new to the series I'd get DDR Extreme 2 or DDR Max 2 - those are my favorites.

The following are the fresh out of the box songs that you get, and the rest you have to unlock:
